Title: Summer delight! Flight to Chandigarh from March 29
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Indore: People travelling between Indore and Chandigarh will have a direct flight connectivity option from next month with Indigo airline announcing to start its service on the route.

As per sources, the airline will start the flight from March 29 on daily basis.

As per a tentative schedule, flight 6E-6014 will depart from Chandigarh at 06.25pm and reach Indore at 08.15pm. The flight 6E-6015 will depart from Indore at 08.45pm and reach Chandigarh at 10.35pm.

“The airline has already started taking booking for this flight,” said airport officials.

The airline has also announced to operate a flight between Lucknow and Bhopal thrice a week, and the flight has been made open for booking from March 30.

Airport director Aryama Sanyal said that this would be an addition in number of flights that have been proposed to be operated under the upcoming summer schedule. “With increase in number of flights, passenger footfall is also expected go up,” she said.

The director added the airline has also sought permission for night parking of two ATR type aircrafts in addition to existing parking lots for two Airbus 320 aircrafts.

Members of Travel Agents Association of India (MP&CG Chapter) said that it was one of a long-pending demands of passengers and they also suggested for flights on others routes. “There is good number of passengers on Indore-Chandigarh route. Airlines should also give focus on launching flights from Indore to destinations like Pune, and Jaipur,” the association’s president Hemendra Singh Jadon said.

Title: Mathura man who set his car on fire outsideSSP’s office in Sept 2019 booked under NSA
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Agra: Mathura district police slapped the stringent National Security Act (NSA) on Shubham Chaudhary, on Tuesday, for setting his own car on fire outside the SSP office in September last year. Chaudhary has been behind bars for the past five months and NSA charges were slapped on him after he applied for bail recently.

Mathura SSP Shalabh Mathur told TOI that the case was registered against Chaudhary as there were apprehensions of breach of public peace if he was released from jail. Mathur said the suspect had earlier opened fire in the air at a public place besides burning his vehicle in front of the district court and police office.

According to police, 23-year-old Chaudhary had created a ruckus on September 25, after his dalliance with a married woman was exposed. He had fired in the air and threatened that the woman accompanying him would shoot herself if anyone tried to stop him. Police later managed to nab him and the married woman, who was accompanying him. Both were booked by the police under section 307 (attempt to murder) and section 7 CLA Act.

The SSP told TOI that Chaudhary was scheduled to get engaged to a local girl the day before his arrest but the same did not materialize as the woman’s husband disclosed his relationship with his wife to the girl. He had then decided to take revenge against the woman’s husband by accusing him for all wrongdoings and took this step, he told police during interrogation.

On September 25, Chaudhary dressed in a lawyer’s attire, set his vehicle S-Cross (UP-50-CI-7533) on fire in the evening. He had come there along with the woman and her three children. They claimed themselves to be representative of a private company. The accused had a portable public address system and addressed the people standing on the road. He talked about corruption in the country and the political system and hurled abuses at the politicians of the day.

Title: Now, train gets one minute stoppage at Uppal railway station
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

SECUNDERABAD: The Secunderabad Superfast Express has been provided with one minute stoppage at Uppal Railway Station for a period of three months on an experimental basis with effect from February 20.

Train No. 12757 Secunderabad – Sirpur Kaghaznagar Superfast Express will arrive and depart Uppal Railway station at 10:44 am and 10:45 am, respectively. Train No. 12758 will arrive and depart Uppal station at 4:54pm and 4:55pm, respectively. TNN

Title: Babaria defends Scindia, says he’d have said the same thing
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Bhopal: AICC general secretary in charge of Madhya Pradesh, Deepak Babaria, on Wednesday sought to suggest that all’s-well in state Congress, defending Jyotiraditya Scindia and saying he has not spoken anything that should be perceived as going against the Kamal Nath government.

“I have seen the entire video clip of what he (Scindia) told a gathering of contractual teachers. There is nothing objectionable in what he said,” Babaria said at the PCC office in Bhopal on Wednesday. A day ago, chief minister Kamal Nath had said that he was not annoyed with Scindia.

On February 14, Scindia had told guest teachers, who are on strike for regularisation of service, that he would “hit the streets with them” if the Congress government didn’t fulfil its manifesto promise. He reiterated it a couple of days later despite the controversy it created. Soon, BJP was taking potshots at Congress over the “faction fight”.

On Wednesday, Babaria spoke up in defence of Scindia. “There was nothing wrong in what Scindia said in that meeting. He said that Congress does not believe in jumlebaazi. Manifesto promises made by Narendra Modi and Amit Shah, when they promise to give Rs 15 lakh in every bank account, can be jumlebaazi. But in Congress, we mean what we promise. We are committed to our manifesto promises and from the first day initiated the process to fulfil farm loan waiver. The first phase has been implemented, and the second phase is on. In five years, all farm loans will be waived,” he said.

“Scindia, in his speech, explained that there are many issues, like regularization of contractual teachers’ issue that need to be resolved,” Babaria said. “But the Union government has drastically cut funds for Madhya Pradesh because there is a Congress government here.”

“Pressures like this come in a democracy. The issue of contractual teachers requires a reasonable solution. There may be hindrances in the path of finding a solution but we stand with contractual teachers in that journey,” Babaria said, adding: “I would have said the same thing had I been in Scindia’s place because we have made a commitment in our manifesto.”

On the controversy over Scindia leaving a Congress coordination committee meeting in Delhi early on February 15, Babaria said: “The entire issue is a matter of perception. Scindia had told me that he had an appointment at 12 noon. He said he would come for the meeting but would have to leave at 11:45am. A section of media wanted to show Congress in a bad light. So, there came the walkout story.”

Title: Ekm GH to get digital x-ray unit
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Works under way on the super-specialty block

Kochi: General Hospital (GH), Ernakulam, which is awaiting a sea change in the patient care and facilities through e-health project, will soon get digital x-ray facility . The state government has given administrative sanction for procuring the machinery using Rs 1.75 crore from the asset development fund of T J Vinod, MLA.

Digital x-ray facility will help patients get the results immediately. According to Vinod, the Ernakulam GH has become first general hospital in the state to get the facility. “GH authorities have informed that they will take immediate steps to procure the machine. We expect that the facility can be launched within a couple of months,” said Vinod. “We also plan to introduce more facilities at the hospital,” he said. The process to float tender for procuring the machine will be started soon. In a week, around 400 patients undergo x-ray tests at the hospital. As of now, the patients depend on the more than 15-year-old x-ray machine.

The digital x-ray facility will also support the e-health project being implemented in the hospital. Meanwhile, there is a slight delay in the implementation of e-health project, which should have become operational by the end of February. Now, the project may be launched by April end, hospital authorities said. “Laying of cables as part of the e-health project is fast completing,” said an official associated with the project.

“Once the e-health project becomes a reality, patients don’t have to stand in queues for registration. All the treatment details will be available at the hospital’s computer systems. Moreover, the results of diagnostic tests will reach the doctors immediately. This will improve the quality of patient services at the hospital,” said the official.

The construction of Rs 86-crore super-specialty block also is progressing. “The contractors have offered to complete the work by June,” said a hospital official. The project is being funded by Kerala Infrastructure Investment Fund Board. As per the proposal, super-specialty wings would be introduced in nephrology, neurology, urology, gastroenterology, neurosurgery and medical oncology.

Though construction of the building may be completed soon, deployment of staff and doctors will be a difficult task. An additional of around 60 doctors, including specialists, assistant surgeons and casualty medical officers, will have to be deployed for the super-specialty wing. For the nursing department, 12 head nurses, 164 staff nurses, 75 nursing assistants and 55 technicians will have to be appointed.

Title: NRK helpline received 1.77L calls within a year
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Having completed a year of operation, the Global Contact Centre ( GCC ), the helpline for non-resident Keralites (NRKs) at Norka Roots, the public sector undertaking under Norka (Non-Resident Keralites Affairs) department, has attended around two lakh calls and chats from 33 countries.

The centre, which functions round the clock, received a total of 1,77,685 calls and 37,255 chats on its website after chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan inaugurated the facility during the west Asian regional conference of Loka Kerala Sabha (LKS) held at Dubai on February 15, 2019, said an official release issued here on Monday.

The Norka, through its website, has so far received 2,320 complaints. The GCC, meanwhile was launched to enable NRKs to request for Norka’s services and to register complaints. The services are available through international toll-free number 0091 8802012345, and NRKs residing in other Indian states can call on 1800 425 3939.

Majority of the calls to the GCC were from NRKs residing in UAE and Saudi Arabia, while calls were also received from Qatar, Kuwait, Bahrain, Indonesia, Afghanistan, Oman, Germany, Turkmenistan, Iran, North Korea, Malaysia, Sri Lanka, UK, USA, Cambodia, Georgia, Italy, France, Ireland, Laos, Myanmar, Philippines, Russia, South Korea, Spain, Taiwan, Tajikistan and Thailand.

“Now, efforts are on to improve the functioning of the centre to be more beneficial to the NRKs,” said Norka Roots CEO K Harikrishnan Namboothiri in the statement.

Title: KMDA to hire agency for a year to maintain Bypass
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Kolkata: The Kolkata Metropolitan Development Authority ( KMDA ) plans to engage an agency for a year to repair , restore and maintain the Ultadanga-Garia stretch of E M Bypass , which is damaged apparently due to shoddy work by different utility service providers every year, especially during the monsoons.

“The firm that will be selected for a year will be given the responsibility of taking up urgent repair and restoration of damaged spots as and when required. The agency will look after the maintenance of the Bypass stretch for one year,” a KMDA official said, adding most of the potholes and craters were created owing to some fault on the part of a utility service provider on the thoroughfare. The total value of work has been fixed at a little over Rs 1.9 crore. According to the terms and conditions of the tender floated, only “bona fide, reliable and experienced firms or individual contractors who have experience working with government and government undertaking bodies, having completion certificate of executing at least 40% value of similar nature of work on a single contract within the last five years”, are eligible to place bids.

KMDA authorities pointed out that despite patchwork on their part, potholes springing up on Bypass, especially near Metro construction sites, had become a yearly problem. “Potholes appearing on the Bypass stretch have become a regular affair, especially during the rains. For the rest of the Bypass, we took up repairs whenever required. But repairing craters created by utility service providers becomes an additional burden on us,” an official said.

KMDA and RVNL has for the past few years trading blames of the repeated deterioration of certain portions of the Bypass stretch between Ultadanga and Garia , where Metro construction has been on. While KMDA claimed the road near Metro sites was damaged due to the constructions and that RVNL should repair them, RVNL insisted they had been taking up repairs in their areas . One such stretch was below the Hemanta Mukherjee station, which RVNL reportedly repaired. However, the agency made it clear that it will not be responsible for road repairs near stations after their work was completed.

Title: Cusat students demonstrate new payload retrieval system
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Kochi: The third year electronics and communication engineering students of the School of Engineering (SoE), Cochin University of Science and Technology (Cusat), successfully conducted the demonstration of a reusable payload retrieval system developed by them. The payload retrieval system safely brought down the weather forecast system payload, which scaled up to a height of 30,000m, and sent data to earth on Wednesday. The demo of the project ‘Mission 100kft’ was held during the SoE’s tech fest ‘Dishna 2020’, which was inaugurated by Indian Space Research Organisation former chairman G Madahavan Nair.

“The objective was to prove that the payload, developed by Advanced Centre for Atmospheric Radar Research (ACARR), Cusat, for weather research, could be launched to high altitudes using nitrogen-filled balloons, tracked, retrieved and reused. Sensors and equipment like radiosonde worth Rs 12,000 could be sent up like this and brought back and reused avoiding the loss of huge amounts for each launch,” said Timothy Simon Thomas, a student and the mission director.

“The payload retrieval system developed by Cusat students will lead to a long range of experiment prospects regarding space,” Nair said. Registrar K Ajitha, School of Engineering principal George Mathew, ACARR director K Mohankumar, electronics and communication division professor Rekha K James were present.

Title: Bhopal: BRTS ‘free-for-all’ rule awaits implementation
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

BMC officials said implementation of the new rule will take time

BHOPAL: A day after BMC mayor-in-council approved vehicles to ply within dedicated BRTS lane along metro rail construction zones, the gates were locked for non-BRT traffic. Bhopal city link limited (BCLL) wardens were not aware of the new rule.

“It is for the metro rail construction company to place track diversion signages along the BRTS. Notification was only passed yesterday. It will take time,” said BMC additional commissioner and BCCL CEO, Pawan Singh. The relief to commuters moving from Board Office to Hoshangabad road is expected to ease the ride for thousands. MPMRCL offcials said they were not intimated about the new proposal to permit all vehicles through BRTS lane.

On Wednesday, some of the drivers took advantage of open BRTS gates near Habibganj railway station. However, others were stopped from entering the BRTS lane. Almost 50% of the 8km stretch from Board Office to Misrod is not manned by BRTS traffic wardens.

The traffic flowing between the BRTS along Habibganj added to more chaos. There were a few near fatal accident situation with BRTS bus drivers not warned about the new rule. Other public transport including Mini Bus took advantage of the BRTS bus stop.

BMC mayor in council on Wednesday passed a resolution permitting all vehicles to play within dedicated BRTS lane in locations where metro rail development work is in progress.

Title: HC orders police to book man for forging bank’s NOC
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: The Aurangabad bench of Bombay high court recently directed city police to register a case against a man for forging a bank’s no-objection certificate (NOC) and submitting it to the regional transport office (RTO).

The man had forged the letter to show that the Paithan-based bank had issued him the NOC to sell his vehicle that he had bought by taking loan from the bank. The truth came to fore after the RTO officials wrote to the bank seeking confirmation about the NOC.

Subsequently, the bank filed three separate applications with the police. However, when police failed to act, the bank — Shivaji Nagari Sahakari Bank Ltd — moved high court by filing a criminal writ petition through lawyers MS Karad and SS Thombre, seeking directions for the police to register a case against the defaulter under appropriate provisions of the law.

Other than the 47-year-old suspect, Sanjay Bhikaji Salve, the petitioner had made the state government, Aurangabad commissioner of police and inspector of Satara police station as respondents.

On September 27, 2019, when the matter came before the high court, the bench had passed an order in this case following submission of Salve’s lawyer that “he will make payment of the loan amount (to the bank)”.

Salve had stated in his statement to police that he had given the vehicle to a person for use, but that man did not return the vehicle.

The bench comprising justices TV Nalawade and MG Sewlikar, on February 10, observed: “Not a single paise has been deposited by the respondent No.4 (Salve). Admittedly, the NOC was not issued by the bank, but such document was made, created and used and subsequently the vehicle was also not found with the respondent. All these circumstances show that there was intention to deceive the creditor and with that intention the aforesaid steps were taken by the respondent No.4.’’

It added: “When the application is given to police of aforesaid nature and there is record of the aforesaid nature, it is the duty of the police station concerned to register a crime. It is a cognizable offence, but no crime as such is registered and nothing was communicated in respect of the aforesaid correspondence. In view of all these circumstances the petition is allowed. Direction is given to the police station concerned to register the crime on the basis of the aforesaid record the applications given in the police station.”

Title: High court dismisses PIL seeking CBI probe
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Kochi: The high court , on Wednesday, dismissed a public interest litigation ( PIL ) seeking a CBI probe into the alleged missing of 25 rifles and 12,061 live cartridges from Kerala police.

A division bench comprising chief justice S Manikumar and justice Shaji P Chaly dismissed the PIL filed by George Vattukulam of Thrissur. While dismissing the plea, the court said the petitioner was not able to bring any materials regarding the case before the court other than media reports and that it cannot order a CBI probe based on media reports alone.

Senior public prosecutor Suman Chakravarthy had argued on behalf of the government that the PIL based purely on media reports is premature and that the state government is taking sufficient action.

The PIL had stated that the missing of rifles and cartridges, which was pointed out in the CAG report, has serious implications on national security. The petitioner had alleged that neither the state government nor the state police chief are conducting a proper investigation. Police force is trying to cover up the matter and a fair probe is not being conducted, the petitioner had alleged.

Even as the court dismissed the PIL seeking a CBI probe on Wednesday, yet another plea was filed before the court raising the same demand. The petition filed by P P Ramachandra Kaimal of Changanassery demanded an order for a probe by either CBI or NIA. tnn

Title: Feeling the heat: Coronavirus likely to hit ship movements at Vizag Port
Content: As the economic damage caused by the outbreak of coronavirus mounts around the world, authorities at the container terminal of Visakhapatnam port expect a 20% drop in ship berthing from March as a result of the deadly disease. They claimed, since mid-January number of berthing confirmations at the terminal has reduced considerably.“We are expecting a drop of 20% in ship berthing at the container terminal from March. Already the number of berthing confirmations has fallen. This might be a fallout of the coronavirus epidemic,” a senior official from the Visakha Container Terminal told TOI.The coronavirus epidemic broke out in China last December and till Wednesday there has been 74,185 confirmed cases in the country. A little over 2,000 people affected by the disease have died in China. Several other countries have also reported cases of coronavirus, including India.However, an official said that they, at the Visakhapatnam port, have not felt the impact of the virus until now. This is because the shipping lines make passage plan and take berthing confirmation at least 45 to 60 days in advance.“Those ships scheduled to berth at the terminal in January and February had sought confirmation from us sometimes between November and December. There had been no such effects on the movement of those ships. But, now we are expecting the bad time to begin,” the official added.The container terminal handles 30 to 35 ships a month. Most of these vessels come from China and other North and Southeast Asian countries. The highest numbers of rakes the terminal has handled are 46 in August 2018 and 44 in September 2019.

Title: Fair conduct of annual exams a top priority: Agra University VC
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Agra: Senior professor of economics, Ashok Mittal, took charge as the vice chancellor of Dr Bhimrao Ambedkar University on Wednesday. The VC said that fair and peaceful conduct of the session 2019-20 and annual exams starting March 2 will be his top priority.

The VC met teachers and asked them for cooperation in changing the “negative image of Agra University”. Talking to media persons, the VC said, “I will first analyze the problems and then plan the course of action for a complete solution. All possible efforts will be made to bring back the high reputation of the varsity.”

Before taking charge as VC, Mittal was serving as a professor of economics in the Aligarh Muslim University. A former student of Agra University, Professor Mittal has a teaching experience of 43 years and research experience of 36 years.

According to the official announcement made by the Raj Bhavan, Mittal after taking charge as VC, will be serving for duration of three years.

The 64-year-old professor completed his Ph.D from Banaras Hindu University in 1987. His research and teaching areas of interest are macroeconomics, public finance and econometrics. He did M.A. (economics) and B.Sc (Mathematics and Statistics) from Agra University.

Currently, he is the vice-president of Uttar Pradesh - Uttarakhand Economic Association. Besides, he is life member of Indian Economic Association and The Indian Econometric Society.

Title: Ahead of Trump’s visit to Taj Mahal, additional 500 cusec water from Ganga canal released to replenish dry Yamuna, mask foul smell
Content:
Additional water will flush away the muck and the clear water will add to the majestic view of Taj Mahal.

TimesView It's heartening that the visit of the US President has brought good health to the Yamuna. A clean river in the backdrop of the Taj is not only a tourists' delight, but also a boon for the residents. The authorities should take it forward from a two-day affair and make efforts to ensure a permanent solution for the river's rejuvenation. Both tourists and the Taj city residents deserve a clean Yamuna.

AGRA: Ahead of US President Donald Trump’s visit to the Taj Mahal on February 24, an additional 500 cusec of water has been released from the Upper Ganga Canal to improve the "environmental condition" of Yamuna river that flows beside the monument and to meet water scarcity in Agra. This will flush away the dirty water and muck, and the relatively clear water in the river will add to the majestic view of the Taj.According to a letter issued by the Uttar Pradesh government, 500 cusec water has been released from the Kot escape in Gautam Budh Nagar on February 17 evening and it will reach the Yamuna in Agra via Mathura on February 22 evening.Talking to TOI, irrigation department superintending engineer Dharmendra Singh Phogat said the aim was to maintain a certain level of water in the Yamuna till February 24. “If 500 cusec of water has been released to control pollution in the river, it will certainly have an impact. This will also improve the oxygen levels in the Yamuna in Mathura and Agra. This move may not make the water in the Yamuna fit for drinking but could reduce the foul smell emanating from the river and improve the water quality," he said.Phogat told TOI that 150 cusecs of water is released throughout the year from Harnol escape, Vrindavan. But this time, additional 500 cusecs of water has been released from the Kot escape in Gautam Budh Nagar that will flow into the Hindon river 18 km downstream and then into the Yamuna in Noida and finally reach Mathura and Agra.Irrigation department’s superintending engineer, Agra circle (III), GP Srivastava told TOI that 1,500-1,600 cusec of water is flowing in the Yamuna here (Agra) at this time. “Additional water will increase the level of water in the river by nearly 1 ft,” he said.Agra district magistrate Prabhu N Singh said the Yamuna is also being cleaned. "It is part of the preparations for US President’s visit to Agra.”An activist, Gopeshwar Nath Chaturvedi, who had filed a petition in the National Green Tribunal (NGT) and the Allahabad high court for cleaning and maintaining the ecological flow of the Yamuna, told TOI, "The move will surely have a positive impact on the river, but only for a day or two. They (authorities concerned) should do this on a permanent basis so that pilgrims and tourists can also see a clean Yamuna.Vikrant Kumar, Uttar Pradesh irrigation department SDO (sub-divisional officer), Haridwar, told TOI, “The Merrut divisional office had asked us to release 500 cusec of water into the Upper Ganga Canal from the Bhimgoda barrage, and additional water is being released since February 12. Currently, a total 10,500 cusec of water is being released daily from the barrage into this canal. The water is being used for irrigation in western part of Uttar Pradesh. Around 1,500 cusec is released for drinking water supply in Delhi.” (With inputs from Shah Nawaz)

Title: UP BJP MLA, 5 sons, nephew booked for gang rape
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

UP BJP MLA Rabindranath Tripathi

Title: Man gets 20-year jail for eloping twice with minor
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Ahmedabad: A man will have to spend 20 years in jail for eloping with a minor girl on two occasions. A special POCSO court in the city sessions court on Wednesday handed down 10-year jail terms to the person in each of two cases, which he has to serve separately because they were separate offences.

In this case, Bhimabhai Bavari, 34, a father of four children, first eloped with the 16-year-old girl from his neighbourhood in Sardarnagar on June 18, 2015. They lived for a brief period in a nearby area. Three days later when they were found out, Bavari escaped. An FIR was lodged for abduction of the minor, rape and offence under the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act. While on the run, Bavari returned and eloped with the same girl again on August 2, 2015.

He took the girl to Ajmer, hired a room and lived there till August 21, 2015. Bavari was arrested and booked under sections363, 366, 376 of the Indian Penal Code as well as POCSO Act for raping her.

On both occasions, Bavari’s friends too were booked for abetment.

During the trial, assistant public prosecutor Bharat Patani examined 16 witnesses to prove Bavari’s guilt. Since the victim was a minor at the time of incident, the aspect of her consent did not count. Special POCSO judge N P Saiyed found Bavari guilty.

The court, however, acquitted Bavari’s friends.

Title: ‘People should bring change in edn system’
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Trichy: Celebrating knowledge is an Indian tradition, but the same has now become a burden, said Atul Kothari, national secretary, Shiksha Sanskriti Utthan Nyas.

Saying that all the national-level issues in the country are because of the flaws in the education system, he said discussing problems in the education system has been an academic activity across the country. But the task of finding solution to it is left to the government.

“A democracy where the society and intellectuals depend on government will never succeed. Therefore, Gyanotsav 2020 is organised as a base to start a movement to bring in solutions to the prevailing problems in the education system, he said.

A good government will frame good policies, fund and support good institutions. But bringing in change in the basic education system must be realised by the people.

Value education is discussed a lot these days, which is part of the new education policy. While it will be introduced across the country through syllabus, Kothari said that “no value education can be inculcated among children through textbook syllabus unless teachers and parents are ready for it.”

Government and society need to work together for the change and discuss solutions. There cannot be any alternative to motherland and mother language. Our education system should be based on mother language and there is a need for a positive movement, he said.

“Moral education was an integral part of education system but slowly the system changed, and we dropped it from our curriculum,” Bharathidasan University vice-chancellor P Manisankar said.

NCT principal R Sundararaman said that our education system is far from ideal even after 70 years of Independence. All the reforms, internal assessment and autonomy have not yielded the required results. We need to reorient the purpose of education. The purpose of SSUN is to reinvent traditional wisdom, which will help provide quality education, he said.

Title: Three of gang arrested for robbing govt bank
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Agra: Agra police on Wednesday busted a gang of six men and arrested three for allegedly robbing a government bank last month.

Identified as Gagan Solanki, his brother Bhanu Solanki of Jaithra Etah district and Jay Prakash Singh of Bulandshahr, currently putting up at rented accommodation in Aligarh, were arrested. The other three accused Sultan and Naresh are still at large.

SSP Agra Babloo Kumar said, “On January 29, the gang had robbed Rs 3.10 lakh cash from a government bank in Barahan at gunpoint. Later, the cash was distributed among the gang members. The gang was planning another robbery when they were caught. A country-made weapon was also recoevered from their possession.

All the accused are history-sheeters with criminal cases such as robbery, theft, attempt to murder, assault and others.

Title: BDU organises numismatics, philatelic & antiquity exhibition
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Trichy: The two-day numismatic , philatelic, notaphily and antique exhibition began with the display of some rare coins, currency notes and stamps in the main campus of Bharathidasan university on Wednesday.

Organised by the history department of BDU along with the Tiruchirappalli Numismatics Society (TNS), the event had a display of archaeological artefacts starting from pre-historic period to the present.

P Vijay Kumar, president of TNS, said Chera Chola, Pandya, Pallava and Nayak era coins were on showcased, apart from coins from British India and over 200 global countries.

He said that world’s biggest currency note from Manaysia of 600 ringgits was displayed along with the smallest from Russia which attracted interest among university students. Currency notes with highest denomination of Zimbabwe and Czechoslovakia were also displayed in the exhibition.

Numismatics section has displayed coins of micro size to the currency notes of the biggest and smallest size in the world. While metal coins made of gold, silver, bronze, Aluminium, nickel and bimetal coin, plastic coins introduced by Transnistria country were also in display.

Every day technology section has interesting artefacts such as pre-electric lighting systems, iron boxes, prayer tools, hair dressing instruments, locks and keys of pre-colonial times, weights and measures.

“Items which reflected the rural arts and culture that were interesting part of the exhibition,” said S Ganesh a student from university. “Early radios, cameras, and projects are displayed in the electronic section,” he said.

Title: Telangana high court gives state four weeks to explain encroachments on Hussainsagar
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: Taking a serious view of a complaint that the state was allowing encroachments and concrete structures right in the midst of the lake bed of Hussainsagar within its full tank level (FTL) area, the Telangana high court on Wednesday issued notices to the chief secretary, municipal administration principal secretary, GHMC & HMDA commissioners, Water Board MD and TS pollution board member secretary, giving them four weeks to explain the steps being taken to protect the lake bed.A bench of Chief Justice Raghavendra Singh Chauhan and Justice A Abhishek Reddy, which converted a letter written to the CJ by social activist Lubna Sarwat into a public interest petition, also appointed senior counsel L Ravichander as amicus curiae who was tasked with submitting a first-hand report on the ground situation.Highlighting encroachments in an extent of 10 acres of Hussainsagar lake bed, the letter sought immediate eviction of encroachers from the FTL area where it pointed out that even tar roads have been laid. Sarwat, who also enclosed photos of structures in the FTL area, in her letter said: “We conducted a field survey as recently as on January 19 and it is evident that the open public space is in danger. Huge barricades are also being put up.”The bench adjourned the case till April 1.

Title: Poor construction, 272 flats for urban poor in Agra to be razed
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Role of nine engineers associated with the project is being investigated.

AGRA: A total of 272 flats of the 632 being constructed by the UP Housing and Development Board for urban poor in Kalindi Vihar in Agra will be demolished after an investigation by a team from IIT Roorkee pointed out that these are not suitable to live in because of poor quality of construction. The team found that sub-standard materials were used and standard norms were violated while constructing these 272 flats.

The report said the walls have not been plastered properly, and the concrete on the roof has come off at several places, exposing the iron mesh. There are cracks on the columns. Besides, the sewer line was not laid properly, the report said. Following the report, these flats have not been allotted.

Role of nine engineers associated with the project is being investigated.

Under the Basic Services for Urban Poor (BSUP), the UP Housing and Development Board in 2008 started construction of 632 flats for economically weaker section (EWS) category. The construction of the one-bedroom flats was completed in January 2020 with a cost of Rs 22 crore.

A year back, following complaints of poor quality of construction, the state government ordered a probe, following which experts from IIT Roorkee were roped in to conduct an investigation.

A senior officer of section-29 of UP Housing Board said, "A total of 272 EWS flats at Kalindi Vihar are not suitable to live in. Soon after the orders of the state government, all these flats will be demolished. A proposal has been sent to the state government in this regard”.

Title: Aurangabad: Jail imparts English lessons to inmates
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Around 50 inmates have enrolled themselves for the first batch

AURANGABAD: The Aurangabad central prison authorities with the help of a local non-government organisation (NGO) have started an English-speaking course for inmates in order to help them hone their skills and prepare them for making a living in a righteous manner.

With this programme, the prison authorities are confident of producing good English-speaking professionals and translators. Around 50 inmates have enrolled themselves for the first batch.

For ensuring the desired results, the NGO has roped in a professional language training institute. Jail superintendent Hiralal Jadhav, while informing that it is the first prison in the state to train inmates in spoken English , said the first batch’s training would last for a period ranging between three and six months.

Moreover, to ensure that the training benefits the inmates professionally, certificates would be issued to those completing the training module and cracking the examination held by the institute.

Prison authorities informed that the inmates are being trained in a manner that at least they could cash on city’s tourism potential by turning in to tourist guides. “Apart from training them to become tourist guides, they are also being trained to become translators, data entry operators,” said an officer privy to the pilot project initiated on Tuesday at the central prison.

“No specific criteria have been prescribed as a pre-requisite for taking admission in the course. However, the inmates with considerably good overall behavior in the prison are being preferred for the course,” he added.

In all there are around 1,200 inmates lodged in the prison that has an intake capacity of 600 inmates. As on date, the inmates manufacture series of articles including Khadi kurtas, towels, high quality teak wood furniture, among others. Of late the prison has also started offering year-round laundry services at reasonable rates.

Title: Coronavirus: Passengers begin leaving virus-hit ship, but Silk City's wait for son continues
Content:
Representative image

BERHAMPUR: Even as a section of coronavirus-free passengers on board the Diamond Princess — a cruise liner quarantined off the coast of Yokohama in Japan since February 3 — was allowed to disembark on Wednesday, the family of a 27-year-old software engineer from Berhampur voiced their concern about his well-being and reiterated their appeal to the Centre to secure his release.Sibashis Nayak is among six Indian passengers on board the cruise liner anchored off the coast of Japan for the past two weeks because of the coronavirus outbreak. Sibashis, who works in a Delhi-based company, was part of a six-member team of software engineers who visited southeast Asia on January 10 and later went on to board the Diamond Princess, which was quarantined after one of its passengers, who had gotten off at Hong Kong, tested positive for the disease.The Diamond Princess has 138 Indians on board — six passengers and 132 crew members. Of the crew, seven have so far tested positive for coronavirus.“We are extremely worried about Sibashis’s health. He has been on the ship for the past 15 days,” said Lingaraj Nayak, father of the software engineer.Lingaraj, a businessman, also requested chief minister Naveen Patnaik to secure the rescue of his son. “Sibashis tested negative for the disease when a routine check was carried out,” he said.On Wednesday, it was not immediately clear if the Indian passengers had also gotten off the ship. Nayak’s father, too, could not shed light on the process of disembarkation of Indian nationals.“Indian crew who tested positive for #COVID19 among 88 new cases yesterday (Tuesday) on #DiamondPrincess taken to hospital for treatment. Indians receiving treatment responding well. From today, disembarkation of passengers only started, likely to continue till 21 Feb,” the Indian embassy in Tokyo tweeted.“Some countries like Canada, the US and Australia have evacuated their passengers from the ship. India should do the same,” Lingaraj said. “I was in touch with my son through WhatsApp. He is desperate to come home,” said Sibashis’s mother Jhunu Nayak. “We are worried about what he is eating. Vegetarian Indian food is not available,” she added.The family said they had earlier contacted the manager of Sibashis’s company. “He assured us that our son would be rescued soon. He is likely to be brought to Delhi,” Lingaraj said.MP (Berhampur) Chandra Sekhar Sahu on Wednesday wrote to external affairs minister, S Jaishankar, for the Odia engineer’s rescue.

Title: Medico tests negative for COVID-19
Content: Visakhapatnam: While the reports of the 18-year-old medico tested negative for coronavirus on Wednesday, another 23-year-old house surgeon from Nanjing in China has been admitted to the government TB and chest hospital.As per reports, the house surgeon had decided to return to India for a while after the outbreak of coronavirus. She landed in Visakhapatnam on February 8, and later developed suspected coronavirus symptoms and was admitted to the hospital. The medical staff are waiting for her reports, which are expected to come in by Thursday evening, sources said. Meanwhile, the first-year MBBS student was discharged on Wednesday after reports reached Visakhapatnam from National Institute of Virology in Pune and SVIMS in Tirupati.The city girl joined MBBS course at Kunming city in Yunnan province of China in November 2019, and returned to Visakhapatnam on February 13. She was admitted in the chest hospital on February 16 with suspected coronavirus symptoms.“We sent the samples for tests on February 16, the day on which she was admitted. The reports reached us on Wednesday and it was negative. So we decided to discharge her,” district medical and health officer Sanapala Tirupati Rao told TOI.The city has reported three suspected Covid 19 cases so far. The first case was reported last month when a man from Dubai was admitted with suspected coronavirus symptoms. He was discharged after reports tested negative.

Title: NMC draft budget to be tabled on Feb 25
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Nashik: The presentation of the draft budget of the Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) has been deferred till February 25, after the civic chief was summoned by high court on Thursday.

The civic chief was supposed to present the draft budget before the standing committee on February 20, but now it would be presented on February 25. Top NMC officials had a meeting on Tuesday and decided to defer the budget presentation.

“The civic administration has prepared a draft budget for the next financial year 2019-20 and it is to be presented before the standing committee of NMC for its approval,” said the NMC officials.

“The Bombay high court has issued a directive asking the municipal commissioner to remain present before the court on the same day at 11 am. The civic administration has deferred its draft budget presentation,” said NMC officials.

Last year, municipal Commissioner Radhakrishna Game presented draft budget of Rs 1,894.50 crore to the standing committee for the current financial year 2019-20. The standing committee had revised the budget and added additional works worth Rs 89 crore, taking the budget to Rs 1,983.50 crore.

The General body of NMC had increased the standing committee’s budget by another Rs 94 crore, taking the total budget of the NMC for the current fiscal to Rs 2,189 crore. Considering the availability of funds, the civic administration decided to implemented the budget presented by the municipal commissioner.

According to sources, the municipal commissioner is likely to present the budget of around Rs 1,950 crore for the next financial year 2020-21.

Title: Kodungallur suicide: Police surgeon team inspects house
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Thrissur: A team of police surgeons, on Monday, inspected the house in Kodungallur where four members of a family were found hanging last week.

Police surgeons Dr Manu Johns Chowalloor and Dr Neeraja inspected the home in the presence of Kodungallur CI P K Padmarajan and SI E R Byju. The police team said the four had committed suicide . The bodies of Kozikkada resident Thiaparampath Vinod, 44, wife Rema, 38, daughter Nayana, 17, and son Neeraj, 9, were found hanging inside their home on February 9.

Last week, the police received audio messages which were allegedly sent by Rema to a shopowner. The voice messages say that Rema had quarrelled with her husband and he had threatened to hack her. Irinjalakkuda deputy SP Famous Varghese said, “Rema, who worked in Regal Stores at Vadakkenada near Kodungallur, had sent voice messages to the shopowner Abbas which said that she had a verbal spat with her husband over working in the shop.”

“Rema had joined the firm 24 days before her death, but she had worked there several years ago under another management. The voice messages show that Vinod was upset about Rema working in the shop and they quarrelled over it,” said Varghese. “The family members had no contact with relatives or neighbours. As per evidence collected, the family committed suicide,” Varghese added.

Police also decoded messages which Nayana had sent to her friend. However, they found nothing unusual about the message and ruled out any link with the suicide.

The postmortem report has revealed that Rema died nearly 24 hours after the death of the other three members of the family. Vinod was found hanging from the ceiling fan while the other three were found hanging from windows.

Title: SP protocol to sanction ‘urgent leaves’ of cops ahead of Trump’s visit
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Agra: Ahead of US President Donald Trump’s visit to Agra, additional director general of police Agra zone has asked Agra SSP to create a nodal officer of the level of SP who will sanction leaves of those cops, who require “urgent break only for emergency work”. Earlier, Agra SSP spoke about the need for “all hands on deck” during Trump’s visit.

After the Agra SSP order, there was concern among cops, and after the ADG’s intervention, SP protocol was asked to sanction leaves for such cops after proper procedure.

On Wednesday, ADG Ajay Anand said, “Though POTUS visit is top priority for us and we need manpower, a blanket ban on leaves is not rational and humane. I have asked to sanction leaves only for those cops, who have family emergencies or a genuine cause.”

However, according to sources at Agra police line, leaves are being sanctioned at various levels, but SP protocol’s involvement in the process will help them maintain a clear record, as how many cops would be available for immediate disposal of the upcoming task.

A total of 3,200 cops, including 1,200 Agra policemen, will be deployed on the entire route for the umbrella protection of the US President. The security perimeter will include around 250 NSG commandos, two anti-terrorism squads, nine superintendents of police, 18 additional superintendents of police, 55 circle officers, 132 inspectors, 450 sub-inspectors, 50 women sub-inspectors, 100 women constables, 2,000 constables, 10 each PAC and RAF companies and one flood company which will guard the Yamuna.

Title: No downsizing of Naidu’s security, says DGP office
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Vijayawada: Clarifying further on the security arrangements for former chief minister N Chandrababu Naidu , the state DGP’s office issued a statement on Wednesday stating that they would once again review it in the upcoming security review committee meeting.

In a bid to put an end to the controversy over downgrading Naidu’s security arrangements, police said they would try and strengthen it if possible, but assured that no downsizing would take place. “The former CM continues to hold the country’s highest security arrangement under the Z plus category. Currently, there are 135 personnel working in Vijayawada and 48 of them in Hyderabad are providing him the necessary security,” the statement reads.

The statement comes a day after TDP slammed the state government’s decision of downgrade Naidu’s son Nara Lokesh’s security arrangement from Z to X category. TDP state president Kala Venkata Rao said the strength of security personnel has been drastically brought down by about 50%, from 146 to 67.

“The state police has found evidence that Naidu and his family members are still facing threat. The government has decided to reduce the security with mala fide intentions and with political motivation,” Rao stated.

Title: I would choose Constitution over Lord Ram: Madhya Pradesh minister
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Higher education minister speaking at the ‘How to Understand Gandhi’ lecture in Barkatullah University on Mond... Read More

BHOPAL: Higher education minister Jitu Patwari on Wednesday said if he has to choose between Lord Ram and the Constitution, he would pick the Constitution.

Addressing a lecture on ‘How to Understand Gandhi’ at Barkatullah University in Bhopal, Patwari said: “I proudly say that I am a Hindu. I believe in Lord Ram. Every day, I pray to be a good human being. I wish god never lets a situation arise where I have to choose between the Constitution and Lord Ram. In such a scenario, I will choose the Constitution.”

When TOI contacted him later, the minister said: “I am a Hindu, a Ram Bhakt. I follow the teachings of Lord Ram, pray to Him daily and seek his blessings that no one should ever be hurt by me.”

Patwari asked students to follow the path of non-violence and truth shown by Mahatma Gandhi. “Gandhiji’s teachings are always for love for each other and unity,” he said.

The Madhya Pradesh government has made it mandatory to set up Gandhi statues at every new university in the state. “We have established Gandhi Peeth for research in 1,400 colleges to make the youth aware of the ideals of Gandhiji,” said Patwari.

Writer Nand Kishore Acharya and legal expert Kanak Tiwari expressed their views at the seminar. Vice-Chancellor R J Rao and historian Geeta Dharmapala were also present.

Title: Dehradun: Hike in transport fares implemented across Uttrakhand
Content:
Representative image

fare chart


DEHRADUN: The hike announced in the fares of intra-city and inter-city public transport on Tuesday by the state transport department was implemented by transport bodies on Wednesday. While transport unions welcomed the move, the hike drew sharp response from daily commuters who said that the increase in fares would hit them hard.“The hike in fares of public buses is still okay but the increase in those of autos and taxis is really steep. A person will now have to shell Rs 1,000-Rs 2,500 more for a trip to hills in a taxi. Similarly, now an auto-driver can charge Rs 80 for a five-kilometre journey. A CNG auto can cover this distance in just Rs 30-Rs 35. I feel that the hike should be reconsidered,” said Sunil Kumar Rawat , a Dalanwala resident.The transport department has created eight slabs for city buses according to which, a commuter has to pay Rs 7 for the first two kilometres against the previous rate of Rs 5. Similarly, for a 6-19 kilometre journey, which is the average distance one travels within the city, one will have to pay Rs 25 as against Rs 20 earlier. The department has set Rs 40 as the maximum fare which can be charged by a bus which covers a distance of more than 29 kilometres within the city.The transport authorities have also increased the rates of both public and private inter-city buses. The passengers will now have to pay Rs 1.05 per kilometre for a journey in a public bus in plains and Rs 1.50 per kilometre if it’s a private bus. The previous fares were 86 paisa and Rs 1.09 respectively. In the hills, roadways buses will charge Rs 1.80 per kilometre.As for autos, Rs 50 has been set as the fare for the first 2 kilometres and Rs 15 for each extra kilometre. Also, autos can charge 50% more than the set fares between 10 pm and 5 am, according to the new guidelines.For non-AC taxis, the fares have been raised from Rs 11 per kilometre to Rs 14 per kilometre in plain areas while for AC taxis, the new fares are Rs 16 per kilometre as against Rs 14 per kilometre earlier. In hills, a non-AC taxi and an AC taxi would now cost Rs 14 per kilometre and Rs 18 per kilometre respectively.Meanwhile, the city bus union and auto-tempo associations welcomed the hike, claiming that this was a long pending demand.

Title: Ahmedabad: Police rehearsals for US President Donald Trump's trip from today
Content:
Decorated light at Airport circle to welcome PM Narendra Modi and USA president Donald Trump in Ahmedabad on W... Read More

AHMEDABAD: Deployment rehearsals for the visit of US President Donald Trump to the city will begin on Thursday. These will cover not just the route Trump will travel, but the will cover the entire city including vulnerable areas, said a senior police official.DCP, control room, Vijay Patel, said 10,000 cops will be involved, including 25 IPS officers, 65 ACPs, 200 police inspectors and 800 police sub-inspectors, along with two companies of the Rapid Action Force (RAF) and ten companies of the State Reserve Police (SRP).“These forces will be involved carry out rehearsals from Thursday. Members of US agencies who have already arrived will also take part in the rehearsals,” said a senior police official. Police sources said on Wednesday a high-level meeting was held in which the deployment of police officers, National Security Guard (NSG) commandos and commandos of the Special Protection Group (SPG) was decided.

Title: Coronavirus aftermath: Govt mulls stimulus, faster green clearances to back local manufacturing of APIs
Content: NEW DELHI: The government is mulling a fiscal stimulus package and faster environmental clearances to support local manufacturing of some identified active pharmaceutical ingredients (API) used as raw material in medicine formulations, official sources said.The move comes in the wake of concerns of shortage of some key medicines amidst the coronavirus outbreak in China – which is the major supplier of API to not only India but across the globe.In a high level meeting on Wednesday, chaired by NITI Aayog chief executive Amitabh Kant, the government assessed the present situation and discussed several measures including an API policy to revive local manufacturing of API and bulk drugs.“The government assured that it will recommend fiscal package and benefits for the API industry, similar to what has been extended to mobile handset manufacturers in the budget to boost local manufacturing,” an official, present in the meeting told TOI.India imports around 80-85% of APIs from China. While some major pharma companies like Lupin, Sun Pharma and Dr Reddy’s Laboratories manufacture APIs locally for some medicines, but it is mostly for captive use.Local manufacturing for API has been unviable in India as China supplies them at 10-15% lower cost. For past many years, the government has been contemplating a policy to revive the local API manufacturing through incentives etc. However, the policy is yet to be finalised.Apart from officials from the government’s think tank, the meeting at NITI Aayog was attended by senior officials from the department of pharmaceuticals (DoP), National Pharmaceutical Pricing Authority (NPPA), Central Drug Standard Control Organisation (CDSCO) and senior executives from the pharmaceutical industry Meanwhile, the DoP has sought orders from the directorate general of foreign trade (DGFT) restricting export of the 12 APIs and formulations. In a letter to DGFT, the department suggested companies should be temporarily restricted from exporting 12 drugs including antibiotics, hormones and vitamins – raw material from which is largely sourced from China’s Hubei and Shandong provinces.However, the industry maintained that there are adequate stocks of both API as well as formulations to continue till mid-May.“The shortage is a perceived shortage. The market always has a stock of medicines for 45 days. In addition, we have a stock of 30 days in our factory. Apart from this, most of the industry – mainly the large players – keep a 90 day inventory of API. Only small scale players are doing panic buying. There is no real shortage,” head of one of the leading pharmaceutical companies said.However, the government maintains that it needs to take precautionary steps to avoid any cascading impact on supplies of essential medicines. “We need to think from the perspective of public health and ensure that supplies continue. Therefore, we have recommended a temporary restriction so that there is no shortage or price hike for patients,” an official said.Though new cases of coronavirus in China appears to be slowing, the death toll from the infection in mainland China crossed 2,000 on Wednesday. China's National Health Commission reported 1,749 new cases, the lowest daily rise since January 29, while Hubei province - the epicentre of the outbreak - reported the lowest number of new infections since February 11. The latest figures bring the total number of coronavirus cases in China to over 74,000 with 2,004 deaths, three quarters of which have occurred in Hubei, provincial capital of Wuhan.

Title: Earning grandparents, not jobless mother, get custody of two kids
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Ahmedabad: A family court in Ahmedabad has ordered that the custody of two minors, aged eight and six respectively, be given to their earning grandparents rather than to their jobless mother, who herself takes shelter at different family members’ homes.

The family court judge Nizar Ali Karovadiya ordered in a judgment pronounced on February 13 that if the custody of kids was changed then it would traumatize them as the children have been staying with their grandparents constantly and not with the mother.

In August 28, 2017, a Saraspur resident, Sunita Patni, mother of the two kids, had filed a petition with the family court seeking custody of her children from their grandparents — Kanu and Meena Patni, residents of Bapunagar.

Sunita states in the petition that her husband Vijay Patni died on March 19, 2015 following prolonged illness. Later in July 2016, Sunita had gone to her parents’ place as her father fell sick. Sunita had alleged that her in-laws harassed her and did not allow her to meet her children.

On other hand, Kanu and Meena Patni’s advocate Shahenaz Saiyed contended that the kids were brought up by their grandparents only, who provided them education, health and shelter unlike their mother who herself is not earning and depended upon her family members.

The family court judge observed that the court has to decide on the point of welfare of the children and not on the rights of the parents.

“The children are living with the opponents (grandparents) before and after the death of their father and hence sudden change in their custody would traumatise them. Applicant mother failed to prove that in paramount interest and welfare of the minors, the custody of minors requires to be given to her. It is very clear from the evidence on record that the applicant is not entitled to get the custody of the minors,” the court ordered.

The court observed that children should not be deprived of their mother’s love and ordered that she could take their custody in the evening of every second Saturday and bring them back to their grandparents on Sunday morning.

Title: Power demand spikes, but on expected lines
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Power consumption in the state has started spiking with average daily demand crossing 77 million units (MU) on Tuesday. The situation will turn alarming when demand touches 85 MU.

“The 77 MU demand for energy is somewhat normal. There is an average 4-6% annual growth in energy demand in the state. We expect the demand to keep below 80 MU per day, on average, throughout the summer season. Of course, there could be instances of demand going up above 80 MU occasionally. The real worry would begin if the demand goes up consistently and crosses all expectations and touch 85 MU and remains so. But we don’t really expect such a situation this summer,” KSEB chairman and managing director N S Pillai told TOI.

The major multipurpose reservoirs owned and run by Kerala State Electricity Board Ltd are above or close to 50% of their storage capacity. The average water level in the dams is calculated as 63% by KSEB.

The water levels in major KSEB reservoirs:

storage capacity: 1460 mcm

Storage capacity: 31 mcm

storage level: 86

storage capacity: 33 mcm

Title: Man involved in loot arrested after police encounter
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Varanasi: A dreaded criminal Saurabh Malviya and a police constable suffered bullet injuries in a police encounter in Bamhor area under the limits of Mubarakpur police station in Azamgarh district on Wednesday evening.

Malviya and his gang members were on the radar of police following the loot of Rs 1.50 lakh from a customer help centre on February 17, said ASP city Pankaj Kumar Pandey mentioning that the police had also announced a cash reward of Rs 25,000 on him. The ASP said that the motorcycle used in February 17 loot incident had also been recovered from Malviya’s possession. Malviya and constable Pramod Kumar were admitted to the district hospital where their condition is stated to be stable.

The police had got clues regarding involvement of Malviya’s gang in the loot incident after which the police launched a manhunt for them, he said. On Wednesday, the police teams received some inputs regarding the movement of the gang in Mubarakpur area following which they cordoned the area. The police tried to intercept him when Malviya, along with his accomplices, passed through the area on two motorcycles. On seeing the police, they opened fire. In retaliatory firing by the police Malviya was injured in leg while his accomplices managed to escape.

Group clash: A general merchant shop owner Jhinku Ram and a customer Harinarain suffered bullet injuries when some motorcycle-borne miscreants opened fire on them in Vajidpur area under Kaptanganj police station in Azamgarh district on Tuesday night and fled the scene.

Angered over the incident, people of Dalit dominates areas of the village attacked the place of one Ramesh Singh alleging that he had planned such attack on Jhinku Ram over a land dispute. Following this Rameh and his supporters came face to face and both the groups indulged in brick batting.

Several persons of both the groups suffered injuries in the clash. Later, police rushed Jhinku Ram, Harinarain and other injured including Baljit to the hospital. Both the groups had filed complaints to police in this connection.

Title: Dy speaker seeks report on nala work
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Secunderabad: Deputy Speaker, T Padma Rao has sought a detailed report on Pedda Nala at Boudha Nagar. On Wednesday, Rao convened a meeting with officials of Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation and Hyderabad Metropolitan Water Supply and Sewerage Board (HMWS&SB), and asked them to conduct a detailed survey on the works proposed to widen the nala. TNN

Title: HC summons civic chief
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Nashik: The Bombay high court has summoned Nashik municipal commissioner Radhakrishna Game, asking him to be personally present before the court on Thursday.

The bench comprising Justices S Kathawala and Milind Jadhav gave the instructions on February 17 while hearing a writ petition filed by the parents of two school students. The petitioners were seeking a direction to the civic body to make the Don Bosco Road area hawker-free as five educational institutes, including a hostel, were located there.

“During the hearing, the court directed the Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) to remove the illegal hawkers and encroachments near the schools within eight days. However, the civic body had sought more time. That is when the court directed the municipal commissioner to be personally present before the court on February 20 at 11 am,” said Sachin Shinde, the lawyer for the petitioners.

Game confirmed to TOI that the court has directed him to be personally present on February 20.

In their petition, the parents had pointed out that the problem of illegal hawkers began on that road, towards the Thatte Nagar stretch, from June 2018. “Due to the presence of these illegal hawkers, problems like illegal parking, sale of junk food and littering of the area have surfaced. It also leads to traffic congestions, posing threat to the safety of students,” claimed the parents in the petition.

According to them, various hawkers park their food trucks not more than 20m from the school premises and the adjoining educational institutions. “The students were affected due to the sale of junk food. The increase in traffic and illegal parking has also made the area unsafe for the school children, who travel on bicycles or by foot, the parents added

The petitioners also drew the attention of the court to the fact that due to the nature of hawking, it attracts anti-socials who consume alcohol and create nuisance on that road. Some of these anti-social elements also harass the students.

According to the petitioners, parents and school authorities have taken up the issue with the NMC at least six times. “But the NMC failed to realise the seriousness of the problem,” said the parents.

NMC sources said that removal of encroachments takes time as due process has to be followed and, therefore, has sought more time.

Title: CM: Let district industrial centres guide investors
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The district industrial centres should transform themselves as places that will help and guide investors , chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan said.

Inaugurating the workshop organised by the industries and commerce department, the chief minister said in addition to officials, industry experts should also be encouraged to visit the centres at least once in a week for guiding the investors.

The chief minister said the management of public sector undertakings should be done scientifically and the industries department should provide necessary training programmes in this regard. The PSUs should also appoint full-time directors in addition to CEOs and MDs, who can undertake day-to-day activities of the PSU, the chief minister said.

While suggesting that industries related to agriculture should be given more focus, the chief minister said the government is in the process of setting up coconut parks and a factory on the lines of CIAL for producing value-added products from rubber. He said the value-added products from agriculture products have great potential.

Stating that the government is considering industrial estates in collaboration with private sector, he said the biggest strength of the state is startups. In addition to IT sector, startups should come up in other sectors too, he said. He added that the government is aiming at facilitating the startups in other sectors as well. The government will facilitate in such a way that all investors including NRI investors can invest their funds safely.

Kerala has climbed up in the list of states with respect to sustainable development index. He said while the state scored only 68 points in 2018, it improved to 88 points in 2019. Industries minister E P Jayarajan, state planning board vice-chairman V K Ramachandran and principal secretary (industries) K Ellangovan spoke on the occasion.

Title: 12,000 public toilet complexes to be built on highways across state
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The state government has decided to ask all local self governments to find three cents of land each along the state and national highways to construct toilet complexes.

The cabinet meeting on Wednesday decided to construct 12,000 such toilet complexes along the highways. Each of the toilet complexes will have separate male and female toilets .

Dearth of public toilets is causing difficulties for people, especially women and children, while travelling by road across the state. There is also a situation that toilets at petrol pumps are restricted to its customers, observed the cabinet meeting. It is against this backdrop that the government has decided to come up with toilet complexes across the state. Agencies willing to cooperate with the project would be made partners. Plots belonging to government, public sector undertakings and cooperative institutions would be utilised for the purpose.

Complexes will also have small shops and snack parlours in potential areas, according to the cabinet decision. The construction and maintenance expenses of the complexes would be borne by respective local self governments.

Finance minister Thomas Isaac had promised this proposal in his budget speech for the year 2020-21. In his speech he had said 12,000 public toilets will be constructed in 2020-21.

“In addition to the renovation of existing toilets in petrol pumps, toilets in ‘take a break rest centres’ under Kudumbashree and toilets sponsored by other government agencies and public sector undertakings, local self government institutions will also set up toilets. This is essential for attaining complete clean status for the state.” Isaac had said in his budget speech.

Title: Kerala: Sree Chitra develops low cost stent graft
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Sree Chitra Thirunal Institute of Medical Science and Technology (SCTIMST) has developed affordable aortic stent graft and its delivery system for the treatment of thoracic aortic aneurysm .

An aortic aneurysm is a ballooning or enlargement of the aorta. Aortic aneurysm is a disease affecting about 5% of the population in their late sixties and can be fatal in case of rupture.

Most patients with aortic aneurysms do not have any symptoms at all. The aneurysm is usually discovered by X-ray during a routine health exam for some other, unrelated condition.

“As there is no indigenous device available in the market for thoracic aortic aneurysm, the institute decided to develop an indigenous affordable stent graft and its delivery system. The imported stent graft (along with its delivery system) costs at least Rs 3.5 lakhs,” said Dr Asha Kishore, director of the institute.

The stent graft is made of polyester fabric in tubular form and are scaffolded by NiTi (Nickel Titanium alloy) rings (stents), which are sewed in to the tubular fabric. The NiTi rings were made in collaboration with National Aerospace Laboratories, Bangalore (CSIR-NAL).

The stent graft is crimped to a lower diameter and is inserted in to the catheter sheath (small diameter delivery tube) of the delivery system.

The stent graft has been developed by the project team headed by Dr Sujesh Sreedharan, Engineer-F, division of artificial internal organs, biomedical technology wing, Dr Jayadevan E R, additional professor, imaging sciences and interventional radiology, Dr Santhosh Kumar K, additional professor, imaging sciences and interventional radiology and Dr Unnikrishnan M, professor, cardiovascular and thoracic surgery.

The stent graft expands and fixes firmly on the inner aortic wall because of the super elastic property exerted by the NiTi rings. Once the stent graft is in place, blood flow occurs only through the conduit created by the stent graft, thus excluding the aneurysm and preventing its rupture.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Man arrested for branding daughter with hot spoon
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: A man was arrested by the all women police station (AWPS), Jeeyapuram in Trichy on Tuesday for branding his 11-year-old daughter with a hot stainless steel spoon.

The accused has been identified as T Govindaraj, 48, of Kallikudi.

Last week, the girl went shopping with her aunt without the knowledge of her father. Enraged, Govindaraj heated a stainless steel spoon and branded the girl on her right shoulder, right thigh, left armpit and right cheek.

Some relatives noticed the injuries when the girl attended a marriage on February 13. One of them called Childline and alerted officials.

Childline coordinator Muralikumar rescued the girl on February 14 and produced her before the Child Welfare Committee (CWC), Trichy. The committee referred the girl to Mahatma Gandhi Memorial Government Hospital (MGMGH). After treatment, the parents took her home. But her mother was reluctant on filing a case against Govindaraj.

“The family members including the mother attempted to cover up the incident since he was her father. Since we were aware of the issue and the girl was severely wounded by the branding, it was our duty to bring the culprit before the law,” Muralikumar told TOI on Wednesday.

On the direction of the CWC, Muralikumar filed a complaint based on which the Jeeyapuram all-women police registered a case and arrested Govindaraj. He has been remanded in judicial custody.

This is the second such incident within one month reported from the district.

In the earlier incident, a24-year-old man was arrested for sexually assaulting his 12-year-old minor stepdaughter and branding her with hot iron on her body in Woraiyur on January 25.

Title: Farmers worry as pests infect coconut trees
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Thanjavur: Coconut trees in nearly 7,500 acres in and around Thanjavur district have been affected by Rugose Spiraling Whitefly (RSW) infestation, farmers said. Farmers have stressed the need to control the menace in their plantations. However, officials from the agriculture department have asked them to follow a few scientific methods to control the insect attack.

Farmers have raised coconut trees in 95,760 acres in Thanjavur district. Of them, around 7,500 acres are affected by the Rugose pest. Rugose Spiraling Whitefly has been noticed in coconut trees in Peravurani, Pattukottai, Orathanadu taluks and some other places in Thanjavur district. The insects suck sap and causes damage to leaf fronds by secreting a honeydew-like substance on the leaves. It induces the development of sooty mould fungus and because of this leaves turn black reducing photosynthesis rate, joint director of agriculture department, Thanjavur, A Justin said. A Palanivel, a progressing coconut farmer from Kuruvikarambai in Peravurani taluk in the district, has coconut trees in 35 acres.

The pest was spotted on his coconut trees, he said. “Several coconut trees in our taluk have been infected by the pest. Agriculture department officials should visit coconut groves and help farmers to control the pest immediately. Last year farmers lost their trees in Gaja cyclone. This year the pest may cause loss,” he said.

Meanwhile, the agriculture department has suggested various measures to control the menace. They have asked farmers to conserve natural enemies of the pest like encarsia parasitoids, chrysoprase and coccinellids in coconut ecosystem by avoiding insecticides. Placing yellow sticky traps smeared with castor oil or horticultural mineral oil can be used for monitoring the population. If needed spraying neem oil @ 3% or neem seed kernel extract @ 5% could help minimizing the population build-up.

Title: Naidu launches ‘Praja Chaitanya Yatra’, slams CM for ‘ruining’ state
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Martur (Prakasam): TDP president N Chandrababu Naidu on Wednesday said chief minister Jaganmohan Reddy has ruined the state in the nine months since YSRC came to power.

Naidu launched his state-wide ‘Praja Chaitanya Yatra ’ with a public meeting at Murtur in Prakasam district on Wednesday.

Speaking at the meet, Naidu said the state government owed an explanation to the people as to why big firms like Reliance and Adani backed away from putting their money in the state. He said that Kia Motors was contemplating to leave the state due to panic created by the government.

“What is the use of having 75% reservations in industries when no industry is coming to the state,” Naidu asked. He said that the state has lost nearly Rs 1.8 lakh crore investments in the last nine months.

He said that Jagan had taken a Tughlaqian decision to create three capital cities for the state only out of his vengeance against his plans to build an economic super power capital city Amaravati. He said that a big capital city would have created many jobs.

“Amaravati is being seen as the capital of a one particular community. Can any city survive with one community? Can we find any town or village in the state with a population of one particular community? Is it not a smear campaign?” Naidu said.

He said that Jagan has stalled development in the state. He said that revenue touched rock bottom with the government struggling to pay salaries. Naidu listed out nine major blunders of the YSRC government committed in the last nine months. He said that Jagan has taken u-turn on many promises including Amma Vodi.

Title: Ahmedabad: CA cheated of Rs 42 lakh by builder, finds his flat sold off
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: A chartered accountant (CA) from the Satellite area of the city on Tuesday filed a complaint of cheating against a builder and two others for cheating him of Rs 42 lakh by selling the same flat and giving its possession to another person which was already sold to the CA.

In his FIR with Ananadnagar police, Malhar Mehta, 39, said that he also works for a Mumbai-based firm which invests in properties. In 2015, Mehta had fixed a deal of buying a flat in a housing scheme named Stavan Avisha made by the builder Mihir Desai through its firm Sambhav Infrastructure Private Limited in the Jodhpur area.

It was decided to pay Rs 42 lakh for the flat out of which Rs 40 lakh was paid though RTGS (Real Time Gross Settlement). On November 20, 2015, Mehta was given the allotment letter, possession letter and he was handed over the flat.

Mehta states in the FIR that he was not provided the documents of the flats. After this, he approached a local court which in January 29, 2018 ordered the builder to give the documents to Mehta. Even after that, Desai did not provide Mehta any documents, states the FIR.

On July 22, 2019, Mehta had sent his employee to the flat for its maintenance work. When Mehta’s staffer, Kalpesh Rabari reached there, he found that someone else was living in the flat. On inquiring about it, Mehta came to know that Desai had first sold the same flat to an Isanpur resident Bharat Padia who had given the flat on rent to another person named Pratik Patel, a resident of Anandnagar.

Later, Mehta approached police and filed a complaint of cheating, breach of trust, forgery and criminal conspiracy against Desai, Padia and Patel.
