Title: Kolkata: NPR a crazy, inhuman idea that will affect everyone’s citizenship rights, says Amartya Sen
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Sen at the release of a book at The Asiatic Society on Wednesday

KOLKATA: Nobel Laureate Amartya Sen on Wednesday described the National Population Register ( NPR ) as a crazy and inhuman idea.

“I think it is a crazy idea. It is against the form of democracy laid down in the country’s Constitution. The Constitution provides there should be no discrimination against any community. It is discriminatory, unconstitutional and inhuman,” said Sen, referring to NPR.

The Nobel laureate was speaking to reporters after releasing a book, “Living World of the Adivasis of West Bengal”, at The Asiatic Society on Wednesday. Asked whether NPR would affect the citizenship rights of Adivasis, Sen said, “It will affect everyone’s citizenship rights. It will affect the rights of Adivasis and all others. Even I don’t have a valid birth certificate. My father and my mother never had birth certificates.” The book Sen released is the outcome of a collaborative research project undertaken by The Asiatic Society and his Pratichi Institute.

Asked about the World Population Review report ranking India as the fifth largest economy in 2019, overtaking France and the UK, Sen said, “There is nothing to be proud of India emerging as the fifth largest economy in the world. It is not surprising that India’s total transactions are greater than that of France and UK. Ours is a much larger population. China is the only country with a population larger than ours.”

Asked about the economic wellbeing of Adivasis in ‘new India’, Sen said, “I find nothing new in the new India. I would have been happy had it been a newer India. People have sought votes of Adivasis with many promises for them. But the reality is that nothing much has been done for them.”

After releasing the book, Sen spoke of deprivation of Adivasis in Bengal and rest of India, a factor leading them to suffer from lack of self-respect. “Their achievements have been constrained because of the disadvantages in their circumstances. There is no question about their deprivation, be it in education, healthcare or social security,” he said

Title: West Bengal: Examinee held with mobile; candidates with gadgets to face expulsion and legal action
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Two Madhyamik examinees, Sujata Singh and Sonali Mahato, from Keshiarai in West Midnapore met with an accident... Read More

KOLKATA/MALDA: On a day a Madhyamik examinee was arrested for using a smart phone at an exam venue in Malda’s Samsi, the West Bengal Board of Secondary Education said that any candidate found with a mobile phone or electronic gadget inside the examination hall shall forthwith be expelled from the examination. The candidate’s mobile will be seized and sent with the answer script to the Madhyamik Board notified as Reported Against (RA). Legal action will also be initiated against the candidate, the board said.

The decisions were announced after state education minister Partha Chatterjee called board president Kalyanmoy Ganguly following the arrest of the student. Six other mobile phones were confiscated from students across exam centres in the state.

A senior board official said: “If a candidate is found to have taken a picture of the question paper with mobile phone and sent it to another person, the officer-in-charge of the main venue shall, on behalf of the board, lodge an FIR with the local police station against the candidate and the recipients of the photographs.”

Even teachers and non-teaching employees will be slapped with charges for violation of any order. As per the decision taken by the Board of Discipline, if any teaching or non-teaching employee is found to contravene restrictions of the board and be involved in any malpractice, they may be debarred from entering the venue to take part in the examination process. Also, after completing a disciplinary committee report, the person may be suspended or disciplinary proceedings may be initiated against him/her. “We hope the decisions will act as a deterrent against such malpractices,” added the board official.

In Malda, the arrest sent ripples among all concerned amid the allegation of question leak for the second day of the examination. What made the situation worse was that apart from several photographs of the English language question papers being circulated through WhatsApp, another set of question paper went viral through TikTok in the first hour.

The boy who was arrested was a student of Baharal High School of Ratua and he was taking his examination at Baidyanath High School of Samsi. He allegedly took the picture of the question paper just after the examination started and sent it via internet. After some time, the invigilator found the mobile with the candidate and detained him. He reportedly admitted that he had committed the misdeed. The school authority informed police and a force from Ratua police station reached the school to arrest the candidate. Police superintendent Aloke Rajoria said: “We have arrested the examinee for taking the mobile phone with him in the exam hall and he would be produced in juvenile court tomorrow.”

Meanwhile, a TikTok video with the photo of the English question paper, which became viral during the examination, was found to be a fake one. Police are trying to find out the source of the video and the question paper seen in this video.

Biplab Gupta, convener of the examination in Malda, refused to comment on the allegation of the paper leak.

Title: Taluk adalats to be held every month
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The state cabinet has decided to convene taluk-level adalats every month to settle grievances of people. The adalats will be held on the third Saturday of every month.

Apart from settling grievances, the adalats are also intended to make government officials more friendly with people. All collectors, tahsildars and district level department heads will also be attending the adalats.

The cabinet has decided to provide prior-notice on the conduct of adalats to people of respective areas. The details of issues settled and decisions taken will be published within 10 days of the conduct of adalats.

All the local self-government representatives and local body heads have also been directed to attend these adalats.

The cabinet also decided to sign a pact with the Netherlands Organisation for Applied Scientific Research with an aim to explore maximum potential of technologies such as the internet of things, big data and machine learning.

As per the agreement, a centre of excellence will be set up in the state by the Netherlands agency. Smart villages, water management, environment, crop security, disaster prevention, etc., are the fields in which the state will explore the possibility of utilising these technologies.

Administrative sanction for Rs 69 crore for executing second phase of Jalagram project for Kozhinjambara, Vadakarapathi and Eruthembathi panchayats in Palakkad has also been given.

Tourism additional director Theja Maila Varapu has been given additional charge as special officer for Kochi-Bengaluru industrial corridor.

A proposal for designating particular zones in city as night shopping zones, which will be open round-the-clock, was also discussed in the cabinet. It will be implemented in Thiruvananthapuram as a pilot project.

Title: Grape containers stranded on border leave for Bangladesh
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Over 100 containers, with 14 tonne of grapes in each, had been stranded on the Bangladesh border for the past ... Read More

NASHIK: More than 100 containers of grapes from Nashik , which had been stopped on the Bangladesh border due to lack of certain permissions, have finally left for Bangladesh after the Union ministry of commerce intervened to resolve the issue.

Over 100 containers, with 14 tonne of grapes in each, had been stranded on the Bangladesh border for the past two-three days. Dindori BJP MP Bharti Pawar had taken up the matter with Union minister Piyush Goyal, who immediately sorted out the issue.

“I had received complaints from some exporters and farmers about the grape containers being stranded on the Bangladesh border. I took up the matter with the commerce minister and settled the issue. Now, all the containers have left for Bangladesh,” said Pawar.

Meanwhile, grape exports from the Nashik district to various European countries have gathered momentum.

So far, the Nashik district has exported around 27,000 tonne of grapes to European countries, including 20,000 tonnes to the Netherlands, 3,000 tonne to Germany and 2,900 tonne to the United Kingdom.

During the same period last year, Nashik district had exported 32,000 tonne of grapes to the European countries.

There has been a drop in grape export when compared to the corresponding period last year. This is because the unseasonal rain in September and October had damaged the vineyards. That had resulted in a drop in export of grapes, said Manik Patil, a senior member of the Maharashtra Rajya Draksh Bagayatdar Sangh, an association of grape growers.

Title: Doctor seeks Rs 20 crore in damages from West Bengal medical council
Content:
Representative Image

KOLKATA: A neurologist has served a legal notice on the West Bengal Medical Council (WBMC), asking it to pay Rs 20 crore for defamation, Rs 60 lakh compensation for loss of income and 7 lakhs for legal cost. The council had barred the doctor from practicing for a year in 2017, holding him guilty of medical negligence while treating a patient in Durgapur. But the Supreme Court set aside WBMC’s verdict in February 2019, exonerating him of the charge. Sources in WBMC said this was the first time the council has received a legal notice for defamation and compensation.The council had suspended neurologist Snigdhendu Ghosh’s registration in July 2017 for one year while pronouncing him guilty of medical negligence in a 2010 case. Challenging the WBMC, Ghosh moved the Calcutta HC which, in turn, quashed the council’s verdict, asking it to reinstate the doctor’s registration.The council, however, filed an SLP at the SC. The apex court too exonerated Ghosh on February 20, 2019, upholding the Calcutta HC judgement passed of 19 July 2018. The HC, while delivering its verdict, had also observed that Gosh could petition for compensation for the time he could not pursue his profession. Ghosh could not practice for 11 months.“I will wait for two months for the council to respond to the legal notice. If they fail to respond, I will file a defamation suit and also seek other damages,” said Ghosh, who now heads the neurology department at Mission Hospital, Durgapur.WBMC registrar Manas Chakraborti said: “We received the legal notice on Tuesday. To my the best my knowledge this is the first time the council has got such a legal notice for paying up a doctor whose licence was cancelled. We are consulting our lawyers and we will move the court against the demand for damages as WBMC has no provision for such compensation.”The case of the medical negligence dates back to December 2010. A teenage girl had died in a hospital in Durgapur a day after she was shifted from another hospital where Ghosh had checked on her, filling in for another doctor, under whom the patient had been admitted. Accusing Ghosh of medical negligence, the girl’s father approached the WBMC.

Title: Guv: Being religious-minded prevents us from sinning
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Trichy: Tamil Nadu governor Banwarilal Purohit on Wednesday said it is good to be religious minded as it will prevent people from committing sins. He also spoke about making India corruption-free.

The governor was speaking here after inaugurating Gyanotsav 2020 - an educational conclave organised by Shiksha Sanskriti Uthan Nyas, New Delhi.

“Human beings have weaknesses. We tend to commit sins thinking that no one is watching us. But if we are religious and fear God, our inner sense will prevent us from committing sins,” he said.

Speaking about a corruption-free India, the governor said former President of India A P J Abdul Kalam had stressed on leading a simple life by being content with “whatever we have.”

“Limit our necessities. Then, even if someone tries to bribe us, we will find it useless as we will not be driven by greed,” he said.

He asked educational institutions to become centres for social transformation.

“Institutions shall adopt villages, provide them support, enlighten them about various schemes of the Centre and the state government and contribute to the welfare of the society,” he said.

He added that over two-third of India’s population comprise youth and if this population is provided with proper skill sets, they shall provide the country with potential quality work force for the next three to four decades.

Title: Terracotta artists hail Rs 250cr outlay for ODOP scheme
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Gorakhpur: Allocation of Rs 250 crore for one district one product ( ODOP ) scheme in the UP budget 2020, has brought smiles to terracotta artists of the district.

The world famous terracotta figures are the part of the ODOP scheme in Gorkhpur district. Ravi Prajapati, a noted terracotta artist said, “I am happy that the government has started thinking about us and this year too, a huge budget for ODOP has been proposed. I want to appeal to the government to also start holding classes of terracotta art in schools. In this way the terracotta art trainers of our village will get and the classes will also promote the age old art. In China, china clay art and pottery are also a part of their school curriculum.”

Another artist Angad Prajapati suggested to start bus service for the artisans from Terracotta village to the main market of the city. “Government support is making our life better. I want to appeal to the government to provide us a showroom in the city and also to run a bus from Terracotta village to the main city to make it easy for the artists to bring their products to the city for sale.”

Title: Pilots’ strike: Air India ordered to compensate NRI couple
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: A consumer court here has ordered Air India to pay compensation to a US-based couple for the inconvenience caused to them due to flight cancellation following a pilots’ strike in 2012.

Indravadan and Ila Amin, an elderly couple originally from Vadodara and based in Austin in USA, had sued the airline in 2013 and the Consumer Dispute Redressal Forum, Ahmedabad city last week ordered Air India to pay them Rs 40,000 compensation for mental agony and hardships.

In this case, the Amins booked their ticket for an Air India flight to Ahmedabad on May 21, 2012. But because the airline’s pilots were on a strike, at Newark airport the couple along with other passengers were sent to a motel, which was full. From there, they were redirected to another motel. After nearly four hours of wandering, they received a call from the airline that they should return to the airport and board a flight to New Delhi. The couple was made to wait at the New Delhi international airport till May 23 morning, when they were given passes for an Ahmedabad-bound plane.

The couple approached the consumer court complaining that they were put to unnecessary inconvenience by the airline and had to travel in a bus in USA from one to the other motel with luggage. They were not even offered a glass of water. They also complained about the delay in New Delhi. The airline defended its case.

After the hearing, the consumer court said that the couple was meted out undue hardships and deficiency in service. “They were made to suffer inconvenience and hardships at Newark and New Delhi airports without their fault. Under such circumstances, it was the duty of Air India to treat the passengers in a very cordial and harmonious manner at both the airports,” the court observed while fixing the compensation at Rs 15,000 for each passenger with 9% interest and Rs 10,000 for expenditure they had incurred on litigation. The couple had demanded Rs 2.51 lakh in compensation.

Title: Battered Mudfort roads give commuters bone-jarring rides
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Secunderabad: The roads in Mudfort area of Secunderabad that fall under Secunderabad Contonment Board (SCB) are causing immense inconvenience to commuters. Following bumpy rides and minor accidents, residents of the area have urged authorities to restore the roads and put an end to their commuting woes. The roads are riddled with potholes and layers of bitumen have been eroded due to weather conditions and poor quality of materials used to lay the road.

“The dust that rises from the surface of the road is a hindrance to the vision of the two-wheeler riders and the uneven roads are dangerous to motorists as well as pedestrians,” said Uma Kanth a resident of Mudfort.

U Santosh, a resident of Bolarum, said that keeping in mind the traffic and the connectivity that the road provides to adjoining areas, repair works must be taken up on war footing.

“The Mudfort road is an important road as a lot of people use it. The road is extremely bumpy and riding on the road is dangerous for pregnant women and senior citizens,” said Santosh, who uses the road frequently.

“As part of the road is covered in sand and granules of bitumen, commuters cannot utilise the complete road. resulting in traffic jam that lasts for long,” he added.

According to officials, the issue will fixed within 20 days. “ We have already identified bad roads in SCB area. The Mudfort road is one among them and the stretch will recarpeted within 20 days,” Secunderabad Cantonment Board vice-president, J Rama Krishna.

Title: Good Samaritan cops help out students
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Kolkata: Three students in Kolkata fell ill while writing their Madhyamik examination. All three were rushed to the Calcutta National Medical College and SSKM, where they wrote their papers after necessary go-ahead from the Madhyamik board.

In another incident, police took an examinee and her mother were taken to the Holy Child School from Shyambazar 5-Point crossing in the official vehicle of Burtolla OC. “She had just a few minutes left to reach the exam centre and she was crying. Finally, she reached the centre at 11.35am, 10 minutes before the papers were distributed,” said an officer.

Traffic sergeant Tapas Sinha and ASI S Saha rushed all the way from Thakurpukur P K Brahmachari Vidyapith to a girl’s home, located 4km away, to get her admit card and registration certificate which she forgot to take with her to the exam centre.

A student, who was supposed to write his exam at Jagatpur Rukmini Vidyamandir, was admitted to CNMC Hospital after he fell sick. The Behala OC talked to the centre and the board to ensure that he could take his exam from hospital. Another student writing her exams at Kasba Balika Vidyalaya was rushed to SSKM Hospital when she reported sick. A third examinee also reported sick at the Calcutta Girls’ academy from where she was shifted to CNMC Hospital by police.

Title: Kidney stones removed sans surgery
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Trichy: A non-surgical procedure used to remove kidney stones, was performed on a 39-year-old woman at the Pudukottai Medical College Hospital on Saturday (February 15).

The procedure - percutaneous nephrolithotomy - which may cost around Rs 1 lakh in a private hospital, was successfully done free of cost in this hospital under chief minister’s comprehensive health insurance scheme.

The patient, Mala from Poondi of Thanjavur district, was admitted in the hospital on Thursday with complaints of abdominal pain.

On examination, it was found that she had right pelvic stone, which is 15mm in diameter. The doctors decided to break the stone without surgery by a procedure called percutaneous nephrolithotomy, which is performed when kidney stones cannot pass on their own from the body.

“Normally, the ureteric stones would be broken by ureteroscopy. But this patient had a stone in the renal pelvis,” said dean Dr Meenakshisundaram. This requires a procedure for which 15 days hospitalization is required and chances of incisional hernia would be high. Therefore, percutaneous nephrolithotomy was planned, he said.

He added that this was the first percutaneous nephrolithotomy procedure done in the government Pudukkottai medical college hospital. He said the hospital did not have the specific nephroscope for this purpose. It was mobilized from outside for the patient.

A team led by dean Dr A L Meenakshisundaram, along with Dr Senthilnathan, Dr Latha, Dr David and Dr Saravanan, performed the procedure.

The surgery lasted for four hours and three units of blood were transfused. The patient was discharged on Wednesday.

Title: Women & child panel accuses civic admin of fund diversion
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Nashik: The women and child welfare committee of the Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) has accused the civic administration of diverting its funds — which amounts to 5% of the total budget — elsewhere.

The committee members alleged that the civic administration is also not taking cognizance of the committee’s decisions.

Mayor Satish Kulkarni has called a meeting of the committee members and the civic officials on Thursday.

“As per norms, 5% funds of the total budget amount is allocated to the NMC’s women and child welfare committee. However, the funds are diverted elsewhere without taking us being taken into confidence. This is a matter of grave concern,” said Hemlata Kandekar, the chairperson of the committee.

“This has been happening for the past three years. By calculation, 5% of the total budget is close to Rs 100 crore. But these funds are being diverted elsewhere by the civic administration,” Kandekar added.

“We have no rights over anything and our works are also not implemented by the civic administration. The repair works at a few angawadis of the municipal corporation had been approved by the general body last year, but they are yet to be taken up,” said Kandedkar.

Kandekar alleged that the committee had also approved the proposal to provide training to women to operate pink rickshaws in the city two years ago. It took almost two years to send this proposal to the general body meeting for its approval. “I don’t know when the civic administration will implement it,” she said.

Committee members Samina Meman, Ranjana Borade and others also the same thing.

The mayor has taken the serious cognizance of the allegation and has decided to call a separate meeting of civic officials and members of women and child welfare committee.

Title: Soon, cuts on dividers to ease commuting woes
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Allahabad: The district administration has decided to provide road cuts on dividers at 21 points across the city, especially at important public utility points, to facilitate commuters who have to cover long distances to reach their destinations.

TOI had raised the issue in October last year.

Many road dividers were constructed in the city as part of smart city project which run for long distances without any cuts or openings. As a result, the commuters either have to jump the dividers, or cover long distance and take a U-turn to reach their destination.

According to officials, the administration has decided to provide cuts at 21 points on different roads including MG road, Nawab Yusuf road, Stanley road, Thornhill road, Kutchery road, PD Tandon road, Master JH road, Prayag Street, Elgin road and Church lane road.

Mission manager of smart city (technical) Sanjeev Sinha said, “As per the norms of the Road Safety Act, commuters should be provided with the facility of zebra crossing. Soon, roads in the city will be provided with cuts and zebra crossings.”

MG Road in Civil Lines area has dividers but planners did not provide a cut and a zebra crossing at Civil Lines bus depot and several other public utility spots on the stretch.

Commuters and passengers on this specific place are more vulnerable because of the fact that it is not only a bus depot but adjacent to it is a mall and state-owned hotel which are frequented by large number of locals as well as people coming from other cities.

Amit Srivastava of Jhunsi said, “Who is asking for a broad opening in dividers? The authorities should at least think of passengers, especially women, for whom crossing the road is a tedious job.”

Title: AAI asks civic body to keep Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel International airport neighbourhood clean
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel International (SVPI) airport in Ahmedabad

AHMEDABAD: In a bid to prevent incidents of bird strikes at the city airport, authorities of Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel International (SVPI) airport in Ahmedabad have asked the civic body to maintain cleanliness in airport neighbourhoods. The concern has been raised specifically in the wake of the upcoming visit of US President Donald Trump. The US president will land at the city airport around noon on February 24.

Some 37 bird strikes were reported at the SVPI airport in 2019, against 87,875 aircraft movements throughout the year. This makes it an average 4.1 bird strikes per 10,000 movements.

“Open disposal of waste in areas near the airport including Meghaninagar, Kubernagar and Sardarnagar often attracts birds. These areas fall in the take-off and landing route of aircraft, causing a safety threat. The Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation ’s (AMC) support has thus been sought by the AAI to keep surroundings of the city airport clean,” said a source.

A Bengaluru-bound flight suffered a bird-strike on Tuesday itself, while rolling for take-off. The Airbus 320 aircraft was eventually grounded. A source also revealed that a few other factors that impact bird movements around the airport and along the funnel area i.e. the take-off and landing route of aircraft, include the Pirana dumpsite and erratic disposal of meat waste around the Asarwa fish market. A series of such representations have been made in the past by the AAI to the civic authorities, in an attempt to curb bird strikes.

Acoustic devices in addition to shot launchers, firecrackers, grass cutting machines and a team of bird chasers has been deployed at the city airport to keep the birds in check.

Title: High vigil, foolproof security for Mahashivratri festivities
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Police team during route march in iBhelupur-Bajardiha area on Wednesday

Varanasi: The holy city, on Wednesday, remained busy in preparations of the Mahashivratri festival falling on February 21.

The police officials held meetings of peace committees and chalked out plans for crowd regulation and security related exercises. Meanwhile, the temple authorities also remained busy in making arrangements for the special religious rituals and programmes to be held in and around the temple on the auspicious occasion.

The series of meetings of peace committees, recently started by the police at all police stations, were held on Wednesday to maintain law and order during Mahashivratri celebrations. The peace committee members were motivated to play an active role in maintaining communal harmony and peace during the festival. The police teams also carried out route marches in sensitive and mixed-populated areas of the city.

SSP Prabhakar Chawdhary said that apart from ensuring foolproof security equal focus is being laid on the crowd regulation exercises for which barricading and barriers have already been installed at all the strategic points of the city. The traffic restrictions and diversions for the festive day will become effective from Thursday night, said the SSP adding that the deployment of outstation police and paramilitary forces will also start from Tuesday night.

Regarding the arrangements for Mahashivratri, chief executive officer of Kashi Vishwanath temple Vishal Singh said that the sanctum sanctorum of the temple will be opened for the devotees for darshan after performing Mangal Aarti between 2.20am and 3.30am on the intervening night of Thursday and Friday. Devotees will be allowed to offer prayers to Lord Vishwanath by viewing him from the doors of sanctum sanctorum, he said. Series of darshan will continue uninterrupted as doors of sanctum sanctorum will remain opened during other aartis, he added.

Meanwhile, other prominent temples of the cities also made arrangements to manage huge crowd expected on the festive day along with the security arrangements. Besides, preparations were also made regarding special religious rituals planned for the day. Many city temples are also being decorated for the occasion.

Title: 1000 more Shiv Bhojan thalis in dist
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Nashik: The state government has increased the limit of serving 1,000 Shiv Bhojan thalis in Nashik district to 2,000 a day and the district administration has started scouting for new centres that would stand by the terms and conditions laid down by the government.

The Shiv Bhojan thali is offered to the needy at just Rs 10 through the state government’s scheme. The thali is served at specified centres across the district. There are six Shiv Bhojan thali centres in the city, of which, four offer 150 thalis a day and two offer 125 per day.

There is one centre at Malegaon that serves 150 thalis a day as part of the government’s subsidized lunch initiative.

The state government pays Rs 40 for each thali and Rs 10 is to be contribute by the beneficiary.

“As per earlier conditions, every city was able to provide food to 700 people per day as every centre could provide 150 thalis. The revised government resolution said that food could be provided to 1,000 people in the city and every centre should deliver 200 thalis,” Nashik district supply officer Arun Narsikar said.

The district administration is now looking for hotels or institutions that can provide Shiv Bhojan thalis to people along with agreeing to the terms and conditions laid down by the government.

“The government has laid down the condition that the Shiv Bhojan thali centre should be a non-profit organization and preferably be run by women self-help groups. The organisation/centre should be able to easily cater to the needy or people coming to the city for work,” the officer said.

Title: US C-in-C likely to give Gandhi Ashram a miss
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Ahmedabad: US president Donald Trump is likely to abort his plan to his visit the Sabarmati Gandhi Ashram on February 24. A detailed press release from the foreign secretary’s office in Delhi states that on February 25 morning — the a day following the Ahmedabad visit — President Trump and first lady Melania Trump will be accorded a ceremonial welcome at the forecourt of Rashtrapati Bhawan. “From there, President Trump and the first lady will go to Raj Ghat to pay respects at the samadhi of Mahatma Gandhi.”

A senior state government official told TOI that it is likely that Trump may drop his plan to visit the Sabarmati ashram as he and Melania are visiting Raj Ghat in Delhi the very next day.

Elaborating on Trump’s Ahmedabad plans, foreign secretary Harsh Vardhan Shringla at a press briefing in Delhi on Wednesday said, “The highlight of the programme in Ahmedabad will be the exhibition of India’s rich and diverse culture and heritage to President Trump in a public manner that has few parallels in India or elsewhere.” As many as 28 stages representing various parts of the country are being set up along the 22-km route of what is being called the ‘India Road Show’. Trump’s visit will be brief but intense, with all essential elements of a state visit, and two additional legs in Ahmedabad and Agra, all squeezed into less than 36 hours, a release from Shringla’s office said.

It adds, “The Ahmedabad road show route will feature decorations depicting different events in the life of Gandhiji, whose association with the city are so well known. The route of their travel to the stadium is expected to have tens of thousands of ordinary citizens of India as well as artistes showcasing the performing art from different states and Union Territories of India. There will be public to greet President Trump outside the Motera stadium. Inside the new stadium, President Trump and Prime Minister Modi will address a capacity audience, which will include people from various parts of India and all walks of life, reflecting the diversity of India. The release states, “President Trump will address the ‘Namaste Trump’ event jointly with Prime Minister Modi at the newly-built Motera Cricket Stadium in Ahmedabad. It will be similar to the landmark ‘Howdy Modi!’ event hosted by the Indian-American community in honour of Prime Minister Modi during his visit to Houston in September 2019, in which President Trump participated.”

Title: Bikes of 11 cops seized for not having papers
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Kolhapur: Gadhinglaj police inspector Prakash Gaikwad has initiated action against 11 police personnel for not maintaining all the required documents of their vehicles.

The police have seized all bikes that did not have necessary documents, including insurance papers.

According to police sources, Gaikwad had launched a drive in the Gadhinglaj jurisdiction to ensure that vehicle owners have proper documentation for their vehicles. After checking the documents, police fined the motorists who didn’t have appropriate documents.

The personnel at the Gadhinglaj police station were surprised when Gaikwad suddenly launched a drive to check the vehicles and documentation of the cops on duty.

“Vehicles of 58 policemen, including constables and police officers, were checked. It was found that 11 of the police personnel did not having proper documents. Most had not renewed the vehicle insurances. One of them was not in possession of his driving license. The vehicles of all these policemen were seized and they were fined as per the rule,” said a senior police officer attached with the Gadhinglaj police station.

Speaking to reporters, Gaikwad said, “The police are always on the road and it is necessary that they have adequate documents with them. During our drive, we found that some policemen did not renew their insurance. It can be dangerous if they meet with an accident. If the insurance is expired, they may face financial losses. We will initiate action against them as per the rule and ensure that the police abide by the rules.”

Title: Another warrant issued against Hardik Patel
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Hardik Patel

AHMEDABAD: A magisterial court at the Mirzapur rural court campus has issued a non-bailable warrant against Congress leader Hardik Patel , who was also the former convener of the Patidar Anamat Andolan Samiti (PAAS), in connection with an FIR registered for taking out a rally in Bopal in 2017 without permission.

As Patel did not attend court proceedings in this case, the court issued an arrest warrant. This is the second arrest warrant issued against Patel for skipping court proceedings.

On February 7, a city sessions court issued an arrest warrant against him for his absence during the trial in a sedition case, in which he had obtained bail last month on the promise of attending court proceedings without fail.

On Monday, the Gujarat high court refused him anticipatory in an offence registered by Vastrapur police more than four years ago, for violence that occurred at the GMDC ground on the evening of August 25, 2015, after Patel took up a fast, following a mammoth rally to push the demand for reservations for the Patidar community.

Patel approached the high court after a city sessions court on January 30 refused to grant him legal protection to him from possible arrest. Citing this possible arrest, Patel had sought exemption from attendance in the sedition case proceedings on February 7, but the sessions court refused to accept his demand and instead issued an arrest warrant for not honouring his word.

Title: No separate objective paper for Class X exam
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Representative image

VIJAYAWADA: The State Commission for Education Research and Training (SCERT) has proposed to do away with separate objective paper in Class X final examination, which is scheduled to begin from March 23 and continue till April 8.

The objective paper will be included in the main question paper unlike earlier when it was a separate paper given in the last half an hour of the examination.

There will not be any change in the number of papers in the examination — two papers for every subject except for second language. The question paper will have 12 objective type questions, eight very short and short answer questions and five essay answer questions.

The weightage for these questions will be 12, 16, 32 and 40 per cent respectively.

The students have to complete the examination within 2 hours 45 minutes. All exams will begin at 9:30am and ends at 12:15pm. A 24-page booklet will be given to the students. There will not be any marks in the memo and grades will be published based on the marks secured by the students. Pass marks will be calculated based on the total marks secured in paper-1 and paper-2 for each subject except for second language subject.

Title: Citizens must not face hardship: CM
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Gandhinagar: Chief minister Vijay Rupani is reported to have directed senior officials of the state government to ensure that citizens are not put through hardship because of the measures being taken for the Trump trip. Rupani was referring to complaints of alleged harassment of residents, vendors, and shopowners along the route that the US president and PM Narendra Modi will take.

In Wednesday’s cabinet meeting, the CM is also reported to have chided officials about the reports of alleged harassment to citizens damaging the perception of the high-profile visit.

A key source in the government said, “In the meeting, the CM expressed displeasure over the series of complaints of harassment of commoners by the local administration and police.” The source said the CM stressed that “too stringent action” must not be taken in the name of security. “The CM asked chief secretary Anil Mukim to ensure that the state government is not shown in bad light as a result of actions of officials ahead of the visit of the US president,” the source said.

Nitin Patel raises the issue of invites

In Wednesday’s cabinet meeting, deputy chief minister Nitin Patel raised several key issues regarding the preparations for the ‘Namaste Trump’ event. A sources said, “Patel stated that only four working days remain before the arrival of Trump, and VVIP invites and parking passes are yet to be distributed.” The source went on to say: “Patel suggested that printing and distribution of invites should be taken up immediately and also sought better co-ordination among agencies.”

Title: Personnel dept staff agitate against SRMU functionary
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Trichy: A section of railway employees of personnel department affiliated to southern railway mazdoor union (SRMU) in Trichy railway division has complained to the Divisional Railway Manager (DRM) a functionary of SRMU used filthy language against them, while they were in Mayiladuthurai to distribute Unique Medical Identification (UMID) cards to the railway employees.

The staff said they were at Mayiladuthurai to distribute Unique Medical Identification cards to the employees on February 13. While the staff were on their duty to hand over the cards, Senior Section Engineer Manivannan arrived there and opposed them. When they explained that they had arrived there as per superior’s instruction, Manivannan had scolded them using filthy language. TNN

Title: KTU’s pooled recruitment drive for Infy
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: For the first time since its inception in 2014, APJ Abdul Kalam Technological University is organzing a pooled campus recruitment for engineering students.

The recruitment drive, planned exclusively for Infosys , say university sources, would be a boon for meritorious students who missed out on campus recruitment opportunities owing to location disadvantage of their colleges. Major recruiters are often reluctant to go to colleges in far-flung areas. However, students from major colleges are not barred from participating in the pooled drive.

The first batch of BTech students graduated from the varsity in 2019. The pooled drive planned is for students completing their course with impressive academic track record in 2020. The drive is likely to be held on February 27, 28 and 29.

“Infosys has requested the university for such a pooled drive. It would be held in the last week of February at Saintgits College of Engineering in Kottayam district. The college has volunteered to host the pooled drive and Infosys too has expressed satisfaction over the facilities available there,” sources said.

Over 4,000 students have already registered for the combined selection drive, and among them a majority are students from self-financing engineering colleges. “The number of students who applied for the drive from government, aided and government run self-financing colleges are very few, compared to private self-financing colleges,” sources said.

According to them, it could either be because the students from government and aided colleges have already received very good offers through campus placements or have not properly been informed about it by the college authorities.

No registration charge would be levied on students who participate in the pooled drive. The partnering college would be providing all infrastructure facilities, including online testing facilities for over 250 candidates at one go.

University authorities would ensure that students get worthy offers and are not entangled in oppressive bonds by the recruiters.

Arresting a year-on-year slump, admission figures in engineering colleges in the state has recorded an 8% upsurge in 2019, as per the student registration details collated by the university.

Title: Five pose as policemen, kidnap youth and extort Rs 12 lakh from him
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Representative image

KOLHAPUR: The Juna Rajwada police have arrested five suspects for allegedly kidnapping four youths and extorting Rs 12 lakh from one of them by posing as police.

The Juna Rajwada police said the suspects had threatened to invoke charges under the Maharashtra Control of Organised Crime Act against one of the kidnapped youth . Three more suspects involved in the case are at large and police are on their lookout.

The arrested have been identified as Yogesh Shankarrao Patole (32, resident of Medhe Park, Near Shingnapur water tank, taluka Karveer), Tahir Shabbir Magdum (30, resident of Azad chowk, Herle, taluka Hatkanangle), Noman Dilawar Shekh (19, resident of Temblai Naka, Railway gate no.2), Suraj Sunil Bhosale (24, resident of Herle, near KDCC bank, taluka Hatkanangle) and Gajanan Sachin Thorvat (30, resident of SaneGuruji Vasahat, Kolhapur).

All were produced before local court on Wednesday and the court sent four of them into police custody up to February 24 and Thorvat to magistrates custody.

Police have registered a case under sections 364 (A) (Kidnapping for ransom, etc.), 386 (Extortion by putting a person in fear of death or grievous hurt) and section 170 (Personating a public servant) of the Indian Penal Code. Shahu Sandip Powar (19, resident of Sane Guruji Vasahat, Kolhapur) lodged complaint in this regard.

Pramod Jadhav, inspector in-charge of Juna Rajwada police station, said, “Powar is a college student. On the afternoon of December 4, 2019, four suspects approached Powar’s friend, who was loitering at Gandhi maidan and forcibly took him in their car. They enquired about Powar’s financial background and later released him.”

“On December 5, when Powar and three of his friends, including the one who was earlier kidnapped, were standing at a cyber chowk, the suspects kidnapped them. The suspects pretended that they were police officials attached with local crime branch and had picked them as they had information that the four youths were involved in criminal activities,” Jadhav said.

Jadhav said that the suspects demanded that Powar pay Rs 34 lakh. “They threatened to book Powar under charges of rape and robbery and invoking MCOCA against him and his friends. Powar initially stated told them that he would not be able to pay them the money, but finally conceded to pay Rs 12 lakh. On the same day, Powar handed over them Rs 5.40 lakh and on December 6, he gave them Rs 6.60 lakh,” he said.

“However, when the suspects again contacted him on January 5, January 10 and February 17 and demanded Rs 6 lakh from him and threatened to kill him, he lodged a complaint with us,” Jadhav said.

Jadhav said that the police set a trap to catch the suspects. The police told Powar to contact the suspects and tell them that he was ready to pay Rs 6 lakh. The suspects asked him to meet them at Kedar park area on February 18.

“We accordingly set the trap and when the suspects approached Powar to collect cash, a team of policemen nabbed them. However, three suspects managed to ran away and we have launched search operation to nab them,” he said.

Title: Registration for Pashu Aadhaar begins in dist
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Around eight lakh cattle and buffaloes in Visakhapatnam district are set to get their Information Network for Animal Productivity and Health (INAPH) tags or Pashu Aadhaar in a couple of months as the animal husbandry department has begun the registration and tagging process for the 5.19 lakh cattle and 2.55 lakh buffaloes in the district.

The animals would be tagged with tamper-proof ID, which will have details of their age, colour, height, lactation, sex and breed among other details along with the owner’s name. Apart from this, the animals’ health and vaccination details would also be entered into the INAPH application database, which has been developed by the National Dairy Development Board.

As per the schedule, the registration and tagging process should be completed within 45 days. But officials are likely to need more time as they have to cover interior pockets and hilly terrain in the Agency.

“We have started the tagging process. We have to register all the cattle under the National Animal Disease Control Programme. This has become a compulsory process for all the states in the country,” the joint director of Visakhapatnam animal husbandry department, D Ramakrishna, told TOI.

The Aadhaar-like system for animals was introduced last year, following a government committee recommending UID for cattle and buffaloes to prevent animal trafficking after the Supreme Court in 2015 directed the government to address cattle smuggling.

Presently, the government has initiated INAPH for cows, bulls, oxen and other domestic animals. So far, 1.52 lakh animals have been tagged with the unique identification number in the district, Ramakrishna said.

The officials are going to register another 6.24 lakh animals. Presently, the vaccination programme has been going on in the district and along with this the tagging programme was also taken up, sources in the animal husbandry department said.

Title: Beat system to be back in 5 police stns of Allahabad range
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Allahabad: With no let up in law and order situation and repeated complaints from citizens, state’s top brass is set to revive the beat police system under which a sub-inspector and beat constables would investigate crime in their area.

Of the total 100 police stations selected by the state police authorities across UP for revival of beat system, five are in Allahbad range — Kydganj and Khiri in Allahabad, Fatanpur in Pratapgarh, Malwa in Fatehpur and Manjhanpur in Kaushambi.

IG (Allahabad range) KP Singh told TOI, “Sub-inspector and beat constables have already been given Radio Transmission (RT) set, CUG mobile phone and motorcycles. They will soon be allotted body-worn cameras in order to facilitate prompt action on crime spot, including collection of evidence.

Emphasizing on the pros of beat system, an official said, “Beat policemen are in direct touch with the residents of their respective areas. With the revamped beat system, they can address the problems of their areas in a better manner.”

This is the first time that state police have initiated the process to provide smart gadgets like RT sets, body-worn cameras, bikes and CUG mobile sets to the beat staff.

The staff have also been directed to compile data such as details of prominent citizens, arms license holders, criminals, people aiding criminals, important and trouble-prone places, hotels/guest houses and religious places of their respective areas.

In addition, beat constables have also been encouraged to interact with prominent citizens of their areas to keep track of day-to-day activities and brief senior police officials on a routine basis, an official said.

If successful, the revived plan would also be launched in rest of the police stations, said another official.

Title: Cyber frauds thrive, over 800 cases pending in four districts
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Allahabad: Investigations into at least 836 cases of online fraud are pending in the four districts of Prayagraj range, with Allahabad police having the maximum backlog of 748 cases, followed by Pratapgarh (33), Fatehpur (31) and Kaushambi (24).

The startling numbers came to the fore after the range police brass on Wednesday reviewed the status of pending cyber fraud cases registered with various thanas in the four districts. They found at least 361 cases where the investigations are pending for over six months.

IG (Prayagraj) KP Singh is learnt to have instructed district police authorities to take “effective and prompt measures” to solve the 800-plus cases at the earliest. He has also asked his men to take up mass awareness campaigns among internet users.

During the review, the range police brass found that probe into 799 cases — 717 in Allahabad, 33 in Fatehpur, 27 in Pratapgarh and 22 in Kaushambi — were pending since 2019.

In January alone, 59 online fraud cases (44 in Allahabad, 9 in Pratapgarh, five in Kaushambi and one in Fatehpur) were registered, taking the total number of cases to 858 by the end of last month.

However, range police claim to have solved 22 of these cases (13 in Allahabad and three each in Kaushambi, Pratapgarh and Fatehpur districts). They also claim to have submitted charge sheet and final report in nine and 13 cases, respectively, by January-end.

Nevertheless, probe is pending in 836 cases as per January data. There are at least 334 cases (298 in Allahabad, 18 in Fatehpur, 12 in Pratapgarh and six in Kaushambi) where investigations were pending for three to six months.

A total of 760 cases of online fraud were registered in 2019 in the range while the number stood at 465 in 2018.

Investigations suggest majority of the cases (76%) involved fraudulent withdrawal of money from bank accounts. Police have solved around 14% cases, tracking down the culprits to Noida and eastern UP districts, besides Jharkhand and a few southern states.

Unsuspecting citizens were conned in online marketplaces as well. Conmen posing as buyers for used cars, bikes, electronic goods and other expensive items swindled them out of money.

“Setting up of a cyber thana (as proposed in the state budget on Tuesday) will certainly help police tighten the noose around fraudsters,” IG Singh maintained. He said besides roping in Crime Branch sleuths to nab cyber crooks, they were also focussing on generating public awareness against online frauds. “We are appealing to citizens to not disclose their bank details to anyone,” he added.

Title: KMF sold only 987 tickets for Karuna music fest
Content:
In a video posted on their Facebook page, Kochi Music Foundation members said around 4,000 persons attended Ka... Read More

KOCHI: In a clarification video posted on Facebook on Wednesday evening, Kochi Music Foundation (KMF), which organized Karuna music concert on November 1, 2019, said that nearly 4,000 persons attended the event while tickets were bought by 987 of them. KMF said the rest watched the event without paying a dime.KMF had announced that proceeds from the event would go to chief minister’s distress relief fund (CMDRF). As per documents released by KMF, 1,492 tickets were complementary and several persons ‘walked in’ after the event started. This is the third explanation by KMF.However, the 40-minute video did not explain why so many tickets were given for free when one of the aim was to raise funds for CMDRF. The event posters had claimed that ‘proceeds would go to CMDRF’. On one hand KMF claims the event was not announced as a fundraiser, but a few seconds later they add that ‘it is not wrong to label it a fundraising programme’.“We are not saying this for the sake of argument. It was conceived as programme that would announce great events in future. Nothing wrong in saying that it was a fundraising programme as we promised to give money from ticket sales to CMDRF. Karuna was a programme with several dimensions,” KMF said in its Facebook video. The video showed Sithara Krishnakumar, Bijibal, Shahabaz Aman and Aashiq Abu , among others.Commenting on the venue, Regional Sports Centre (RSC), that was given for free, Abu said that when they applied to RSC, KMF was asked to pay Rs 1.5 lakh as rent, besides GST and other expenses. “ Rs 1.5 lakh as day’s rent was pretty huge. We then explained that we also intend to donate the ticket revenue to CMDRF. We also told them that the artists were performing for free. This was a festival of musicians. So obviously they won’t take remuneration for their own programme. All of them attended it like a festival. The rent was waived and we bore other expenses. This is what happened in the case of the stadium,” he said.“After nearly 1,000 ticket holders, the rest had complementary passes. Our friends and relatives, establishments like libraries, office of MPs, music students, film students, political parties were given these tickets. The programme was not entirely a business. The correct number of complementary tickets will be clarified soon. During a music night, people would come once the rush is over and seats are remaining. We didn’t want people to wait outside just because they lacked a pass. Many watched without passes and they are included in this numbers,” KMF said.The issue pertains to KMF depositing Rs 6.22 lakh, the ticket revenue received from Karuna, to CMDRF on February 14, hours after TOI published a story based on an RTI document that showed KMF had not remitted the money.In the Facebook video, KMF said they were legally bound to deposit the money only before March 31 (end of the financial year) but did so in haste so that the campaign to tarnish their image is stopped. KMF claimed that its women members faced a vicious hate campaign in the previous days.

Title: Farmer killed over money row, two held
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Allahabad: Two persons were arrested on Wednesday for killing a 52-year-old farmer in Bhawargarh area under the limits of Saraymamrez police station.

The accused were identified as Jalaluddin alias Jagga of Bandi and Rajesh Kumar Bharatiya of Kundaura.

The duo were arrested from Madwa petrol pump road while they were planning to escape from the city.

SSP, Allahabad, Satyarth Anirudh Pankaj said the criminals had murdered a farmer, Lalmani Yadav, on the intervening night of February 16 and 17 following dispute over money. A case was registered by Lalmani’s nephew, Sandeep Yadav, at Saraymamrez police station.

“Jalaluddin had taken Rs 50,000 from Lalmani but when he demanded his money back, Jalaluddin decided to kill him,” he said.

Jalaluddin sought the help of his aide, Rajesh Kumar, to eliminate Lalmani.

Title: Central kitchen system on cards for social welfare dept hostels
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Nashik: The social welfare department is toying with the idea of implementing the central kitchen system for its hostels and residential schools so that the beneficiaries get quality food.

The system was being chalked out on the basis of the one being followed in the tribal development department where the quality of food has improved significantly with efficient monitoring of the process.

Social justice and special assistance minister Dhananjay Munde expressed the idea to run the central kitchen services in hostels and residential schools across the state for which the ministry has sought the details of the central kitchen system that is currently being run by the tribal welfare department.

After a meeting with the minster, the commissioner for social welfare and justice department ordered the assistant commissioners in Thane, Palghar and Nashik districts to file an in-depth report about the tried and tested system through which the children get piping hot breakfast, lunch and dinner in tribal schools in the said areas.

The department runs hostels and residential schools for children belonging to scheduled castes where the food is locally cooked and served. Also, there have been several complaints about the quality of food or the facility being not up-to-the mark or, at times, the food being bland, among other things.

The ministry has been thinking over ways and means to get rid of the situation and, hence, has stumbled upon the system that is being implemented in the tribal schools and ashramshalas located in rural and remote areas.

The deputy commissioners have, therefore, been asked to collect all information in detail about the process in which the food is cooked, the way in which the quality is monitored and the system through which the food is delivered to the beneficiaries.

Information has also been sought on the number of students served food through the entire system, the numbers of delivery vehicles, number of schools and children attached to every delivery vehicle, the distance the delivery vehicle covers, the modes of monitoring the quality control on a daily basis, the menu provided to the beneficiaries, the safety and security involved, etc.

The officers have been asked to visit the schools and ashramshalas that are providing the same and prepare a report that has to be presented to the ministry which will then take the future measures for safe and quality food delivery to the beneficiary.

Title: Man held for sexual assault of minor girl
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Trichy: A 47-year-old man was arrested for sexually assaulting a 11-year-old girl here on Tuesday.

The accused has been identified as Ramesh. The all women police station (AWPS) police attached to the Trichy rural police said the man was sexually abusing the girl, who was his relative, for the past one-and-a-half months.

A police officer said the girl endured the harassment until she revealed it to the headmistress of the school where she was studying. As soon as the girl revealed the entire story of the sexual abuse by her relative, the headmistress decided to lodge a complaint with the police on Tuesday.

Police said that according to the complaint, the girl was residing in Ramesh’s house after her father passed away. She was facing sexual harassment from Ramesh from December 31. Police booked Ramesh under sections of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (Pocso) Act.

He was produced in court and remanded in judicial custody.

Title: Kalank strikes right notes, rules the charts and heart
Content: The sheer magic of seven musical notes mesmerised the audience at the 12th Smule Mirchi Music Awards 2020 held at YashRaj Studio, Andheri, on Wednesday. The awards ceremony is the most-awaited industry event of the year.The title track of ‘ Kalank ’ boosted the film’s fortunes, bringing it a clutch of six most coveted trophies. Apart from being named Song of the Year, it bestowed Male Vocalist of the Year upon Arijit Singh. Pritam was designated Music Composer of the Year for the same number while songwriter Amitabh Bhattacharya earned the mantle of Lyricist of the Year. Another charming number from the film, ‘Ghar more pardesiya,’ earned Shreya Ghoshal the enviable award for Female Vocalist of the Year. This song rewarded DJ Phukan, Prasad Sashte, Prakash Peters and Sunny MR for Best Song Producer (Programming and Arranging).Equally competent films such as Gully Boy , Article 15, Kabir Singh , Super 30, Bharat and Marudhar Express saw their “time arrive” too, as they picked up other important trophies for music.Witticisms flew fast and thick as show hosts Shekhar Ravjiani, Aparshakti Khurana and Neeti Mohan engaged in banter. Comedian Sunil Grover evoked many laughs.Veteran singer Usha Mangeshkar (85) received the Lifetime Achievement Award from composers Anandji and Bappi Lahiri. She sang a few lines of C Arjun’s immortal ‘Main toh aarti utaroon re’. Anandji marvelled at her strike rate of hits despite having sung fewer numbers than others. Bappida reminded her she had sung ‘Goron ki na kaalon ki’ for him in ‘Disco Dancer’.Two new award categories Mirchi Social Media Icon of the Year and Mirchi Trendsetters Album of the Year were introduced.A R Rahman played the piano and sang. Colourful stoles flew as leading playback artistes performed a medley of Deepika Padukone ’s songs as she won the Make It Large Award. Spectators also cheered a performance by Meet Bros who sang a medley of ‘Radha teri chunri’, ‘Tainu leke’, ‘Kab tak jawaani’ and ‘London thumakda’. The brothers revealed it was a tribute to their late father.A special segment on women empowerment stole the show too. Artistes Bhoomi Trivedi, Akriti Kakkar, Shruti Pathak and Taapsee Pannu performed ‘Rubaru’.The fortunes of the nominees were in safe hands given that the grand jury comprised reputed artistes such as Kavita Krishnamurti, Suresh Wadkar, Udit Narayan, Ila Arun, Ramesh Sippy, Roopkumar Rathod, Sameer, Raju Singh, Talat Aziz, Pritam and Louiz Banks.The Smule Mirchi Music Awards 2020 is co-powered by sponsors Niine, MX Player and Let’s Antakshari.The Smule Mirchi Music Awards 2020 will be telecast at 8pm on March 22 on Zee TV.

Title: US president Donald Trump to walk in to BK drummers’ beat
Content:
Poster of PM Narendra Modi with USA President Donald Trump and first lady Melania in Ahmedabad on Tuesday.

AHMEDABAD: Drummers from Banaskantha (BK) district in north Gujarat will welcome US President Donald Trump and first lady Melania Trump at the Ahmedabad airport next Monday. Some 40 persons of the Taral community will play the dhol and perform tribal dances to welcome the guests at the airport. Drums are usually played on auspicious occasions.The state youth and cultural affairs department got in touch with tribal persons from Sanali village in Danta taluka of Banaskantha, and informed them that they would be part of the welcome accorded to President Trump in Ahmedabad.These traditional dhol players of Banaskantha district have performed at several state-level functions and were also invited to perform at the airport when Chinese President Xi Jinping visited Ahmedabad in September 2014.“We are proud that our tribal music and dance will be showcased at the airport when the US President arrives. We have been practising for several hours a day for the event. The dhol is the primary musical instrument that accompanies our dance,” said Ramesh Taral, one of those chosen to welcome the US President.Krishna Taral, another resident of Sanali village, said that apart from performing at the airport, some 80 tribal persons from Sanali and Sandhoshi villages will also participate in tribal music and dance performances along the route of the road show, between the airport and Sabarmati ashram. “A few participants have already left for Ahmedabad, while the others will do so in a day or two,” said Krishna Taral.Banaskantha collector Sandip Sagale confirmed that drummers from the district would be part of Trump’s welcome at the airport. “Yes, tribal artists from the district will participate in the welcome ceremony of the US President,” Sagale said.Groups like the Janaviya Band, Arasari Vikas Mandal and Adivasi Kala Mandal of Sanali and villages near it in Banaskantha district have earned a name showcasing tribal art forms and have performed at several important functions and events.

Title: Schools worried about bandobust
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Ahmedabad: Worries about getting to their exam hall on Monday have been added to the exam anxiety of Class X and XII students of the Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE). A part of the city will be cordoned off for security reasons due to US president Donald Trump’s visit to the city on February 24.

This area has four schools — Podar International School, Rachana School , KV Shahibaug, KV Cantonment. Some 417 students are to take their exams at these four centres. Class X students will take their Gujarati paper, while Class XII students have their Physical Education exam.

The issue for students is how to reach the exam hall at 10am, as these areas will be blocked for 3-4 hours before the visit and will open only after Trump’s departure. The exam time for students is 10.30am to 1.30pm. Students will thus have to get to their exam centres by 8.30-9am. They will likely have to wait till as late as 6.00pm, till after the VVIPs have left.

The CBSE city coordinator and principal of Prakash School said, “I had a word with the police commissioner, who assured me that students will not face any problems. Students with hall tickets and school uniform will be allowed to commute.” He added, “The controller of examinations has been apprised of the situation and I am confident a solution will be arrived at.” Rachana School principal Gopa Ghosh said, “The board has been informed of the situation and we are waiting for their guidance in this regard.”

Title: ‘Bandicoot’-maker Genrobotics wins Infosys Foundation award
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Tech entrepreneurs Vimal Govind M K, Rashid K and Nikhil N P, who developed manhole cleaning robot ‘ Bandicoot ’ with the aim of eliminating manual scavenging , won the Aarohan Social Innovation award instituted by Infosys Foundation , the philanthropic and CSR arm of Infosys.

The Arohan awards were established in 2018 to recognize and reward individuals, teams, and NGOs for creating innovative solutions to support the underprivileged in India, at scale. The gold award carries a purse of Rs 20 lakhs.

This year, Infosys Foundation identified winners across four award categories: healthcare, rural development, destitute care and sustainability. The winners were shortlisted from a pool of over 1,700 submissions and evaluated by a jury comprising Arvind Gupta, toy inventor and science expert, Anil Gupta, visiting faculty member, IIM Ahmedabad, Trilochan Sastry, former Dean, IIM Bangalore, GVV Sharma, faculty member of the department of electrical engineering, and coordinator, teaching learning centre, IIT Hyderabad, Sumit Virmani, chief marketing officer, Infosys and Sudha Murty, chairperson of Infosys Foundation, philanthropist and author.

The Genrobotics team won the award in the category of sustainability. Genrobotics CEO Vimal Govind M K said that the prize money will be utilized for research and development of Bandicoot.

Partha Pratim Das Mahapatra from Kolkata, who developed a non-invasive, non-contact robust hand-held portable device to measure human bilirubin, oxygen saturation, and hemoglobin levels, without drawing blood from the body, Binita S Tunga and Rashbehari Tunga from Bengaluru, who created a single device that detects mosquito-borne diseases such as malaria, chikungunya, and dengue in very early stages of infection, and TUMAAS (Foundation for Tuberculosis, Malnutrition and AIDS) from Mumbai, which is developing a point-of-care, user-friendly, cost-effective, and rapid test for diagnosis of TB through urine, won gold awards in healthcare. Ramalingam P L from Chennai, who created an affordable standing wheelchair that helps special children and individuals with spinal cord injury, won the award in destitute care.

Title: ‘Some houses of Jamtara villagers bigger than Big B’s’
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

What made you take up a topic like phishing in Jamtara ?

An article in an English daily on phishing in the town caught our attention. It spoke of how school dropouts from Jamtara duped tech-savvy people in big metros. The economy of the village is driven by phishing. Almost each and every villager is involved in the crime. It all began when shops started giving away SIM cards for free. Though the village has a population of 2,000, it accounts for 80 per cent of India’s cybercrime cases.

We always imagine this kind of crime to be based out of big, technologically advanced cities, but phishing was happening in a town as small as Jamtara. We thought it would be an amazing story to tell.

What is Jamtara like now?

The people of Jamtara have palatial homes. Some houses have remote-controlled gates and some are bigger than the Big B’s house. Earlier, there were only tiny mud houses. The town is extremely well-kept, clean and green. It feels like a village with zero crime. One wouldn’t have the slightest indication of it being the hub of cybercrime in India.

The crime has gone to another level in the past few years. It has spread like cancer. Now it is run like a family business.

Aren’t the youths scared of getting arrested or punished?

They don’t care about what’s happening outside Jamtara. They are willing to break the law and know there’s money to be made. The sense of morality is missing. People are making crores of rupees now. They think of it as their time to make it big. They enjoy political backing and some are even contesting elections. The local administration and police are not only aware of the crime, they are closely involved in the network.

The situation there is complex. The socio-political structure the youths grew up in pushed them towards crime. A large part of India, including the state of Jharkhand , is mired in poverty and runs on caste divisions. I think improving access to education in rural areas can be a game changer.

The ones making the calls are mostly below 18 and it’s a soft crime. So, registering a case or getting them arrested is not easy.

Do you think pro-active policing could have prevented the crime from occurring on such a large scale?

It could have lessened the intensity of the crime, but I don’t think pro-active policing would have stopped it. There is a breaking point for everyone. The youths of Jamtara have never seen this kind of money and they couldn’t care less about what rules they are breaking while making it. Somewhere, we all are guilty of complicity.

We have seen The Mahabharat being worked into the narrative. Why?

‘Lower’ caste groups didn’t have much access to mythology. Literature was always part of the upper caste. And India’s past and castes are still alive. Whatever little knowledge these people gathered of mythology was from unofficial sources. We wanted to show how caste controlled people’s lives.

What kind of cinematic liberties, if any, have you taken?

We didn’t show much of phishing as it involves very little use of technology. Anyone with a smart phone can do it. The youths involved in the crime aren’t hackers. The series is more on the characters than on the crime. I think minimalism was the key. The credit goes to the writing team. They did the research and mixed reality with fiction, without altering the essence of Jamtara. It was a team effort. There was a lot of freedom as well as challenges.

We see strong female leads in the series. Was that deliberate?

Women in Jamtara are extremely strong. I believe strong characters make their own story. It is a great time to be a story-teller in India. We have seen enough male-dominated stories and we are bored. The audience wants variety.

Small (town) is now big in web series and Hindi films, but Odisha’s towns and villages have stayed below the radar. Do you think it’s time to tell the Odisha story?

The transformation has begun. Big city stories have been exhausted. Small towns and villages have a lot to tell and show. Odisha will catch up, too. I am looking forward to telling stories from the state. I didn’t have the chance to explore it much, but I will soon.

Title: People slam state govt for not passing resolution against CAA
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Trichy: Muslim outfits under the banner of Jamaath Ul Ulama staged a protest near the Trichy collectorate here on Wednesday demanding the state government to pass a resolution against the Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ), National Register of Citizenship (NRC) and National Population Register (NPR).

After police denied permission to the Jamaath Ul Ulama to lay siege, which was organized as part of a state-wide call, the agitators staged the protest on the road adjacent to the collector’s office.

More than 1,500 people including women joined the protest that started around 10am. Besides criticising Prime Minister Narendra Modi and home minister Amit Shah for pushing CAA, the Ulama leaders hit out at chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami for not passing a resolution against the Act in the assembly.

Though the BJP-led central government won’t budge to the states’ opposition, Tamil Nadu government should register the opposition of the people to the central government by moving a resolution in the on-going assembly session, the leaders said.

They said that CAA, NRC and NPR were an attempt to drive a wedge between Muslims and Hindus as they are living in harmony. A significant number of protesters dispersed from the venue around 12 noon, while the leaders continued their speech till 1pm. The organisers asked the crowd to move to Uzhavar Sandhai grounds where around 300 people including women were staging a sit-in protest from Monday night.

Trichy city police led by commissioner of police V Varadharaju made elaborate security arrangements with superintendent of police, Trichy district, Zia Ul Haq and deputy commissioner of police, law and order, N S Nisha monitoring the protests and traffic arrangements.

The Thillai Nagar police registered cases against Usman and 100 others for staging the sit-in protest at Uzhavar Sandhai on Tuesday. The KK Nagar police also booked 63 college students for picketing the road opposite to Jamal Mohammed College (JMC) on Tuesday.

Protests were held in 18 places in Pudukottai, Karur, Perambalur, Ariyalur, Thanjavur, Tiruvarur and Nagapattinam districts in the central region. The SDPI, PFI, Muslim Jamaath, All Jamath Federation, and Iykkia Jamath Saba also participated in the agitations.

Title: Sudanese woman held at RGIA for smuggling gold
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Hyderabad: Customs officials intercepted a Sudanese woman at Rajiv Gandhi International Airport (RGIA) while she was trying to smuggle out 287 grams of gold on Wednesday. Officials intercepted the accused based on passenger profiling technique and seized gold bars and jewellery, hidden in her shoes and undergarments. The market value of the gold was Rs 11 lakh.

In another case, customs officials intercepted a male passenger from Dubai and recovered 149 grams of gold worth Rs 6.38 lakh from his possession. TNN

Title: Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation gives stadium building use permission
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

On Wednesday, the world’s largest cricket stadium, in Motera, was issued building use (BU) permission by the A... Read More

AHMEDABAD: On Wednesday, the world’s largest cricket stadium, in Motera, was issued building use (BU) permission by the Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation (AMC), thus ending two and half years of construction and rigorous safety tests. Municipal commissioner Vijay Nehra said every structural component of the stadium has been examined by a safety committee and only after that was the building-use permission granted. “Fire safety no-objection certificates were issued to the Gujarat Cricket Association after tests were conducted by our department a few days ago,” Nehra said.

A senior official in the state urban development department told TOI that the stadium is 51 metres high and had to clear several structural tests before the BU certificate was issued.

Title: Awareness prog on I-T for students
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Allahabad: An awareness programme on central government’s scheme, ‘Dispute to confidence’, was organised by the income tax department for the students of United Institute of Management, Naini, on Wednesday.

Addressing students, chief commissioner, Income Tax (Allahabad), Sadhana Shankar said: “Though you do not pay taxes now but in the coming years many of you will have your own startups, then you will understand its significance. As a responsible citizen, you can ask the country and the government to pave way for progress and development only when you are an honest taxpayer.”

Convener Aarti Pandey welcomed chief commissioner (I-T) Sadhana Shankar and joint commissioners Etesham Ansari and Shiv Kumar Rai.

Joint commissioner Etesham Ansari said, “Our endeavour is to make income tax simple so that people know that it is for their betterment.” Shiv Kumar Rai said, “We have succeeded in bridging the gap between the income tax department and taxpayers.”

Title: ‘Cycle Bank’ project for tribal girls hits roadblock
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Nashik: The proposal by the district administration for having a ‘cycle bank’ for tribal students under the Manav Vikas Mission (MVM) has hit a roadblock with the commissioner of the project has stayed the project.

Based on the human development index and women literacy rate in selected talukas, the girl students of class VII to XII are given bicycles to travel a maximum distance of five km distance to their respective school/college. “The bicycles would remain with the students and we proposed to get them back and present them to the next batch of students,” the officer from district administration said.

The commissioner of MVM, however, has said that since there was no provision of keeping the bicycles with the department and no provision for maintenance, the proposal was not feasible. The MVM is implemented in 125 talukas across the state and evaluation is based on poor human development index, the poor literacy rate among women, health issues and many other factors.

Every year taluka under the MVM gets the aid of Rs 2 crore from the state government for taking measures like female literacy, mother and child welfare works, children education, etc. “Since the project of presenting bicycles started in the year 2013, there are hundreds of the children whose bicycles now either remain unused, or the parents are using them – after the children have finished their Class XII or even dropped out,” the officer said.
