Posting her complaint on Twitter handle of Kanpur police, the 21-year-old woman alleged that instead of listening to her complaint, Raipurwa cops asked her: “Zyada padh gayi ho, itna advance kisne bana dia hai, tumhare Papa ne?”

She alleged that instead of taking necessary action on her complaint, the police forced her father to have a compromise with the accused, the son of her landlord, who harassed her on Monday.

The woman also claimed that there were no female cops at the police station and she had to wait for several hours. “Throughout my presence at the police station, I had to interact with male cops,” she tweeted.

Inspector, Raipurwa, Sunil Kumar, however, denied allegations. “Her allegations are not true. Both the parties settled the dispute on their own,” he said.

IG Range Mohit Agarwal said, “I have asked the SSP to initiate a probe in this regard and act accordingly against guilty cops.”

Title: Tanneries allowed to operate in city but with 50% capacity
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Last week, the RPCB gave notices to tannery owners to shut their units from February 19 as the limit granted t... Read More

Kanpur: Uttar Pradesh Pollution Control Board (UPPCB) has given permission to tanneries of the city to run their units uninterrupted but with a condition that they would be operate at 50% capacity and follow the roster released by the board for holy baths in coming days.

The letter to this effect, issued by the UPPCB to the Regional Pollution Control Board (RPCB) Kanpur on Tuesday evening, was received by the latter on Wednesday, said RPCB officer S B Franklin.

"It is a big relief for the tannery industry. Now they can run their business properly", said an office-bearer of Small Tanners' Association.

After a long time, we got some relief, and now we can fulfill our international commitments, he added.

Last week, the RPCB gave notices to the tannery owners to shut their units from February 19 as the limit granted to them had expired on that day, and that all tanneries would remain closed till further orders.

Earlier, there were around 500 tanneries in the Jajmau area of the city but due to back-to-back closure at present around 280 units are in working condition. The fate of the tanneries was hanging in balance after the state government had closed them on November 18.

The RPCB official while talking to TOI stated that UPPCB has given permission with certain conditions that are different for each tannery. The RPCB office would serve the order regarding the operation of the units in a couple of days after examining the condition of each tannery, he said.

The UPPCB, he said, had allowed 255 tanneries to operate in November 2019 for around two months with 50 percent capacity while permitted 28 tanneries to run even in the closure period with certain specific conditions, he added.

Firoz Alam of Small Tanneries Association said, at last, the tanneries have been given permission to do their business because they are following the norms set by the UPPCB and RPCB. They would get permission letter in a day or two.

"The UPPCB has given sanction to even those 11 tanneries which were closed since last one year for not following the set standards”, he added.

As around 70 percent tanneries were exporters they would now be able to fulfill their international commitments, Firoz said. General secretary, Leather Industries Association, Asad Iraqi while hailing the decision of the board to grant permission said that it would pave way for the leather industry to flourish.

Title: Father-son duo held; SUV, firearm seized
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Rana Maradia had created drama in a toll booth

Rajkot: The father-son duo who had allegedly threatened two staffers at Bharudi toll booth near Gondal in Rajkot district on February 15 with a revolver were arrested from their residence in Amin Marg locality of Rajkot on Wednesday.

Police said the accused, identified as Rana Maradia (52) and his son Manthan Maradia (21), had arrived in their SUV at the toll booth on February 15 morning.

According to the police, the father-son duo asked Bhupendrasinh Sengar and Mohit Chauhan to remove the barricade at the toll booth. When Sengar and Chauhan asked them to first pay the toll tax, Manthan alighted from the SUV and tried to remove the barricade physically, in the process of which he tripped and fell.

“At this time, Rana allegedly showed his revolver to Sengar and Chauhan allowing Manthan to remove the barricade. After removing the barricade, Manthan sat in the SUV and both the father-son duo sped away. The CCTV footage of the incident went viral on WhatsApp and social media. We traced the accused on the basis of the CCTV footage and the registration number of the SUV,” said A V Jadeja, sub-inspector with Gondal taluka police station. “We have seized the SUV and the revolver from Rana,” Jadeja added.

Title: Bank manager, two others get 3 yrs’ RI
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The second additional special judge for the CBI court in Vizag, G Satya Prabhakar Rao on Wednesday convicted a former branch manager of Bank of India , Kakinada and another couple for defrauding the bank.

The court sentenced the trio to three years of rigorous imprisonment (RI) and slapped a fine each of Rs 30,000. The convicted persons are Marella Satyanarayana Murthy, branch manager of Bank of India, Madhuranagar branch, Kakinada (A1), Marisetti Vankata Satya Chandra Sekhar Sudheer Raju (A2) and his wife Marisetti Durga (A3).

Between 2003-06, Satyanarayana Murthy, Sudheer Raju, M Durga, Soorabathula Venkata Maruthi Chandra Sekhar (A4), a panel valuer and proprietor of Swapna Soudha Architects and Designers, Kakinada and Pattamatta Ravi Shankar (A5), an advocate entered into a criminal conspiracy to cheat Bank of India.

The branch manager abused his official position as a public servant and sanctioned an overdraft on mortgage of property to Sudheer Raju and his wife Durga and disbursed the entire loan amount to the couple on the basis of legal opinion issued by avocate Ravi Shankar.

The court said that the valuer Chandra Sekhar knew that the property mortgaged to the bank was agricultural land but it was valued in terms of a residential property. The prosecution charged all five with cheating the bank, causing wrongful gain to themselves and wrongful loss to the bank.

The court convicted the branch manager under various sections of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1988 and private persons under the same sections. Ravi Shankar has been acquitted from the charges leveled against him while Chandra Sekhar was also discharged from the case.

Title: Court extends Chhabra’s remand for three days
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Indore: The court has extended police remand of land shark Bobby Chhabra for three days till February 22 on Wednesday.

He was produced before chief judicial magistrate first class Mahendra Pal Singh. As soon as the officials reached the court with the accused, he asked for water from them. One of the constables brought a bottle for him and Khajrana inspector PS Thakur and Kanadia inspector RD Kanwa checked it by taking a sip. However, Chhabra refused to have water claiming that he would drink only in a glass and not from bottle. Since a glass could not be made available, he did not drink water.

Chhabra was arrested by Indore police on February 14 from Delhi and was produced before the court and taken on police remand for five days.

Title: Traders body demand action against plastic bag suppliers from Gandhinagar
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Representative image

KOLHAPUR: The Kolhapur Chamber of Commerce and Industries (KCCI) has appealed to the Maharashtra Pollution Control Board (MPCB) to take action strict against those supplying plastic bags and other plastic packaging material from Gandhinagar .

Gandhinagar is a trading town located in the outskirts of the city. The Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) does not hold the authority to act against those supplying plastic carry bags from Gandhinagar. The health officials of the municipal corporation have alleged that plastic carry bags are being supplied to shops in the city from Gandhinagar. They said that they have found a chain of network connecting the manufactures to suppliers and eventually buyers. They said that this chain comprises traders and roadside vendors which needs to be broken to ensure effective implementation of plastic ban in the city.

Sanjay Shete, president of KCCI said, “We have information about 16 suppliers of plastic packaging materials from Gandhinagar. They supply huge amount of plastic bags to traders in the city. We have asked the MPCB to take action against them as Gandhinagar does not come under the jurisdiction of the KMC. We have also found that plastic carry bags are being manufactured in Karnataka state. The chain needs to be exposed. At the same time, we as the apex body of traders, will ensure that awareness about plastic bags and its ill-effects on the society is created among the traders and vendors from the city. If we find that no action is being taken by the MPCB, we will protest outside their office.”

Grampanchayats have the jurisdiction to implement plastic ban. However, the village panchayat lacks adequate staff for the same. The KCCI has also demanded the increase in number of plastic waste collection centres in the city. At present, the KMC has started centres at 13 places, mostly in the divisional ward offices and KMC-run schools. The trader’s body claims that the system of taking back plastic bags and bottles has not yet been set up by many traders, especially milk dairies who sell milk in pouches which are sold in lakhs every day.

In the general body meeting held on Tuesday, civic chief Mallinath Kalshetti said that the KMC will soon start penalising the traders and suppliers from a certain section of the Gandhinagar area which comes under the KMC’s jurisdiction.

Title: In 24 hours, The Park hotel gets fire licence back
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

On Monday, DFS had suspended the fire NOC of the hotel

NEW DELHI: Nearly 24 hours after the fire clearance certificate of The Park was suspended, Delhi Fire Service (DFS) revoked its earlier order contending that the shortcomings had been rectified by the hotel. On Monday, DFS had suspended the fire NOC of the hotel, following which the Delhi Police licensing department had written to NDMC seeking cessation of operations.

In a letter to the NDMC chairman and the licensing department of Delhi Police, DFS said, “An inspection carried out by officers of the fire department has shown that the shortcomings communicated to the hotel have been seen to.”

Atul Garg, DFS director, said, “The major issue was that the pressurisation and ventilation was on manual mode instead of automatic. In any tragedy or a fire situation, everyone rushes to the exit making it difficult to switch on the devices that are on manual mode.”

A senior NDMC official said, “We received a letter from Delhi Fire Service on Wednesday restoring the fire safety certificate of The Park. However, we have not taken any decision on the revocation of the hotel’s health/trade licence. Our department will first verify the status and then reach a decision.”

A statement issued by The Park said, “We had received a suspension notice from the fire department to undertake certain fire prevention improvements to ensure better safety. We had actioned all the suggestions made in the notice and complied with it. The fire department officers visited the premises and conducted an inspection to verify the compliance of safety norms on February 18.”

“We have been doing regular drills and are completely safety compliant. After a thorough check by the fire department, the hotel received a clearance and the fire safety certificate has been restored. Additionally, Delhi Police has also revoked the cessation order of the hotel and has allowed continuation of operations,” the statement said.

Meanwhile, the lodging and dining services of the hotel continued to operate on Wednesday as the 48-hour notice period had not lapsed, a source said.

On Saturday morning, a fire had broken out in the basement of the hotel. Though the blaze was doused by the hotel staff, the smoke reached the above floors through the air-conditioning ducts. Instead of informing the fire department and police, the hotel authorities used their staff to evacuate the guests.

Police were informed around 12.30pm by authorities at the hospital where the guests had been taken for treatment. Following the incident, a team of fire officials visited the hotel and listed out 11 shortcomings in the premises.

Title: Maharashtra: Painted Stork sighted six years after tagging
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

An ibis

PUNE: A Painted Stork was sighted by bird watcher Sandeep Nagare on February 2, six years after it was tagged (wing tag number A 40) by Pune-based Ela Foundation, in association with the state forest department and the National Institute of Virology (NIV), as part of the bird flu surveillance programme.

This is the first such long-term recovery of the bird and the stork was seen about 4.5km from the site where it was first tagged, said ornithologist Satish Pande, founder-director of Ela Foundation.

The foundation, NIV and the forest department have been jointly conducting the wild bird monitoring programme for bird flu surveillance since 2008. The study is supervised by Pande, Shailesh Pawar, NIV and Nitin Kakodkar, forest department.

Pande said on May 12 and 24, two bird flu survey studies were carried out in Bhadalwadi Wetland, near Bhigwan in Pune. As many as 51 birds of several species were studied. These included Painted Storks, Black-headed Ibis , Grey Heron, Night Heron, Pond Heron, Little Egret and Small Cormorant.

“Their cloacal and tracheal samples were taken and blood was taken for bird flu scrutiny. Their wing length, tail length, leg, toe and talon (nail) length were measured. The weight of all birds was recorded and the overall health status was examined. All birds were either ringed and/or wing-tagged with numbered, lightweight, red tags on both wings. The birds were immediately released in the wild,” Pande said, adding that all birds tested negative for bird flu.

After a year, one Black-headed Ibis (wing tag A 27) was re-sighted 4km from the ringing site. One Painted Stork (wing tag A 47) was re-sighted at Bhigwan after four years, in 2017.

“Interestingly, one more Painted Stork (wing tag No A 40) was re-sighted by bird watcher Sandeep Nagare on February 2 this year. This is the first such long-term recovery of the bird after six years. This stork was seen about 4.5km from the site where it was first tagged. It confirms that the stork was alive for six years after tagging,” Pande said.

At the time of tagging in 2014 the A 40 tagged stork was aged around six weeks, weighed 2.5kg and was about to fledge. “After six years, this stork was found healthy and seen feeding with other Painted Storks, Grey Herons and Ibises. It was seen in the same general area indicating the importance of Bhadalwadi-Kumbhargao wetlands for aquatic birds,” Pande said.

Title: Suspect held in bank employee murder
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Hyderabad: A day after a 25-year-old bank employee was murdered in Gajwel, police took an engineering graduate, who confessed to slitting her throat, into custody.

The suspect, K Venkatesh Goud, surrendered before police at Vemulavada town police station on Wednesday evening. “Gajwel police took him into custody for interrogation,” said Vemulavada Town circle inspector (CI) Sridhar.

Around 8 pm on Tuesday, E Divya, an employee of AP Grameena Vikasa Bank, was killed by unidentified persons at her house in Gajwel shortly after she returned from work.

Police sources said Venkatesh killed Divya as she spurned his marriage proposal and instead was preparing to wed another person.

Preliminary investigation revealed that the 25-year-old victim was all set to get married to a bank employee from Warangal on February 26. Divya had joined AP Grameena Vikas Bank as a clerk in September 2019 and was staying in Gajwel town with her parents for the past three months.

In their complaint Divya’s parents said they suspect involvement of Venkatesh Goud, 27, in their daughter’s murder.

“Due to my business, I stayed in Vemulavada for some time in the past and Venkatesh met my daughter there. He has been harassing my daughter for the past four years asking her to marry him. About four months ago, Venkatesh agreed that he will stop following my daughter and even gave an undertaking at the Yellareddypet police station. We suspect he killed Divya,” the victim’s father alleged.

Police also found that Venkatesh had earlier come under the radar of the OU police for causing nuisance at a hostel where Divya was staying a few years ago.

Title: CISF cop shoots self to death at VSP
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Visakhapatnam: A constable in Central Industrial Security Force ( CISF ) in Vizag Steel Plant ( VSP ) committed suicide by firing his service weapon in the wee hours of Wednesday.

Sadu Satish (30) is survived by his wife and two-and-a half-year-old son.

The cops said that no suicide note was recovered at the spot or at his quarters.

Satish, a native of Rampapeta village under Etcherla mandal in Srikakulam district, had resumed duty on Tuesday night after 10 days of leave at Watchtower No.11 inside the Steel Plant.

He had gone to attend his brother’s marriage and relatives and friends said he was under severe stress.

Satish had joined the CISF in 2010 and served mostly in Assam. He was transferred to Vizag Steel Plant last year.

As per schedule, his duty hours were from 9 pm to 5 am. The incident took place at around 1.30 am on Wednesday.

Police were informed of the death by authorities at the steel plant on Wednesday morning.

Title: Water trickles in at Alandi after 2 days
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Pimpri Chinchwad: Water supply to Alandi has resumed at low pressure after a two-day closure. Normal supply will begin from Thursday.

Vaijayanti Umargikar, president, Alandi Municipal Council (AMC), said, “The town needs 5MLD to 7 MLD water. We began the alternate day water supply a month ago for which the town has been divided into four zones. The old water pipelines from the British era have rusted and are leaking leading to contamination. The Maharashtra Jeevan Pradhikaran (MJP) has been allotted the work of laying new water pipelines and constructing elevated storage reservoirs.”

She said the newly laid main water pipeline from the bund on Indrayani river burst two days ago. There was no water supply to the town for two days. “The municipal council provided water tankers in some areas to tide over the shortage,” said Umargikar.

The civic officials asked the Maharashtra Jeevan Pradhikaran to divert water through old pipeline, which enabled resumption of supply on Wednesday.

Title: In battle against calamities, government ups allocation by Rs 1200 crore
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

The state government had received international recognition for its disaster preparedness during cyclones like... Read More

BHUBANESWAR: The state government has raised its disaster management funds to Rs 3,200 crore from last year’s Rs 2,000 in the annual budget presented on Tuesday.

For Odisha, which faces cyclones almost every year, this is the highest allocation in disaster management in the last four year. Of the total amount, Rs 1,711 crore will go to the state disaster response fund, Rs 1,000 crore to the national disaster response fund, Rs 428 crore to the state disaster mitigation fund and Rs 43 crore to the national disaster mitigation fund.

Sources in the finance department said the significant jump in the allocation could be attributed to the additional grants of Rs 2,139 crore to the state by the 15th finance commission.

The allocation is designed to increase assistance to the affected people. “A large amount of the money will be spent on building infrastructure such as multi-purpose shelters, training community people, necessary repairs post disasters and strengthening the capacity of mitigation institutions,” a senior government official said.

“As the government is aiming to develop disaster-resilient infrastructure in the state’s power, housing and telecommunication sectors, the allocation will be useful,” the official added.

The state’s geographical location makes it extremely vulnerable to natural disasters and has faced at least 18 major calamities like cyclones, floods and drought in the past 20 years. It has been hit by about 35 per cent of all cyclonic and severe cyclonic storms that crossed the eastern coast of India, causing colossal damage to its public properties.

The state government had received international recognition for its disaster preparedness during cyclones like Phailin (October 2013) and Fani (May 2019).

There are 20 specialized units under the Odisha Disaster Rapid Action Force (ODRAF) equipped with modern facilities for relief and rescue operations. This apart, there are 879 multi-purpose cyclone shelters in different parts of the state.

Meanwhile, adequate funds have been allocated for the road and energy sectors under different ongoing schemes.

The government has allocated Rs 2,272 crore for road development programmes. It includes Rs 500 crore for improving roads and bridges and Rs 100 crore for double laning of state highways under the state highway development programme.

In the energy sector, the state government has allocated Rs 184 crore for setting up of 33/11 kv sub-stations under the Odisha Distribution System Strengthening Project.

Similarly, Rs 200 crore has been given for laying underground cables in Bhubaneswar and Cuttack under the State Capital Region Improvement of Power System.

The state government has not announced any new scheme for these sectors.

Title: Telangana: Suspect held in Gajwel murder
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: A day after a 25-year-old bank employee was murdered in Gajwel, police took an engineering graduate, who confessed to slitting her throat, into custody.

The suspect, K Venkatesh Goud, surrendered before police at Vemulavada town police station on Wednesday evening. “Gajwel police took him into custody for interrogation,” said Vemulavada Town circle inspector (CI) Sridhar.

Around 8 pm on Tuesday, E Divya, an employee of AP Grameena Vikasa Bank, was killed by unidentified persons at her house in Gajwel shortly after she returned from work.

Police sources said Venkatesh killed Divya as she spurned his marriage proposal and instead was preparing to wed another person.

Preliminary investigation revealed that the 25-year-old victim was all set to get married to a bank employee from Warangal on February 26. Divya had joined AP Grameena Vikas Bank as a clerk in September 2019 and was staying in Gajwel town with her parents for the past three months.

In their complaint Divya’s parents said they suspect involvement of Venkatesh Goud, 27, in their daughter’s murder.

“Due to my business, I stayed in Vemulavada for some time in the past and Venkatesh met my daughter there. He has been harassing my daughter for the past four years asking her to marry him. About four months ago, Venkatesh agreed that he will stop following my daughter and even gave an undertaking at the Yellareddypet police station. We suspect he killed Divya,” the victim’s father alleged.

Police also found that Venkatesh had earlier come under the radar of the OU police for causing nuisance at a hostel where Divya was staying a few years ago.

Title: In battle against calamities, government ups allocation by Rs 1200 crore
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

The state government had received international recognition for its disaster preparedness during cyclones like... Read More

BHUBANESWAR: The state government has raised its disaster management funds to Rs 3,200 crore from last year’s Rs 2,000 in the annual budget presented on Tuesday.

For Odisha, which faces cyclones almost every year, this is the highest allocation in disaster management in the last four year. Of the total amount, Rs 1,711 crore will go to the state disaster response fund, Rs 1,000 crore to the national disaster response fund, Rs 428 crore to the state disaster mitigation fund and Rs 43 crore to the national disaster mitigation fund.

Sources in the finance department said the significant jump in the allocation could be attributed to the additional grants of Rs 2,139 crore to the state by the 15th finance commission.

The allocation is designed to increase assistance to the affected people. “A large amount of the money will be spent on building infrastructure such as multi-purpose shelters, training community people, necessary repairs post disasters and strengthening the capacity of mitigation institutions,” a senior government official said.

“As the government is aiming to develop disaster-resilient infrastructure in the state’s power, housing and telecommunication sectors, the allocation will be useful,” the official added.

The state’s geographical location makes it extremely vulnerable to natural disasters and has faced at least 18 major calamities like cyclones, floods and drought in the past 20 years. It has been hit by about 35 per cent of all cyclonic and severe cyclonic storms that crossed the eastern coast of India, causing colossal damage to its public properties.

The state government had received international recognition for its disaster preparedness during cyclones like Phailin (October 2013) and Fani (May 2019).

There are 20 specialized units under the Odisha Disaster Rapid Action Force (ODRAF) equipped with modern facilities for relief and rescue operations. This apart, there are 879 multi-purpose cyclone shelters in different parts of the state.

Meanwhile, adequate funds have been allocated for the road and energy sectors under different ongoing schemes.

The government has allocated Rs 2,272 crore for road development programmes. It includes Rs 500 crore for improving roads and bridges and Rs 100 crore for double laning of state highways under the state highway development programme.

In the energy sector, the state government has allocated Rs 184 crore for setting up of 33/11 kv sub-stations under the Odisha Distribution System Strengthening Project.

Similarly, Rs 200 crore has been given for laying underground cables in Bhubaneswar and Cuttack under the State Capital Region Improvement of Power System.

The state government has not announced any new scheme for these sectors.

Title: Over 2000kg ganja seized from CG
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Indore: Directorate of Revenue Intelligence ( DRI ) officials have seized more than 2000 kg ganja (cannabis) valued at Rs 3.1 crore in the international market from four persons in two different operations in Chhattisgarh.

On the basis of specific intelligence, in two different operations in Chhattisgarh, the DRI Raipur and Indore intercepted a septic tank cleaning truck, an SUV and a trailer truck, an official release said here on Wednesday.

Around 1230 kg ganja was being carried in the septic tank cleaning truck and 838 kg was hidden on the trailer truck.

One person was arrested with the septic tank cleaning truck and three with the trailer truck escorted by an SUV. They were booked under the Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act.

In recent times, it has been noticed that drugs smugglers are finding new ways of transporting ganja, the release said adding the banned drug ganja was addictive and caused both short term and long term adverse effects on health.

Title: Nine pirates held for mid-sea theft
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Rajkot: As many as nine thieves who had sneaked into a ship, eight nautical miles off Pipavav coast in Amreli district, were arrested in mid-sea by the coast guards on Wednesday.

The ship, ‘Al-Marjo’, was navigating towards Alang ship breaking yard when the accused led by Osman Belim and Iqbal Hussien had got near the ship on a tug boat to commit the crime. However, they were spotted by the sailors on the ship who sent an SOS message to the coast guard.

“The moment we received the message, we rushed our boat towards the ship and caught the accused from the ship along with their boat,” said Mohbin Khan, coast guard commander of Pipavav port.

“We have seized the boat in which the accused had gone to the ship. We have handed over the custody of accused to Pipavav marine police station,” added Khan.

Title: Maharashtra: Nine held guilty of stripping, parading Dalit woman in 2016
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Representative image

KOLHAPUR: The Solapur district and sessions court has sentenced nine people, including two women, for beating up, verbally abusing, stripping and parading a Dalit woman in 2016. The accused have been sentenced to five years of rigorous imprisonment.

The incident had taken place in the North Solapur taluka of Solapur district 13 years ago and had evoked sharp reactions from all quarters. The Dalit woman has since been given police protection.

District and sessions judge D K Anbhule held nine people guilty under various sections of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) and the Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes (Prevention of Atrocities) Act, 1989. Heavy police force was deployed in the village after the court announced its judgment on Tuesday.

According to the prosecution, the nine accused had a doubt that the woman had complained about their illegal and illicit activities in the village. They held a grudge against her for a long period as she was consistently following up on the complaint.

In March 2006, the woman was waiting at a bus stop along with her son at 9 am . All the accused were also standing at the bus stop. They forcibly stopped the woman and started verbally abusing and beating her. They also beat up the son. She was then stripped and paraded naked from the bus stop to the chawdi (a place where villagers gather). The woman lodged a complaint after the incident and a special investigation team was formed.

Public prosecutor Gandadhar Rampure said 16 witnesses, including the woman and her son, appeared during the hearing of the case. The court upheld the witnesses and other circumstantial evidences and declared the accused guilty. All the accused have been charged a total fine of Rs 2.43 lakh, which would be handed over to the woman.

The court held all the accused guilty under section 506 (2) (punishment for criminal intimidation) and under various sections of the Scheduled Caste and Scheduled Tribes (Prevention of Atrocities) Act, 1989. The accused were charged with section 3 of the Atrocities Act.

Title: Take proactive steps to find missing kids, Delhi high court tells cops
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: Delhi high court on Wednesday said proactive steps should be taken by Delhi Police to trace missing children and issued a slew of directions to make it easier for the cops to trace them.

A bench of Justices Manmohan and Sangita Dhingra Sehgal said district anti-human trafficking units (AHTU) were currently functioning to investigate cases of children between ages of three and eight who were missing for four months or more, and cases where there was suspicion of links to trafficking and organised crime.

The bench directed AHTUs to be the nodal agency for all cases of missing children in a district. It also asked the unit to work in close coordination with the police and other agencies providing expert assistance in collection and analysis of technical evidence.

“Proactive steps should be taken by Delhi Police to curb the menace of missing children. To this end, within 48 hours, an officer not below the rank of additional DCP shall be nominated in each district, who shall thereafter hold at least one meeting a month with ACP (AHTU) and SHOs concerned, to identify sections/pockets of their respective districts that are worst affected,” it said.

The high court added that an action plan should be drawn with inputs from other stakeholders for steps to be taken in this regard.

The court asked Delhi Police to file an action-taken report by the next hearing on March 3. It was hearing a plea seeking directions to police to trace his 15-year-old daughter, who went missing in October last year. On being informed that investigating officers often face problems in getting prompt transport while tracking missing children, the court asked the department to make cabs available on immediate-basis at request. It added that reimbursements must be processed quickly and efficiently.

During the proceedings, the court also looked into the larger issue of children going missing from Delhi. On Wednesday, the girl was produced before the court where she stated that she would turn 18 on Thursday and had willingly gone with the man. She added she did not wish to go with her parents and was sent to Sanskar shram in east Delhi. The court directed the police to carry out ossification test of the girl to ascertain her age.

Title: Man gets 8-year RI for sexual assault of cousin
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Cuddalore: A special court for cases booked under the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (Pocso) Act, 2012, on Tuesday convicted a 28-year-old man to eight years rigorous imprisonment for sexually assaulting his minor cousin. District judge (Pocso) K Karunanithi also slapped a penalty of Rs 2,000 on the man, identified as T Palanivel, from a village near Neyveli in Cuddalore district.

According to special public prosecutor K Selvapriya (Pocso cases) the victim, a Class IX dropout, used to stay alone at home after her parents, both brick kiln labourers, leave for work everyday. Her cousin Palanivel, a daily-wage labourer, learning that the girl will be alone during the daytime, visited her house on February 12, 2018. Taking advantage of the situation, he sexually assaulted her. Palanivel escaped after threatening her not to reveal the incident to anyone, else he will harm her and her parents.

The girl, who was 16 then, subsequently narrated the incident to her mother, who lodged a complaint with the Neyveli all-women police station. Police registered a case against Palanivel under Section 4 (punishment for penetrative sexual assault ) of the Pocso Act and 506 (punishment for criminal intimidation) of the Indian Penal Code and arrested him. TNN

Title: NREGS funds granted to tribals building road
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Visakhapatnam: NREGS funds have been allocated to the tribals of the nine hamlets of Pinnikota and Kivarla panchyats of Ananthagiri Mandal. The tribals, vexed with the delay in getting a road connecting their hamlets, took it upon themselves the task of laying the 12 km unpaved road.

A sum of Rs 15 lakh has been allocated under NREGS, with a total 8,000 work days granted to all the people put together. But a total of 80 people have job cards, while another 90 do not. As a result, NREGS authorities have decide to make the payments through customer service providers to the 90 who do not have job cards.

“About 100 people among those working on the road do not have bank accounts. This has become a major problem and has been brought to the notice of the authorities,” said Govinda Rao, district executive body member of CPM said.

Govinda Rao added that the ITDA authorities have drawn up plans to construct a BT road at a cost of Rs 15 crore but pointed out that for the BT road they would require permission from the forest department.

Speaking to TOI, ITDA project officer, D K Balaji, said, “The BT Road grant may be made in November.”

Title: India’s first private gold mine to take off in 2021 in Kurnool district
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Hyderabad: India’s first private gold mine is expected to take off in the last quarter of 2021 if land acquisition for it is completed in the next six months at Jonnagiri in Kurnool district , Andhra Pradesh . After negotiating with farmers and completing exploratory mining, Geomysore Services India Pvt Ltd is in the process of acquiring the land.

Geomysore has acquired mining lease for 1,500 acres in Jonnagiri. “We have started the land acquisition process for 350 acres. We are hoping to complete it in the next six months. Once the land acquisition is completed, we will take 10 more months to set up the processing plant. Then we will start production. We have agreed to pay Rs 10 lakh plus Rs 2 lakh for each acre to the farmers, whereas the government value is Rs 1.5 lakh. Farmers are responding positively to the move,” said Jade Devenish, managing director at Geomysore Services India Pvt Ltd. The process of negotiation took eight months. So far, the company has invested Rs 160 crore into the exploration and is expecting investments of Rs 300 crore more.

Andhra Pradesh Pollution Control Board (APPCB) had earlier stopped the automatic renewal of Consent for Operation (CFO) based on a complaint. However, the CFO was recently granted to the company after an independent enquiry. Hanuman Prasad, a senior functionary of Geo Mysore, told TOI, “APPCB stopped auto-renewal based on a complaint. But after they have made an independent enquiry and found that there were no irregularities, they have renewed the CFO. One of the allegations in the complaint was that there were archaeological and heritage sites. But as per rules mining is allowed 300 metres away from the sites. Our mine is located three to four kilometres away from the archaeological sites.”

Prasad added, “As per the package being given to the farmers, for the first 350 acres, Rs 10 lakh will be paid upfront and Rs 2 lakh will be paid in first year of production as bonus. For the remaining 1,150 acres, we are going to pay a lease amount of Rs 16,000 per acre where farmers can grow crops. They must allow us to carry out exploration work if needed.”

Prasad added that there were a total of four blocks and initial mining will be done only in one. “Initially, Geological Survey of India (GSI) estimated 2.4 grams of gold per ton of ore, but those bores are not deep. We have done extensive studies and dug many bore wells and found it to be 1.68 grams per ton,” he said.

Title: 32 iron traders to lose lease of plots for violating terms
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Indore: Indore Development Authority (IDA) is likely to cancel lease of plots of 32 iron traders for not shifting their business from old Loha Mandi to the new market, posing as hurdles in development planned at both the places and violating other lease terms.

“We have identified 32 iron traders, who were allotted plot in new Loha Mandi in Scheme 78. But they have not shifted there. Many of them were also found violating lease terms in other way. Proposal to cancel the allotment will be put in the board meeting to be held on February 22,” the authority CEO Vivek Shrotriya told TOI.

In the meeting, IDA will also seek permission to appoint consultant for restoration and use of Rampur Kothi, which was earlier used as RTO office, under Lalbagh Palace campus. It will furnish a proposal of some farmers, who have given their land for implementation of Scheme 166 and now want to reduce size of the plots allotted to them to ease in selling.

According to IDA officials, a discussion over plots allotted to grocery and tea merchant associations in Scheme 54 (PU-4) will also be held in meeting. IDA has received many complaints of violation of lease terms for benefiting some people by allowing commercial activities other than meant for the scheme.

Agendas including, assigning of tenders for construction of proposed bus terminal in Nayata Mundala and one in Scheme 139 and 169-A, development work in Scheme 140 and 59 and some other work will be tabled in the meeting for discussion and approval.

Title: Cops pose as bizman’s kin to turn tables on abductors
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: Three men , posing as Crime Branch sleuths , abducted a businessman from outside Tilak Nagar metro station . However, their quest for Rs 25 lakh in ransom money ended on a sour note after they were outwitted by the cops at their own game. One of them was arrested.

Police said they were contacted by the family of the businessman, Aman Kumar, around 9.40pm on Tuesday and told about the ransom demand. A team was immediately formed and a group of policemen posing as the victim’s relatives laid a trap. When the abductors reached the designated spot in Delhi Cantonment to collect the ransom, the policemen immediately swung into action.

When the cops asked the suspects to surrender, three of the abductors managed to flee after ramming their car into the policemen’s vehicle. However, one of them, Haripal, was caught. The businessman was rescued from a parking lot nearby after information from Haripal.

The accused told police that he wanted to start a business. To tide over the shortage of funds, he and his friends hatched a plot to abduct a businessman. They chose Kumar, who runs a call centre in Tilak Nagar, as they presumed that his business was doing well.

While Kumar was returning home from work, the three men, posing as crime branch officers, stopped him near Tilak Nagar metro station to make the “arrest”. They dragged Kumar out of his vehicle and pushed him into a Swift.

The men made Kumar sit in the rear seat and drove him around west Delhi for around eight hours. They used the businessman’s phone to call his family and make the ransom demand. After much haggling, they brought down their demand to Rs 10 lakh. They asked them to drop the money bag at a certain location in Delhi Cantonment.

Police said the hunt was on to nab the other two accused.

Title: Coimbatore’s Shaheen Bagh begins with a bang
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Coimbatore: Hours after the massive rally against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) that shook the city, federation of Muslim organizations and Muslim political outfits started a Shaheen Bagh-model indefinite dharna in front of a mosque at Athupalam here on Wednesday night. When the last report came in, around 9 ,000 people had gathered at the mosque to participate in the dharna.

Shamiyanas were erected in an open place adjacent to Irshadul Islam Shafia Sunnath Jamath mosque at Athupalam for the dharna, which commenced at 9pm.

Initially only around 500 people, comprising elders, women and children, were there. However, the number swelled to 9,000 in no time. The protesters held placards that read 'Kovaiyin Shaheen Bagh Athupalam'. The organizers said the dharma would be conducted peacefully. “It will be similar to the one conducted by women in Delhi.”

The protesters said the dharna would be continued till the Union government accepts to withdraw the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, the National Population Register (NPR) and the National Registry of Citizens (NRC).

Earlier in the day, tension had gripped the city after Muslim men and women came out in large numbers to take out a rally to demand that the state government pass a resolution against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, 2019, in the assembly.

The city police had deployed 1,384 cops to prevent any untoward incidents and used drones to keep an eye on the protesters. In view of the call given by the Coimbatore District Federation of All Jamaath and Islamic Organizations to besiege the collectorate at 10am, the city police had also blocked traffic on the Big Bazaar Street and the State Bank of India Road from 9am.

More than 7,000 Muslims, including 2,000 women, who had gathered near the Coimbatore Railway Junction, began the rally towards the collectorate around 11am. Police blocked the road to the collectorate using barricades. Rapid Action Force (RAF) personnel were deployed in the front row. Women cops from rural and city armed reserve police carrying lathis and shields were deployed in the second and third rows.

Police had also stationed a water canon vehicle and anti-riot vehicle Vajra that can lob tear gas shells.

City police commissioner Sumit Sharan and deputy commissioners L Balaji Saravanan (law&order), and ES Uma (crime) monitored the security arrangements.

The women protesters sat on the road and raised slogans demanding withdrawal of CAA. They had brought their children, who were waving tricolour flags. Two police drones recorded the protest.

Organiser of the outfit Raja Hussain, who addressed the protesters, said that AIADMK MPs supported CAA in the Parliament and the State government is supporting the Union government. “We are fighting against not only CAA, but the National Population Register (NPR) and the National Register of Citizenship (NRC) also. Several states have passed resolutions in assemblies against CAA. We want the State government to pass a similar resolution,” he said.

Muslims will continue the protest till the Union government withdraws CAA, NPR and NRC, Hussain said.

Traffic was restored through the stretch after the protesters dispersed around 12.30pm.

Title: Nagpur: Products made by special kids to be on sale at ‘NGO Connect’
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Products made by children

NAGPUR: It is inspiring to see the expertise of young minds of specially-abled children, youth and women from different NGOs in the city in making beautiful handmade products, right from paper bags to herbal tea. But their talent is often restricted to the walls of these NGOs.

But they will now get a chance to showcase their art at ‘ NGO Connect’, an initiative of Sir Gangadharrao Chitnavis Trust, to bring together all such organizations on a common platform. NGOs marketplace, the first programme of this initiative, will take place at Rangayan, Chitnavis Centre, on February 22 and 23.

Amol Awankar, a constable at Central Jail, believes that it is an amazing opportunity as all the products made in the prison will be exhibited. “Prisoners have made beautiful saris by using handloom and power loom which will be sold at the event. It’s a positive step which will motivate them,” he said.

Nikhil Kulkarni, an accountant from Sandnya Sanwardhan Sanstha, shared details about their items to be put on display. “We work for the mentally handicapped children. They have made files and other paperwork. Children, who put their heart and mind in making these handmade products, will get a platform to showcase it,” he said.

Products on display range from files, jute bags, fancy envelopes, paper flowers, rugs, terracotta products and bamboo artwork. There will be enough options for products like honey, herbal tea, organic ground nut oil and millets.

Dr Mrunalini Balla, a parent-member of Sweekar Parents Association , expressed happiness as her son is in the NGO. She said, “I believe it is a step to encourage specially-abled children, that they are equally loved and their work needs to be appreciated. At the exhibition, we will exhibit phenyl and liquid soaps, besides other items.”

Bhagyashree Deshpande from Abhyudaya Global Village, which educates children from 18 nearby villages, said, “Those who are at the school have in abundance knowledge and talent. We will sell refined oil extracted from machines.”

Durga Chede is a speech therapist at Deaf and Dumb Residential School, Saoner, and is working for the uplift of hearing and impaired students. She said, “Children have made beautiful paper flowers, beads Ganesha, pots and necklaces. They are excited to display their talent at NGO Connect.”

Twenty-six NGOs are participating in the event the aim of which is to market products produced by their beneficiaries. It will act as a bridge between NGOs and the local business community. Other programmes of ‘NGO Connect’ will include skilling and workshops for quality improvement, marketing and providing employment opportunities.

The next stage will be to identify products for further design/quality inputs and skilling. “These products will then be made commercially marketable. Local businessmen and companies would be encouraged to contribute to this project and tie up with the NGOs,” said Avantika Chitnavis, trustee.

Title: 20-year-old jumps to death from fourth floor
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Representative image

VISAKHAPATNAM: A 20-year-old girl jumped to her death from the fourth floor of a building in Maddilapalem area—which falls under MVP Colony police station limits—in Visakhapatnam city on Wednesday morning, after her parents rejected her proposal to get married to her boyfriend.

The deceased has been identified as M Padmavathi, a BSc student at a private degree college in the city.

According to police, Padmavathi and her boyfriend—who is a resident of Gollalapalem—had been in a relationship for a year.

A week ago, the boy along with his parents came to Padmavathi’s house to seek consent from her parents for their marriage.

A few days after the visit, Padmavathi’s parents rejected the proposal for various reasons and also informed the boy’s family of the same.

Following the rejection, Padmavathi, disappointed with her parent’s rejection of their proposal to get married, went to their old house near Maddilapalem on Wednesday and jumped to her death from the building.

Padmavathi’s father Srinivasa Rao runs a tiffin shop in Chinna Waltair area.

Title: Hyderabad: GST is biggest madness by BJP government, says Subramanian Swamy
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Subramanian Swamy

HYDERABAD: Rajya Sabha MP Subramanian Swamy left BJP red-faced on Wednesday by terming the Goods and Service Tax (GST) the “biggest madness” of the 21st century. He also raised several eyebrows by demanding the Bharat Ratna award for former Congress Prime Minister PV Narasimha Rao.

Speaking on ‘India–an economic superpower by 2030’ at University of Hyderabad here on Wednesday, he advised government to not terrorise investors with GST and income-tax slabs.

Saying that the country had achieved 8% growth from time to time, Swamy said, “So how to get that 3.7% (efficiency factor to utilise investments)? (We need to) fight corruption and reward those who will invest,” he said.

According to him, the current problem of the country is shortage of demand as people do not have money to spend. “You want 10% growth rate. Then investment rate to the GDP should be 37% and 3.7% should be your efficiency factor and not 5% as it is today,” he said.

He is confident that India could become a superpower by 2030. He said Narasimha Rao deserved the highest civilian award for the economic reforms he unveiled during his tenure.

During the lecture, a section of students held a silent protest within the auditorium with placards stating ‘Say no to NRC, NPR, CAA’. On this, Swamy said: “What are they protesting for? In this election, a huge proportion of Muslim women voted for us. BJP removed triple talaq.”

Title: Gujarat: Darbars to abolish celebratory firing and liquor in marriages
Content:
Chudasama leaders meet at Cher village.

RAJKOT: Weddings in many Darbar households are said to be incomplete without liquor, splurging of notes on drummers and a boisterous display of weapons.For generations, the community has been fiercely holding on to intimately entwined customs, notwithstanding the dangerous celebratory firing in grooms’ processions that have even snuffed out lives.But winds of change are blowing among the community members. Dabar and other sub-caste leaders recently met in Cher village of Dhandhuka in Ahmedabad district and Talaja near Bhavnagar and resolved to abolish these archaic practices.Talking to TOI, Mahendrasinh Chudasama, a community leader of Cher said, “Firearm in the hands of a drunk reveller is a very lethal combination. In such a scenario, people dying from misfiring or being injured in wedding processions are common. That is why we have decided to henceforth stop all these practices.”Cher is dominated by the Chudasamas, a sub-caste of Darbars . This decision stands to impact nearly 52 villages dominated by Chudasamas in the village’s vicinity.For a start, the Chudasamas of Dhandhuka and the Sarvaiyas of Talaja have decided to slap Rs 25,000 penalty on those indulging in any of these ritualistic practices.Another practice they are looking to abolish is ‘ghor’ tradition, wherein relatives of groom rain notes on drummers.“Financial condition of every family may not favour such extravaganza. Many even borrow money to maintain their prestige,” Chudasama said. Due to this ritual, the procession takes a long time to reach the marriage venue and it is during this time that some revellers open fire, some in inebriated condition.Bhupendrasinh Chudasama, executive council member of Dhandhuka Rajput Samaj said, “We will call a meeting of 52 villages of Chudasamas and put up a proposal to follow the decision taken by Cher village.”The Sarvaiyas in Pasvi village near Talaja had also taken the same decision a few months ago. Shaktisinh Sarvaiya, a primary teacher and leader of the community, said, “We have started abolishing these practices from the current marriage season itself. The villagers have also agreed not to indulge in the practices looking at the disadvantages of the traditional rituals.”Sarvaiya further said that the villagers have also agreed to boycott marriage functions where liquor is served to the guests. They will also ban entry of zonked guests in such functions.

Title: Irregular parking plagues commuters in Rockdale layout
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

More Bottlenecks: Commuters complain that parking on both sides of the roads are leading to traffic congestion... Read More

Visakhapatnam: Traffic congestion in Rockdale layout on account of irregular parking has become a matter of concern for commuters. With vehicles, including buses and autos, parked on both sides of the narrow and steep roads, commuters are unable to drive in the area.

The neighbourhood has a school and a hospital, leading to high traffic flow at certain peak hours. Residents of the area said entering or leaving their apartments at these hours has become inconvenient given the rush of traffic.

Rakesh Kumar, a resident of one of the apartments in the layout, said, “It is very difficult to move out of our apartment, especially at 8 am and 4 pm. The traffic snarls have been disturbing us over the past few years now. Despite frequent complaints to the municipality and police, the issue has not changed.”

Another resident of the same apartment, Hemanth, said, “There is no parking sense among the people who park vehicles on the road. Last week, a car was parked so close to the entrance gate that my car hit it while moving out of the apartment. Many times we have observed that vehicles are parked in front of the gate, making it difficult for the residents. The cars are parked in a way that they partially block the main entrance.”

Hemanth added, “When a complaint was raised with the police officials, the police visited and raised e-challans on the vehicles parked irregularly. However, it was done only for two days and the situation has come back to square one.”

When contacted, assistant commissioner of police (ACP) Y Govinda said, “A police vigil will be kept in this area to regulate parking. The roads cannot be used for parking, hence we will be raising e-challans on a regular basis. A notice will also be issued to the school authorities and others who park vehicles on the road.”

The ACP added, “Vehicles cannot be parked adjacent to boundary walls of the apartments. If required, we will keep no parking boards so that rules are not violated.”

Title: Mandsaur civic body to procure latest tools to catch stray dogs
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

The civic body had drawn flak for catching stray dogs with metallic pincers

INDORE: After taking the heat from animal activists for deploying untrained workers, who caught stray dogs with pincers and carried them in garbage vehicles in Mandsaur , district administration has ordered to purchase appropriate tools for the work and implement animal birth control (ABC) programme to check population of the strays in scientific manner.

“On instruction of Animal Welfare Board of India under ministry of environment, forest and climate change, conventional technique (use of pincers) for catching stray dogs will be discontinued. Also, animal husbandry department officials have been ordered to purchase required tools and use it for catching stray dogs,” collector Manoj Pushp said.

The collector’s order came in wake of a news published by TOI on civic body launching a drive to catch stray dogs after they ran riot and bitten over 20 people in Pipliya Mandi area on February 10. The team managed to catch over 10 dogs. But it had to face resentment of animal activists for using pincers and ropes to catch and tie the animals and allegedly even killing one of them.

According to animal activists, use of iron pincers to catch animals has been banned by Supreme Court and it is a clear violation of Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Act, 1960.

Nagar Parishad Pipliya Mandi chief municipal officer Garima Patidar had blamed untrained staff and lack of equipment for the incindet. She had also accepted that procuring required tools to catch and control dogs along with providing training to staff is part of their job. But before the official could have initiated the process, she was transferred to Ratlam within a week.

Title: Coimbatore’s Shaheen Bagh begins with a bang
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Coimbatore: Hours after the massive rally against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) that shook the city, federation of Muslim organizations and Muslim political outfits started a Shaheen Bagh-model indefinite dharna in front of a mosque at Athupalam here on Wednesday night. When the last report came in, around 9,000 people had gathered at the mosque to participate in the dharna.

Shamiyanas were erected in an open place adjacent to Irshadul Islam Shafia Sunnath Jamath mosque at Athupalam for the dharna, which commenced at 9pm.

Initially only around 500 people, comprising elders, women and children, were there. However, the number swelled to 9,000 in no time. The protesters held placards that read 'Kovaiyin Shaheen Bagh Athupalam'. The organizers said the dharma would be conducted peacefully. “It will be similar to the one conducted by women in Delhi.”

The protesters said the dharna would be continued till the Union government accepts to withdraw the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, the National Population Register (NPR) and the National Registry of Citizens (NRC).

Earlier in the day, tension had gripped the city after Muslim men and women came out in large numbers to take out a rally to demand that the state government pass a resolution against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, 2019, in the assembly.

The city police had deployed 1,384 cops to prevent any untoward incidents and used drones to keep an eye on the protesters. In view of the call given by the Coimbatore District Federation of All Jamaath and Islamic Organizations to besiege the collectorate at 10am, the city police had also blocked traffic on the Big Bazaar Street and the State Bank of India Road from 9am.

More than 7,000 Muslims, including 2,000 women, who had gathered near the Coimbatore Railway Junction, began the rally towards the collectorate around 11am. Police blocked the road to the collectorate using barricades. Rapid Action Force (RAF) personnel were deployed in the front row. Women cops from rural and city armed reserve police carrying lathis and shields were deployed in the second and third rows.

Police had also stationed a water canon vehicle and anti-riot vehicle Vajra that can lob tear gas shells.

City police commissioner Sumit Sharan and deputy commissioners L Balaji Saravanan (law&order), and ES Uma (crime) monitored the security arrangements.

The women protesters sat on the road and raised slogans demanding withdrawal of CAA. They had brought their children, who were waving tricolour flags. Two police drones recorded the protest.

Organiser of the outfit Raja Hussain, who addressed the protesters, said that AIADMK MPs supported CAA in the Parliament and the State government is supporting the Union government. “We are fighting against not only CAA, but the National Population Register (NPR) and the National Register of Citizenship (NRC) also. Several states have passed resolutions in assemblies against CAA. We want the State government to pass a similar resolution,” he said.

Muslims will continue the protest till the Union government withdraws CAA, NPR and NRC, Hussain said.

Traffic was restored through the stretch after the protesters dispersed around 12.30pm.

Title: BEE session on new energy standards
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The Bureau of Energy Efficiency ( BEE ) held a workshop here, with the support of Andhra Pradesh State Energy Conservation Mission (APSECM), to introduce International Standard Organisation (ISO) 50001:2018 energy management standards in industries.

BEE director Sunil Khandare said implementation of ISO 50001:2018 energy management systems would benefit the industrial sector in the state. AP Energy Regulatory Commission (APERC) reports show that industries in the state consume 20,026 of the 59,162 million units (MUs) of electricity generated.

ISO 50001:2018 standards, Khandare said will support industries use energy more efficiently and deliver multiple benefits across the industrial value chain, leading to lower energy consumption, enhanced competitiveness, lower costs of environmental compliance, operation and maintenance as well as an improved working environment for all employees.

Citing a 2017 Niti Aayog report, Khandare said India is likely to account for 25 per cent of the rise in global energy demand by 2040.

At the same time, energy-related greenhouse gas emissions account for 75 per cent of all greenhouse gas emissions in the country, he added.

Energy consumption in industries in the country is expected to reach 443.4 millions of tonnes of oil equivalent (Mtoe) by 2031 as against the present consumption of 347 Mtoe, Khandare added.

Title: Delhi: 12 more metro stations get e-rickshaw facility
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Fleet of 250 e-rickshaws was flagged off at Patel Nagar metro station. (Photo: Twitter/@OfficialDMRC)

NEW DELHI: Delhi Metro Rail Corporation on Wednesday extended the facility of e-rickshaw services to 12 more stations across its network, taking the total tally to 29 with an overall fleet strength of over 1,000 e-rickshaws.

A K Garg, director (operations) flagged off a fleet of 250 e-rickshaws — SmartE — from Patel Nagar station on Wednesday. These e-rickshaws will provide last-mile connectivity between 6am and 11pm.

“Over 800 e-rickshaws are already plying from 17 metro stations, facilitating over one lakh commuters to reach their destination or stations on a daily basis,” a DMRC spokesperson said. In the next three months, he added, 500 more e-rickshaws will be deployed at 12 more stations.

These GPS-enabled SmartEs are specially designed with covered cabin and full front windscreen to provide last-mile connectivity within an area of 3-4 km around metro stations. “The fares start at Rs 10 for the first two kilometres and Rs 5 for every subsequent kilometre. Commuters can also book vehicles through the SmartE app and pay digitally for their rides,” the spokesperson said.

According to the spokesperson, DMRC has, in recent years, introduced a number of eco-friendly initiatives to ensure a robust last-mile connectivity system, which enables commuters to prefer non-polluting public transport modes over personal vehicles.

At present, the metro operator runs 174 non-AC CNG feeder buses from 69 metro stations and on 32 feeder routes. DMRC has also started e-scooter rental services from Vishwavidyalaya, Mandi House, Dwarka Sector 9 and Nehru Enclave stations and plans to extend the service to Kashmere Gate, IIT and New Delhi metro stations soon.

Title: Sealing shadow back on shopping centres in Delhi
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: With the elections over, the sealing committee is back in action. The Supreme Court-appointed monitoring committee has directed the local bodies to prepare and submit the standard plans for all designated local shopping centres falling under their jurisdictions.

The three-member panel has noted that though a standard plan was prepared for the Rajouri Garden complex , no action has been taken. After the additional commissioner of South Delhi Municipal Corporation (SDMC), Ramesh Verma, submitted that some clarifications had been sought from the Delhi Development Authority , the committee asked him to deposit its copy and clarify why standard plans hadn’t been prepared for other centres.

A sealing drive at the market has been a contentious issue for the past two years. Last September, the panel ordered the west zone to carry out sealing at Rajouri Garden but civic officials and councillors stonewalled the directive by citing a status quo in terms of the land-use notification. The committee said a new directive had to be issued as SDMC didn’t act on a similar order sent in May 2018.

However, the corporation argued no sealing action was possible as the notification on the change of land use for 351 roads had been pending with the Supreme Court, an official said. The market is situated on one of these roads identified by the erstwhile MCD in 2007 for commercial/mixed land use.
