Title: Lucknow: 3 residents injured in scramble for safety
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Lucknow: Sugriv Singh was lounging in his room after lunch when he suddenly had trouble breathing. He turned around to see billows of thick, black smoke blurring his window. Instinctively, he grabbed some belongings and rushed out with his family.

Singh was not the only one who panicked. A major fire at a neighbouring plywood factory in Aishbagh triggered a stampede-like situation with every family residing dangerously close to the unit scurrying for cover.

Three women, identified as Urmila Devi (52), Asha Devi (40) and Poonam (25), were injured when they fell on the road in the mad scramble for safety.

Some stood on the streets for the next three hours, apprehensive that flying embers would burn down their homes as well and praying for safety.

“I was taking bath when I heard commotion outside. I came out and saw the leaping flames. Without wasting a second, I rushed out of our house with my three children,” said Ajay Singh, who lives very close to the factory.

While most people began evacuating the place, some brave residents tried in vain to control the blaze by pouring buckets of water from their rooftops. But, once the plywood factory’s synthetic overhead water tanks began melting because of intense heat, people in the neighbourhood decided to keep safe distance until evening when firemen finally managed to extinguish the flames.

Title: Indore: Alirajpur villagers move mountain to make a road
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

MHOW: Fed up of administration’s hollow assurances for decades, people of Anjanwada village in Alirajpur paved a seven km road by chiselling a mountain without heavy machinery and finally connected the isolated village with the mainland.

Falling under Sakarja panchayat, the only way to reach Anjanwada village is crossing Narmada river on a boat which takes around two to three hours.

The plight of around 350 residents of Anjanwada prevailed despite decades of pleading public representatives and administrative officials.

Alirajpur collector Surbhi Gupta said that she got to know about the issue after being posted there and she verified it. “80 families are residing in the village and we are trying to get a road constructed under MGNREGA scheme. There is a small stretch of forest in the way for which the forest department’s nod is essential and the process is underway,” she said.

Alirajpur MLA Mukesh Patel said that he had been elected for the first time and while campaigning, he could meet only a dozen people of Anjanwada in Sakarja. “They had come all the way after a boat ride to meet me and I had promised a road to the village but there were other priorities as per the election manifesto so I could not do anything in that regard,” he said.

As a last resort, the villagers, who are mostly manual labourers and farm workers, decided to pave way for the road by themselves and began working in September.

As of today, four-wheelers can easily reach the village via the three-metre-wide road stretching seven km.

Sarpanch of Sakarja Ap Singh told TOI that he was a resident of Anjanwada and as a sarpanch, he had tried all available means for getting the road constructed but nothing happened. The villagers achieved the target without any modern machinery or earth-moving machines, he said.

Panchayat secretary Rajesh Kanesh told TOI that it was a great example as even children and women of the village contributed to build the road. Now the children will be easily able to visit the school, five km from the village, he said.

Title: Arvind Kejriwal: Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal meets Amit Shah, says will work together
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

At the first meeting since Kejriwal took oath as chief minister, the CM and the Union home minister discussed ... Read More

NEW DELHI: Chief minister Arvind Kejriwal on Wednesday called on home minister Amit Shah at the latter’s residence to discuss a wide range of issues. The meeting, coming in the backdrop of highly charged election campaigns by AAP and BJP, was held in a cordial atmosphere and the two sides agreed to work together for the city’s development.

The CM described the 15-minute meet as fruitful. He tweeted, “Met Hon’ble Home Minister Sh Amit Shah ji. Had a very good and fruitful meeting. Discussed several issues related to Delhi. Both of us agreed that we will work together for development of Delhi (sic).”

It was the first meeting between the two since Kejriwal took oath as chief minister of Delhi for the third consecutive time on Sunday.

Kejriwal said various issues concerning Delhi were taken up. “Overall, there was an agreement that the Centre and Delhi government should work together for the development of Delhi. We both agreed to work together,” he reiterated at a press conference later.

Among the issues that were discussed were women safety, law and order and the role of Delhi Police. “Since there is a lot of division in power and responsibility (among different agencies) in Delhi, it was decided that we work together for all matters related to the development of Delhi,” Kejriwal added.

Asked whether there was any discussion on Shaheen Bagh, where hundreds of people have been protesting against Citizenship Amendment Act , Kejriwal said there were no such talks during the meeting. In the run-up to the elections, several BJP functionaries had targeted Kejriwal and AAP on the issue.

Seeking to put behind the heat generated during the poll campaigns, both sides continued to make the right noises as they sought to put Centre-Delhi relations in order. Kejriwal sought the cooperation of the central government in making Delhi a “world-class city” while thanking Prime Minister Narendra Modi for his congratulatory message on AAP’s victory in the elections.

At the swearing-in, too, Kejriwal had sought the PM’s blessings. Modi couldn’t make it to the ceremony as he was in Varanasi at that time. Shah had led the BJP offensive against Kejriwal in the assembly polls that saw AAP storm back to office, winning 62 of the 70 seats.

Title: They didn’t reach the fort, their message did
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

CHENNAI: They came, they stood their ground and after making a point, they left. Thousands of anti-CAA protesters, mobilised mostly by Muslim organisations, gathered on Wallajah Road on Wednesday with plans to march towards the Secretariat. But security was tight — barricades with barbed wire, around 5,000 of police personnel with drones and cameras. And the march towards the government headquarters ended before it could start.

Unlike the ugly scenes in Delhi, where protesters charged at barricades with blinkers on and police caned them at will, Wallajah Road remained peaceful. The only casualty was the traffic on Anna Salai that came to a crawl. With Kamarajar Salai, Wallajah Road, Swami Sivananda Salai blocked for traffic, vehicular movement on Anna Salai, Blackers Road and Dams Road was badly hit.

Around 9am, protesters began to assemble on Wallajah Road. Twenty-one Muslim organisations, including Manithaneya Makkal Katchi, Indian Union Muslim League and Indian National League, had mobilised anti-CAA protesters who, while rejecting CAA and NRC, demanded the state government to pass a resolution against the law.

The protest prop for the crowd, which mostly consisted of young men, included the national flag, portraits of B R Ambedkar, Mahatma Gandhi and Maulana Abul Kalam Azad, and placards. The women, who are spearheading the protest at Shaheenpet (a new name for Washermenpet) did not turn up in huge numbers.

At Chepauk, protesters told TOI that they intended to remain peaceful. Some though said they were ready to retort should the police crack down. That never happened and the talking was left to the placards they held.

‘Reject NRC, NPR, CAA’ caught the eye every now and then as did ‘azadi’ (a punchier alternative to freedom). “Our demand is simple — revoke CAA and do away with NRC and NPR,” said Ameer, a protester. “If the process takes long, we are ready to agitate longer,” he said indicating that protesters are ready to soldier on if required.

But on Wednesday, they decided to wind up by 12.55pm with leaders addressing the gathering near the Chepauk guest house and the protesters singing the national anthem.

M H Jawahirullah of Tamil Nadu Muslim Munnetra Kazagham said had CAA been brought a few decades ago, even MGR, born in Kandy, Sri Lanka, would not have been the chief minister. “This protest is on behalf of the people of Tamil Nadu,” he said.

T Velmurugan, founder of Tamizhaga Vazhvurimai Katchi, said the Muslim community played an important role in India’s independence struggle and it was “wrong to check their antecedents”.

Title: Prog on use of TEDs for sea turtle conservation
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Visakhapatnam: An awareness and training programme on fabrication of Central Institute of Fisheries Technology-Turtle Excluder Device (CIFT-TED) was conducted by the Indian Council of Agricultural Research (ICAR)-CIFT in collaboration with World Wide Fund-India as part of the project, ‘enhancing awareness among stakeholders of trawl systems in Andhra Pradesh and Odisha through capacity building, on use of CIFT-TED for sea turtle conservation ’.

Sea turtles are endangered species, protected under Schedule I of the Wildlife Protection Act, 1972. They are listed as ‘critically endangered’, ‘endangered’, or ‘threatened’ on the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) Red List.

While use of TEDs is mandatory in Andhra Pradesh and Odisha, compliance rates are poor due to lack of awareness and misconceptions regarding the operation of the devices.

R Raghu Prakash, principal scientist and project leader, gave a talk on the role of TEDs in sea turtle conservation. M Vinod, WWF-India team leader stressed the importance of compliance.

Title: Nagpur: Evergreen Hindi songs entertain music lovers
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

NAGPUR: Evergreen Hindi songs were presented by amateur artistes at a musical titled ‘ Hum Aap Aur Swar Ragini ’ at Arpan Hall of Vidarbha Hindi Sahitya Sammelan on Tuesday.

The programme started with ‘Zindagi ittefaq hai’, presented by Alpa Talavia which was followed by ‘Maine tere liye hi’ by Dharmendra Verma.

Sunita Gautam entertained the audience with beautiful song ‘Laag jaa gale’ while Meena Rajankar sang ‘Ajeeb dastan hai yeh’ from popular movie ‘Dil Apna Aur Preet Parai’.

Gunwant Parse and Asha Umre performed duet ‘Kora kagaz tha ye mann mera’. Pankaj Joshi sang ‘Kehna hai kehna hai’ while Swati Joshi presented romantic song ‘Unse mili nazar’. Priya Gupta sang ‘Aapki nazro ne samjha’, originally sung by Lata Mangeshkar.

Shrikant Sapre beautifully presented ‘Gawah hain chand taare gawah hai’ which got an encore. This was followed by ‘Ye mera deewanapan hai’ by Shakil Qureshi which was well received.

Prashant Mankar entertained with ‘Aate hain chale jate hain’. Duet ‘Main tere pyar mein pagal’ was preformed by Ajay Deshpande and Alpa Talavia. Priti Malekar rendered ‘Nisha aaha ha hahaha’.

Kaushik Pujari sang beautiful ghazal ‘Sandese aate hai’ which was followed by duet ‘Gazab ka hain din’ by Sandip Mallik and Dipti Purohit.

‘Chudi jo khanki hatho mein’ was presented by Parvati Verma. Qureshi and Talavia performed a duet ‘Tujhe dekha toh yeh jana’ which got cheers from the audience.

Pankaj Joshi was repeatedly applauded when he sang ‘Chala jata hoon’. Anchal Walde presented a soulful song ‘Tum se hi’ from film ‘Jab We Met’ while Sandil Mallik sang popular song ‘Dil hai ki manta nahin’. Prashant Mankar brought life to song ‘Sar jo tera chakaraye’ that was featured on Johnny Walker in film ‘Pyaasa’.

The musical was conceptualized, organized and anchored by Alpa Talavia.

(Reporting by Rushabh Rathod)

Title: Shaheen Bagh protesters say they will vacate in 2 minutes, but...
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Protesters at Shaheen Bagh

NEW DELHI: Ruksaar Begum , a perpetual presence at the protest in Shaheen Bagh , was among the thousands who asserted on Wednesday that they would not shift elsewhere and thus open up the Kalindi Kunj road for traffic. They also asserted on Wednesday that it would not take them even two minutes to vacate the site of the 66-day-long sit-in if the central government addressed their grievance: the Citizenship Amendment Act and the National Register of Citizens.

“Nobody knew about Shaheen Bagh earlier. Now because of this Shaheen Bagh in Delhi, there are a hundred other Shaheen Baghs across the country,” said Begum. As for why they couldn’t shift the agitation to another place, the 50-year-old reasoned, “If the government does not hear our concerns despite the road being blocked, would it listen to us at some other site?”

Begum’s inflexibility was expressed on a day when two senior lawyers, of the three people appointed by the Supreme Court as interlocutors, reached Shaheen Bagh for a dialogue to clear the impasse. While Sanjay Hegde explained the concerns of the Supreme Court to the mostly women demonstrators, Sadhana Ramachandran promised to find a solution “together”. The latter cheered the hearts of the demonstrators when she said, “A country that has daughters like you can never face any threats.”

Glad that someone had at long last officially reached out to them, a woman who preferred to remain unnamed, said, “We felt marginalised that despite bearing the winter cold, nobody cared about us. Aren’t we citizens of India? Finally, someone has come to find out what exactly we are sitting in the cold for. We are grateful for this.”

However, there was no woman that TOI encountered on Wednesday who expressed comfort at the idea of shelving the agitation or changing the protest site. “If the Prime Minister listened to us, would we be protesting? If he amended the laws that we, as citizens of India, are demanding, we would immediately vacate the place,” said Rubina, 36, who has sat there for 45 days with her two-year-old son. “They claim to be sabka saath sabka vikas, but laws like these represent vinaash (destruction).”

Rubina said she brought her son to the protest even in cold weather because she wanted him to “witness the struggle so that tomorrow, with God’s grace, this country frees every citizen of the burden of CAA and NRC”. Many women talked of the struggle to sustain their sit-in. “We all have families to take care of, colleges to attend and hundreds of other chores. But where are we? We are here, protesting, so that we do not have to live in fear,” declared 40-year-old Nausheen. “They describe some people getting stuck in traffic because of the occupied 150 metres of the road as public inconvenience. But is their trouble bigger than our having to sit here night and day to secure the future of our children?”

Nausheen added that disbanding their protest would not do justice to the ‘Shaheen Baghs’ that have emerged in other states. Many others nodded their assent, convinced as they were that the central government had amended the citizenship law only to benefit its vote bank. “The leaders have been remarking about what we wear and what we eat. Why are we being stereotyped?” bristled Jannat Ruheen, Nausheen’s friend. “Does anyone have the courage to do the same to the PM?”

Ruheen also bared the frayed nerves of the protesters. “We are facing an existential crisis and it is becoming hard for us to sleep at night,” she exclaimed. “What have we done to deserve this?”

Title: Girl’s death: Crime scene ‘defiled’, FSL suggests narco test on parents in Lucknow
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Representative Image

LUCKNOW: A day after Vikasnagar police registered a murder FIR in connection with the mysterious death of a 15-year-old girl, forensic experts analysed the crime scene on Wednesday and said it had been tampered with to make the case look like suicide.

On Monday, parents of the Class X student had told police that she shot herself with the licensed pistol of her father, a police head constable in the security department, after being scolded for not studying. The girl was rushed to KGMU Trauma Centre, but died during treatment. The postmortem examination, however, revealed that she did not have any gunshot wound and instead died of head injuries. Thus, a murder case was lodged.

A senior forensic expert told TOI that though the girl did not have any bullet injury, a pistol and an empty shell were recovered from the spot. There was also a hole in the wall, apparently caused by the bullet fired from the pistol.

“We traced the trajectory of bullet to the wall from the place where body was found, but it did not match scientific pattern. The lacerated wound on girl’s head seems to have been formed by some hard and blunt object, as mentioned in autopsy report,” he said.

“There is less noise in winters, hence, a 9mm Glock pistol that emits 160 decibel without silencer could not go unnoticed. The neighbours said they did not hear any noise at the given time,” he added.

The multiple abrasions on girl’s feet and left arm are antemortem injuries, which raise questions on handling of body after the crime. The FSL has recommended a crime scene reconstruction and Narco test on her parents. JCP (crime) Nilabja Choudhury said the crime scene would be recreated.

Title: Drone enthusiasts assemble in Dehradun for ‘Dronathon’
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Drone enthusiasts assemble in Dehradun

DEHRADUN: The second edition of “India Drone Festival — Dronathon @ Dronagiri 2.0” organised by the Information Technology Development Agency (ITDA) of the state government, started on Wednesday at the IT Park in Dehradun .

The two-day-long event was inaugurated by chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat . Speaking at the event, Rawat said, “Drones can play a major role during natural disasters like floods and other natural calamities. They can be of great help especially in our state which is prone to natural disasters. The country’s first centre for drone technology was also established in our state and I am sure that young people will get inspired by the use of such technologies.”

Officials of around 20 companies from across the country are attending the event which is focussed on addressing various issues related to counter drone technologies to promote the creation of intelligent solutions. A DARC Mapper Software was released during the inauguration ceremony which generates professional maps, elevation models, 3D models, and point clouds from aerial images.

Several sessions were also held to stress on the importance of drones in supplying medicines in remote areas and during natural calamities like floods.

The event also saw several drone-related competitions which gauged speed, control, and other skills of the participants while operating drones. Some of the competitions held during the event were — Drone PFV Racing, Scan and Lift the Payload, Dhanvantri, Real Time Helicopter Landing Area Detection, Tie the Knot, and others.

Title: Seized Chinese ship isn’t just a cargo vessel: Sources
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Rajkot: ‘Da Cui Yun’ , the Chinese ship which was seized by the customs department a few days ago based on intel reports, has been found to be more than just a cargo vessel.

According to sources, the ship which was found to be carrying suspected equipment used in missile manufacturing had visited Deendayal port nearly 15 times in last one year to discharge consignments here and thereafter leave for Karachi to deliver cargo. In all earlier shipments, the vessel had declared the same cargo as ‘machinery’.

According to sources the vessel belonging to Hong Kong flag of China Ocean Shipping company limited (COSCO) visited Deendayal port at least twice in a month in the past one year. It carried windmill tower as its deck cargo, while it declared the under-deck cargo as machinery or project cargo. After unloading the windmill tower at Kandla, the vessel left for Karachi.

The sources further said that in the last one and half years, a few other multi-port vessels too have gone to the UAE, Gulf and Bahrain after unloading cargo at Kandla. “The loading port — Jiangyin port in China — has always always remained the same for the earlier ships, while the destination of most of the ships was Qasim,” the sources said.

The Defence Research and Development organization (DRDO) which is probing the seized cargo is also investigating into how many times the ship had been carrying such type of cargo.

According to sources the suspected cargo is discharged and taken to a warehouse of Deendayal port. After this, the vessel is released from berth and shifted to outer tuna buoy (OTB). The DRDO is investigating inside the warehouse.

Da Cui Yun started its journey from Jiangyin port in China in January. Around 10 days ago customs department seized the vessel suspecting it to be carrying equipment that is used in missile manufacturing which was meant for unloading at Karachi. The custom officials are tight-lipped on the investigation so far, terming it an issue of national security.

Title: Odisha: Opposition targets government over mismatch in Kalia beneficiaries
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Representative image

BHUBANESWAR: The opposition on Wednesday slammed the state government over the mismatch in the number of beneficiaries under Kalia scheme in the statements of two different ministers. While agriculture minister Arun Sahoo on several occasions said over 51 lakh beneficiaries have been covered under the scheme, finance minister Niranjan Pujari in his budget speech on Tuesday, said 43 lakh farmers have benefitted from Kalia. Pujari said Rs 5,115 crore has been transferred directly to the bank accounts of farmers.

Leader of opposition Pradipta Kumar Naik said BJD used the Kalia scheme to sail through the 2019 elections. Naik said many ineligible people, including government employees, have received assistance under Kalia. Agriculture minister Arun Sahoo did not respond to allegations of mismatch in the number of beneficiaries in two different statements. In a written reply to the assembly on Wednesday, Sahoo said as many as 45,965 ineligible beneficiaries have availed assistance under the Kalia scheme.

Steps are being taken to ensure that ineligible farmers return the money they availed under Kalia scheme, he said, adding that 1,863 farmers have so far returned the cash they received in their bank accounts, Sahoo said.

The state government has earmarked Rs 3,195 crore under Kalia scheme for 2020-21. It has also reduced the annual assistance from Rs 10,000 to Rs 4,000 crore under Kalia.

Title: Kolkata Accident: Tree crashes on three cars, injures bystander
Content:
Vehicles were damaged when a gulmohar tree got uprooted

KOLKATA: One person was seriously injured and three vehicles were damaged when a gulmohar tree got uprooted around 11.25pm on Sambhunath Pandit Street in Bhowanipore on Tuesday.Kalighat Police, which is probing the case, said it was sheer “good luck” that a marriage procession had held up traffic on the road. Had it not been the case, the consequences of the accident could have been worse. The fact that the tree got uprooted without even a burst of strong winds left the KMC red-faced as it went about the entire Wednesday clearing the debris. Locals though claimed that without proper maintenance, at least two other trees in the vicinity is only awaiting a similar fate.Keshav Prasad (27), a pedestrian from Bhowanipore Place, who was watching a band party perform at the marriage ceremony, got injured after the tree fell on him. He is admitted at the SSKM Hospital with head injuries. Two yellow taxis and a Maruti Eeco have been damaged.Cops from local police and the disaster management group teams removed the tree to restore traffic movement. Later, KMC workers took over the task of removing the branches from the tree. No one from the KMC agreed to speak to TOI.“This tree is at least seven-decade old. As a child, we used to take care of this tree and was often rebuked for trying to climb it. I had bought my taxi in 2010. Like any other day, it was parked at the Kasaipara crossing. I rushed out of my residence after my friends informed me that the taxi was completely damaged. When I saw it, I could hardly control my tears. The bonnet was crushed and the rear portion sustained extensive damages,” said Md Zumman (45), owner of one of the damaged cabs.According to Pappu Roy and Sukesh Singh, two local residents aged over 70, rats pose a major challenge in the area. “The trees were guarded by a makeshift boundary earlier. Ever since it was removed two years ago, there was a lot of hue and cry and the rats moved in. We strongly believe better maintenance could have avoided the accident,” Roy said.

Title: Can extend budget session if required says CM Trivendra Singh Rawat
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

CM Trivendra Singh Rawat

DEHRADUN: Reacting to the concerns raised by opposition members that a five-day session would be inadequate for discussing the budget properly, CM Trivendra Singh Rawat said on Wednesday that it was initially decided to conduct the session at Gairsain from March 1 onwards but in view of the International Yog Festival starting in Rishikesh and Holi falling in the second week of March, the session is now being held from March 3 to 7.

“If required, the session can be extended,” the CM told mediapersons. He added that the recent decision to get ministers to be available in the state assembly would enable more people to approach them.

Title: Kolkata Metro: East-West Metro engineers keep tabs on Dalhousie buildings
Content:
Kolkata East-West metro (file photo)

KOLKATA: Kolkata Metro Rail Corporation (KMRC), the implementing agency of the East-West Metro project, has changed gear after getting the high court nod to resume the tunnelling work. While it has restarted burrowing at Bowbazar, engineers are now taking extensive measures to make the entire stretch foolproof and build confidence among people.At Dalhousie, the agency has started taking a host of demonstrable measures, like installing tilt and crack meters to track even the slightest change in the heritage zone, where work is currently on to build a diaphragm for the entrance to the Mahakaran station from the pavement across Currency Building.A subway will come up from this side of the road so that commuters won’t have to cross the road to access Mahakaran station next to Laldighi. Shop-owners and office occupants said engineers from Afcons, contracted to build this part of the underground corridor along with Mahakaran station, were visiting multiple times a day to check for any deviation or cracks that may have developed due to the ongoing work.Before the construction began on the subway and entry-exit point, strengthening work was carried out in the adjoining buildings with fresh cement grouting. Officials from Afcons and KMRC have also informed the occupants to stay away on certain dates when the construction of the diaphragm wall will be under way.In June, 2017, the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) had allowed the construction of Metro tunnels and a station (Mahakaran) close to three heritage structures in the Dalhousie area, removing a major hurdle in the path of a project with stop-start-stop history.Most shop-owners and occupants of offices in the neighbourhood expressed satisfaction over the way Afcons and KMRC were keeping an eye on the buildings. “Engineers come every evening before we shut our shop to check for vibrations. Before the work started, they did some fresh cement grouting to strengthen the foundation,” said Anubhav Biswas, owner of DN Biswas and Company, which deals in arms and ammunition.According to engineers of KMRC and Afcons, multiple instruments, including tilt, settlement and crack meters have been installed in the buildings to record the slightest change so that corrective measures can be taken, if required. “Surface settlement points and building settlement points have been identified for the slightest change while construction around the Mahakaran station is on. The meters are transmitting real-time data, showing any structural change of the buildings. The instrumentation is for heritage buildings like Currency Building and St Andrew's Church that fall within the radius of the impact zone,” the sources said.Engineers have also installed multiple mechanical crack meters to monitor the opening and closing of the “surface crack” in the buildings. “Engineers come every morning and evening to assess if the cracks have deepened or increased in size,” said Dilip Banik, who works in Khadi Gram Udyog on 11 BBD Bag.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Fire breaks out in Uthumalai; trees, herbs damaged
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Local residents saw fire raging in the hills on Tuesday night and alerted the forest department and Shevapet ... Read More

SALEM: Fire broke out in Uthumalai in the city on Tuesday night, destroying trees and herbs spread across a few acres. The forest department is yet to ascertain both the cause of fire and the extent of damage caused by the same.

According to a senior forest officer, local residents saw fire raging in the hills at night and alerted the forest department and Shevapet fire service station officials, who sprang into action to put it out and prevent it from spreading to more areas.

Quoting residents, the officer said thick smoke started to emanate from the hill area around 11pm on Tuesday. “The residents could feel the stench of burning dried trees and other waste material. The fire soon started to spread.”

He said they had removed dry leaves in the surrounding areas of the incident place to prevent fire from spreading to other areas.

“We, along with the fire and rescue services personnel, managed to put out the fire on Wednesday morning. An inquiry is on to identify whether it was a natural fire or man-made one,” the officer said.

Uthumalai is situated near Seelanaickenpatty in the city.

Title: Lammasingi’s 3-yr wait for a resort continues
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Situated a little over 100 kilometres from Visakhapatnam city at an elevation of about 1,000 metres, Lammasingi is well-known for its misty climate, coffee plantations, strawberry farms and scenic landscape. But in spite of being a major tourist attraction in the state, the Lammasingi resort project of AP Tourism Development Corporation ( APTDC ) has been pending completion for three years now.

In August 2017, the then regional director of APTDC had said work would be over by end of December 2017. In June 2019, the executive director of APTDC said work was 90 per cent complete and the resort would be inaugurated within a few months before the tourist season commenced in October. The delay was attributed by APTDC authorities to a lack of funds on occasion and the state election.

With another financial year drawing to a close, the main building in the Rs 5 crore project is still awaiting completion. Civil works outside the building are incomplete as is work on water and electricity supply and other infrastructure.

Some temporary tents without amenities were put up during winter for visitors, with the price of accommodation varying between Rs 1,500-Rs 2,000 depending on the season and days of the week.

A resident of Visakhapatnam, who recently visited Lammasingi said, “Tourists and visitors will have a negative opinion if they stay in the tents available beside the main resort building. There are no toilet facilities nearby and visitors have to go to the incomplete main building among rubble and construction materials to use the barely functional toilet. There is no proper approach road or restaurants, reception counter, telephone facilities – nothing. Someone cooks limited items based on orders from guests. Even if the construction works resume now, it will definitely take eight months to a year for the resort to be fully functional with all amenities.”

When asked about the delay, CEO of AP Tourism Authority and managing director of APTDC Pravin Kumar told TOI, “We have identified 8 to 10 big impact tourism projects worth Rs 50 crore in the state such as resorts in Kovur and Srikakulam, ropeways and Lammasingi is one of the priority projects. Works will commence soon. As for Lammasingi, we did some revalidation of orders last year and this year, and fresh orders have been issued. Works will start immediately and will be completed in the shortest possible time.”

Title: Saurasthra traders, bizmen to attend ‘Namaste Trump’ event
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Rajkot: Scores of traders and businessmen from across Saurashtra will be attending the ‘Namaste Trump’ event in Ahmedabad on February 24. Various trade and industry bodies have been invited by the state government for the inauguration of the world’s largest cricket stadium at Ahmedabad at the hands of PM Narendra Modi and US president Donald Trump.

Parth Ganatra, vice president of Rajkot Chamber of Commerce and Industry said, “Nearly 15 representatives from RCCI will be attending the event in Ahmedabad. We are also expecting to meet trade delegation from the USA.”

Nilesh Jeparia, president of Morbi Ceramic Association said, “About 25 representatives from our association are taking part in the event. After China’s crisis, the window for USA market has opened for us.”

Some industrialists have expressed apprehension over the tight security at the venue. A businessman who did not wish to be named said, “We have been informed to take seat hours early of the event, we have to park our vehicle few kilometers far and have to walk towards event. Some of the members are reluctant to go looking to the security.”

Title: Odisha government hints at jump in paddy procurement
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

CM Naveen Patnaik

BHUBANESWAR: State food supplies and consumer welfare minister Ranendra Pratap Swain on Wednesday indicated the paddy procurement for the ongoing kharif season could exceed expectations with 43.38 lakh metric tonne (MT) having been procured till February 13 against the target of 51 lakh MT for the entire season that started in November last year and is set to be over in April.

The minister was responding during question hour as legislators cutting across party lines, including the ruling BJD, raised concern over discrepancies in the paddy procurement system. With the state government introducing a centralized token system for paddy procurement this year, the minister said as many as 8.13 lakh farmers have sold paddy through this process. In contrast, 7.77 lakh farmers had sold paddy in the same period last year.

“The token system has been introduced this year to ensure transparency in the procurement system and to check bogus beneficiaries from participating in the procurement system. The state government is committed to procure paddy from all genuine farmers,” Swain said. In a separate reply, the minister said as many as Rs 7,458 crore has been transferred to the accounts of farmers who have sold their paddy in the 3,500 mandis across the state while the remaining Rs 416 crore will be transferred to their accounts soon.

Senior BJD leader Bhupinder Singh said many farmers are yet to get tokens as a result of which they could not sell their paddy. He said some of the farmers who have received tokens could not even sell their paddy because of mismanagement at the ground level.

Raising the issue in the assembly, senior BJP leader Jaya Narayan Mishra alleged that farmers are not able to sell their paddy in the mandis. He urged the minister to hold meetings by involving local MLAs to streamline the procurement process. During the discussion, Congress leader Santosh Singh Saluja came down heavily on the state government over its failure to control unscrupulous millers who have been exploiting the farmers. Sensing the mood of the house, speaker Surya Narayan Patro directed Swain to hold meetings with district-level officers to take stock of the procurement status and to place a report in the assembly.

Title: Pune: Snarl-free drive likely in Wagholi by May
Content:
Work includes addition of two lanes to the stretch a six-lane road

PUNE: The residents of Wagholi and people travelling through the area can expect a snarl-free commute along the arterial Ahmednagar road by May.The public works department (PWD) has started making the Pune-Ahmednagar highway’s Wagholi-Shikrapur stretch a six-lane road. Officials said the department was looking forward to complete widening of the Wagholi stretch of the highway on a priority basis and put an end to the daily snarls.The nearly 26km stretch from Wagholi to Shikrapur will have a lane each on both sides, making it a six-lane facility. The officials said the existing four-lane stretch was insufficient to cater to to the increased vehicular load and the entire road widening work was likely to take two years.The PWD has mobilized the machinery for the work on the Wagholi stretch. “Shifting of the underground utility lines, cables and removal of encroachments has been started along the 1,200m stretch starting from Wagholi. There is a plan to widen the road (3,300m stretch) by the end of May. This will cover the portion around Wagholi that often faces traffic snarls,” a PWD official said.Frequent commuters and local residents have been complaining about the chaotic traffic on Ahmednagar road.The issue was also raised during the recent meeting with district guardian minister Ajit Pawar to discuss various issues in Wagholi, which has been witnessing a significant rise in residential projects.The PWD officials said the six-lane project would not face any hurdles, as land acquisition was not required to widen the road. The officials said the department has the right of way that would help expedite work on both sides of the road.With the addition of one lane on either sides, the width of the road would be increased by about 7m — 3.5m on each side. The cost of the work is estimated at Rs219 crore.Vikas Patil, who regularly takes the stretch for commuting, said the road required urgent attention to address the daily woes. “The stretch up to Shikrapur cannot be called a highway, as it has lot of punctures. The road should either have a flyover or an underpass at the major junctions,” Patil said.Kharadi resident Ajay Sathe said, “The PWD should ensure that there’s no delay in the work. It should also ensure that the work does not obstruct traffic.”

Title: Rudrapur: In US Nagar towns, potholes, not roads, the norm says residents
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Potholes

RUDRAPUR: Numerous roads in Udham Singh Nagar district — in prominent towns like Rudrapur, Kashipur as well as other areas — are in a dilapidated condition, with potholes on the roads often leading to accidents. Even the two national highways — NH 74 and 87 which pass through the district —have not been completed, despite the deadline getting over in 2018.

According to residents, the Kashipur bypass road in Rudrapur, which takes the maximum load of traffic, is one of the most affected. Another road — from Civil Lines to National Highway-87 — along with roads inside residential colonies is also in a bad state.

Residents say that it is important to “macadamize the roads on priority.” President of the Rudrapur traders’ union, Sanjay Juneja, said, “People are facing immense hardships owing to dilapidated condition of roads which connect with the main town as well as rest of the colonies. In fact, a person cannot find 100 feet of stretch in Rudrapur without huge potholes.”

Former mayoral candidate belonging to the Congress, Nand Lal, said that the 1.5 km-long road connecting Rudrapur city to Transit Camp, which has a population of over one lakh, “cannot even be termed a road.” “CM TS Rawat had sometime back announced the construction of this road but it still remains a muddy drain. Complaints of residents have simply fallen on deaf ears,” he added.

When contacted, Rudrapur mayor Rampal Singh said that macadamized roads can only be constructed after the temperature goes over 16 degrees Celsius. “We will start constructing roads as soon as the temperature rises. Meanwhile, tile roads are being constructed in full swing to provide relief to people,” he said.

In Kashipur, too, roads are in a poor state, many residents said, adding that some streets are in such a condition that transporters often refuse to ply their vehicles there. A few residents added that the construction of two flyovers above railway crossings in the city have only added to the problem as the projects are running far behind schedule and are simply adding to the chaos on the road. “The main city road from Maharana Pratap Chowk to Haridwar road is dotted with potholes which proves hollow the tall claims of the government in improving road connectivity,” a resident added.

Kashipur's BJP legislator, Harbhajan Singh Cheema, when queried about the situation, said, “I assure that construction of the flyovers and other arterial roads will be completed this year, which will provide relief to residents.”

Title: Tamil Nadu: Old vehicles, waste dumped in Adyar park
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

The ill-maintained park has turned into a den of anti-socials.

CHENNAI: A corporation park at Venkatrathinam Nagar, Adyar, has become a junk yard for old vehicles and a den for antisocial elements. A hotel nearby discards waste into the plot rendering it unusable for children and the elderly, for whom it was set up.

“The park now looks like a dump yard. Food waste and alcohol bottles are strewn all around. No one visits it now,” said K Akanksha, a homemaker and resident of the area.

Opposite the park is an urban community health centre where many pregnant women come for check-up. T Selvi, one of the patients, recalled an incident when two drunk men got into an ugly brawl, broke bottles on the road and stopped an ambulance. “They were joined by their friends. We had to call the police to bring the situation under control. It took 15 minutes for the ambulance to enter the main road which is only a few metres away,” she said.

Caretaker of the hospital said he locks himself in at night. “The moment it gets dark, you can find thugs in the park, drink and shout abuses. They sometimes try to pick fights with me so I stay locked inside the hospital,” he said.

Last year, the Venkatrathinam Residents Association spent more than Rs 1 lakh to redevelop the park. They installed swings, slides, benches and laid a small walking track. “For at least two months, we pooled in funds from all residents and maintained the park. But one month ago, we found old vehicles dumped inside the park and slowly things became worse,” said Shanthi Kamalasekaran, a resident. “We have asked corporation officials to develop this into a proper park, but nothing has happened,” she said.

Zonal officer N Thirumurugan said vehicles were dumped by a local police station. “They are all seized vehicles. Officers said they have no other space to keep them. But I have requested them to take it away,” he said. “This issue was not brought to our notice so far, but we will do the needful.”

Title: Lucknow: 6-hour inferno at Aishbagh plywood unit, 3 workers hurt
Content:
Firefighters douse the flames at plywood unit on Wednesday

LUCKNOW: Three workers suffered serious burns and one is reported missing as a major fire broke out at a plywood factory in densely-populated Aishbagh on Wednesday. It took five fire tenders over six hours to tame the blaze. Firemen and police are yet to ascertain the cause of fire.Locals said the fire started around 1.15pm when 25 people were working in the factory. Trapped in the inferno, they broke windows and scaled walls to escape. Three workers — Mithlesh (22), Virendra Kumar (20) and Sonu (18) — received burns on the head, hands and legs and were rushed to civil hospital, police said. Later in the evening, workers said a colleague who was sleeping inside the factory was still untraced. Police said they were scouring the debris.The leaping flames melted the rooftop water tanks, reduced to cinders a shanty near the factory and threatened to engulf an adjacent unit manufacturing acid along with more than three dozen houses. Residents panicked and dialled 112 but firemen reached around 1.45pm. Although the flames were tamed after a six-hour combat, stacks of plywood were still smouldering till late in the night.Chief fire officer Vijay Kumar Singh said the fire tenders made multiple rounds to refill water. “The factory lacked adequate firefighting equipment. The cause of the blaze will be ascertained.”The factory is owned by an 80-year-old businessman, Dharam Veer Gulati, a resident of Motinagar, but he refused to speak to media.Bazarkhala SHO Vijendar Singh said they had put diversions to block traffic movement near the spot. “There must always be enough space for ambulances and fire tenders,” he added.

Title: Lucknow: Tigress found dead in Dudhwa reserve
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Carcass of Tigress was found in core area of Dudhwa reserve

LUCKNOW: An adult tigress was found dead in Kattaiya range of Kishenpur wildlife sanctuary of Dudhwa Tiger Reserve on Wednesday morning. The carcass was found by beat staff patrolling the area around 7.30am.

“We have got the veterinarian and other staff to investigate. We did not disturb the carcass till afternoon so that we could collect enough evidence,” said director of Dudhwa Tiger Reserve Sanjay Pathak. Prima facie, it appeared to be a case of infighting. The carcass was intact with no organs missing or mutilated. It was found lying inside the jungle in the core area of the reserve.

A postmortem examination report said the feline, aged about 10 years, died of a punctured trachea. Some of its ribs were also fractured. The flesh around the neck was ripped and had canine marks. Pugmarks of a tiger and blood were also found around the carcass. Besides, the claws of the dead feline had flesh of another tiger.

“We looked for the other tiger assuming it would be injured too but could not locate it. We will put up camera traps and try to locate it,” said the official. The viscera of the dead feline was sent to IVRI, Bareilly, for further investigation. Toxicological and histopathological reports would throw more light on the cause of the death of the feline.

Title: HC gives 30 days for report on property tax revision
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Chennai: A 30-day ultimatum has been laid by Madras high court for the committee that is looking into the revision of property tax revision in the state. A report shall be filed in court within 30 days, said a division bench of Justice N Kirubakaran and Justice P Velmurugan, adding that the government should take an appropriate decision on the issue at the earliest.

Issuing the directions on the PILs of SV Subbiah and VBR Menon, the bench also suo motu impleaded the secretary of the union ministry of housing and urban affairs, as a party-respondent to the proceedings, since funding with regard to Swachh Bharat II has to be made by the ministry.

It also recorded the undertaking given by assistant solicitor-general G Karthikeyan to get instruction as to when the Swachh Bharat II fund could be released, so that the Rs 1,000-crore proposal for disposal of garbage being dumped for the past four decades in Kodungaiyur could be claimed.

On Wednesday, as directed by the court the Commissioner of Greater Chennai Corporation and deputy secretary of municipal administration and water supply department, Chennai were present in court.

As for the court’s queries on steps taken to prevent pollution of Cooum, Adyar and Buckingham Canal, as also construction of sewerage treatment plants along the waterways every 3kmor at every stage or creating master sewerage treatment plant for whole of the city, the Commissioner said the projects were being implemented by the Chennai Rivers Restoration Trust in coordination with other departments.

The bench said the Commissioner had submitted that about 7 million tons of garbage had been dumped in Kodungaiyur. As for Perungudi, it was submitted that a Rs 400-crore proposal had been sent to the government for 100% collection of household waste. Additional advocate-general P H Aravindh Pandian submitted that within 30 days’ time the Perungudi project would be approved and provided to the corporation.

Further, it was submitted that to dispose of the waste, contract has been given to a Spanish based company, for about 3000 MT covering 7 full zones. Out of the remaining 8 zones, 4 zones will be directly maintained by the corporation and for 4 zones tender process was almost over.

The bench then posted the case to February 27 further hearing.

Title: Kolkata: TBM modified to avoid Bowbazar repeat
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

KMRC has razed 23 buildings in Bowbazar for extensive grouting

KOLKATA: TBM Urvi, which is completing the job left half-done by its twin Chundee after hitting an aquifer, has been refurbished in the most advanced way. Even if it hits a water pocket of sand aquifer, there will be no water seepage into the tunnel.

Chundee, the machine that was digging the west-bound tunnel of East-West Metro, hit an aquifer on August 31 and water started gushing into the tunnel, leading to large-scale subsidence in Bowbazar. Since Chundee has become defunct, Urvi will complete the rest of the eastward tunneling and then burrow the 800m of tunneling left unfinished by Chundee.

The seal of Chundee’s tail skin brush went off when it was boring a sand aquifer that contained large volume of water. Before Urvi started digging on Tuesday, it was fitted with new tail seal brushes, additional grease supply lines, cover plates for tail skin gap, extra grout holes and Bullflex seals for emergency sealing of any leaks.

Officials said that stringent monitoring schedule is being adopted to complete the rest of the tunneling. Twenty-one additional boreholes were drilled at the Bowbazar area for more detailed soil profiling and strengthening has been done accordingly. The strengthening measures included pressure-grouting and TAM grouting, which have considerably improved the soil strength.

While tunnelling is on, more frequent measurement of deformities within the soil will be carried out. There is improved coordination between the field staff and officials for quicker reaction times to prevent any untoward incident. While TBM Urvi digs through its own path, special care will be taken to inspect the tunnel lining around the affected TBM (Chundee) in the subsidence zone of Bowbazar, where 23 damaged house have now been razed. The ground remediation, officials said, will help in the foundation of buildings that will come up in the area once the two TBMs are pulled out through a retrieval shaft.

In case any severe distortion or movement observed after reaching down 14m to the location where Chundee is lying idle, the affected tunnel linings will be carefully replaced by providing temporary support.

Title: 2-day Araku Utsav to start on Feb 29
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Tourism minister M Srinivasa Rao and Araku MP G Madhavi jointly released the poster for the Araku Utsav , which will begin on Feb 29 and conclude on March 1.

The minister stressed on the need to use the two-day festival as a platform to showcase the culture, tradition and the economy of the region. “Araku draws so many tourists because the region is extremely rich in cultural heritage and endowed with great natural beauty,” he said, while adding that Araku played a key role in giving Visakhapatnam district a prominent place on the country’s tourist map.

Srinivasa Rao said there would be a total 30 stalls, 10 from various government departments, 10 showcasing the region’s culture and 10 food stalls. Besides the cultural events, adventure sports such as trekking, zip cycling, rappling and para motoring would also feature as part of the Utsav. “The state government is committed to the economic development of tribal areas and the welfare of tribal youth. The youth of the area should seize the opportunity to showcase their entrepreneurial skills,” he added.

Earlier, the minister conducted a meeting with representatives of IT companies operating from Visakhapatnam. The minister raised queries concerning the requirements of companies and added that there was a need to provide greater employment for which more companies were required.

Title: Pune: Missing height cap sparks traffic mess
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

PIMPRI CHINCHWAD: The delay in installing a height restrictor on Babasaheb Ambedkar Road and the poor implementation of the heavy vehicle ban has increased traffic congestion on the stretch, which is in the Khadki Cantonment Board-limits.

Motorists coming from Pimpri Chinchwad via the old Pune-Mumbai highway use the Babasaheb Ambedkar Road to go to Vishrantwadi, Yerawada and Pune-Ahmednagar Road.

Manish Anand, an elected member of KCB, said, “The heavy vehicle ban on Ambedkar Road was approved in the 1990s but was not implemented effectively. The board installed a height restrictor before the PMPML bus terminus nine years ago after a student was killed in an accident while riding pillion with her mother. The height restrictor was damaged within a few months and it has not been replaced till now.”

Pramod Kumar Singh, KCB’s CEO, said the cantonment officials and elected members had raised these issues at a recent meeting convened by Pune MP Girish Bapat. “We have demanded the traffic police’s permission to install the height restrictor,” he said. Suresh Kamble, chairman of KCB’s finance committee, said, “There is a need for effective ban on heavy vehicles to reduce the daily congestion and pollution.” Kamlesh Chaskar, an elected member, said there was a need for effective implementation of P1 and P2 parking in Khadki bazaar.

A commuter Anand Kale said motorists faced daily congestion on Ambedkar Road Prasad Akkanouru, DCP traffic, said the KCB had made various demands to reduce congestion, which the traffic police were considering.

Title: Cleanliness takes back seat in Pallipalayam
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

PALLIPALAYAM ( NAMAKKAL ): Overflowing garbage bins and piles of waste on roadsides are a common sight in all the panchayats in Pallipalayam taluk, where sanitary workers’ shortage has affected the overall cleanliness of the area.

According to the local residents, it has been more than two weeks since sanitary workers have turned up to empty the overflowing garbage bins and clean the waste that has piled up along roadsides.

TOI had on Tuesday visited Avuthipalayam , Ottamethai, Matheswaran Koil, Chinnarpalayam and Tharkadu panchayats and they all had the same story to tell.

A Shanthi, of Avuthipalayam, said, “The last time when I saw any sanitary worker in my area was around two weeks ago. As the don’t come for door-to-door collection, we are left with no other option but to dump garbage on street corners.”

Most residents admitted that sanitary workers were not turning up for door-to-door garbage collection.

Social activist A Aadhavan said instead of clearing the garbage, sanitary workers were just setting that on fire on roadsides or where ever that was dumped. “As a result, smoke envelop the entire residential areas, causing respiratory problems to the residents. Also, foul smell fills the air.”

The activist said many private hospitals in Erode city were also dumping medical waste in those panchayats, as they were situated close to that city. “Pallipalayam shares its border with Erode city. On one side is the Cauvery, while Erode is on the other side.”

A sanitary worker said there were only 12 of them to cover all the panchayats, which together have a population of more than 2,400 families. According to him, sanitary workers are paid a meagre Rs 2,600 a month as salary. “So, our daily wage comes around just Rs 87. Each one has to cover at least 100 houses that too with push carts to collect garbage. Then, we have to travel another 4km to take the garbage to the segregating place. How could one expect us to do all that daily for just Rs 87?”

When contacted, block development officer (village panchayats) S David Amalraj said he has been doing his best to manage the crisis with the available manpower. “They are all temporary workers. If I scold them for not collecting garbage a day, they won’t turn up for work the next day. I will, however, look into the issue with all its seriousness.”

Title: Cleanliness takes back seat in Pallipalayam
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

PALLIPALAYAM ( NAMAKKAL ): Overflowing garbage bins and piles of waste on roadsides are a common sight in all the panchayats in Pallipalayam taluk, where sanitary workers’ shortage has affected the overall cleanliness of the area.

According to the local residents, it has been more than two weeks since sanitary workers have turned up to empty the overflowing garbage bins and clean the waste that has piled up along roadsides.

TOI had on Tuesday visited Avuthipalayam , Ottamethai, Matheswaran Koil, Chinnarpalayam and Tharkadu panchayats and they all had the same story to tell.

Title: Vasoya ‘viagra’ jibe sparks row
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Rajkot: Dhoraji Congress MLA Lalit Vasoya , known to have a penchant for making controversial statements, stoked another row on Wednesday with his Facebook post taking a swipe at union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman.

Vasoya put up a photograph of a newspaper article of Sithamaram holding coronavirus responsible for price rise. Below the photograph, he put up a poster stating: “Now, I hope she doesn’t blame viagra as being responsible for population explosion.”

Vasoya also scoffed at Sitharaman saying she is sure to get a ‘gold medal’ in tall empty talks.

Reacting to Vasoya’s jibe, BJP spokesman Raju Dhruv said, “Sitharaman had expressed a possibility that coronavirus can be reason for price hike because if it hits China’s economy, it will have a spiralling effect on India too. Congress MLAs are using such derogatory language out of frustration.”

Title: JNU sedition case: Govt likely to take decision at earliest
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Delhi government is likely to take an “early decision” on the prosecution sanction against former JNSU preside... Read More

NEW DELHI: Delhi government is likely to take an “early decision” on the prosecution sanction against former JNSU president Kanhaiya Kumar and nine others in a sedition case.

Chief minister Arvind Kejriwal told reporters on Wednesday: “I don’t have a say in the department concerned (home). I cannot change their decision, but will ask them to decide as soon as possible.” The CM’s comments come hours after a court directed Delhi government to file a status report by April 3 on the issue.

Delhi Police had booked Kanhaiya and nine others for “sedition” for allegedly raising anti-India slogans during an event on JNU campus in February 2016. The file is “under examination” in the home department, which is yet to take a final decision.

The Code of Criminal Procedure lays down that for offences against the state (like waging war against the government, sedition etc), the court cannot take cognisance of the police chargesheet without the sanction of the home department of the state concerned. In this case, police have invoked Section 124A of IPC relating to the charge of sedition against Kanhaiya and other students.

Delhi government has often questioned the urgency of Delhi Police in filing an “incomplete chargesheet without obtaining the prior sanction of the competent authority”. The home department had earlier pointed out that the investigating agency (Delhi Police) had sought its approval only after filing the chargesheet in the court.

While hearing the case, the court also directed police to send a reminder to the government seeking requisite sanctions to prosecute Kumar. The court passed the directions after police submitted that permission to prosecute Kumar and others had not been granted yet and the letter requesting sanction was pending with Delhi government.

On January 14, the police had filed a chargesheet in the court against Kumar and others, including former JNU students Umar Khalid and Anirban Bhattacharya, stating that they were leading a procession and supported the seditious slogans raised on the campus during an event on February 9, 2016.

Title: Police knew of plan to kill Gulshan Kumar, says ex-top cop’s book
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Mumbai: The crime branch had prior information about gangster Abu Salem’s specific plan to kill music baron Gulshan Kumar , former city police chief Rakesh Maria has said in his book ‘Let me say it now’.

Gulshan Kumar got protection. “Both the protectors and protectee relaxed.” Their sloth and complacency were punished by the patient underworld...,” the book said.

Maria was posted in the director general’s office when he got a call from an informant on the night of April 22, 1997, indicating a plot to kill Kumar. Asked who was behind it, the informant said, ‘Abu Salem’. The gangster had also finalised his plan with his shooters and was to kill Kumar on his way to the Shiva temple he visited every day.

In the morning, Maria called film director Mahesh Bhatt who confirmed with Kumar if he indeed visited the temple daily. Bhatt conveyed the information to Kumar. Maria told Bhatt he would inform the crime branch and Kumar should not step out of home before he gets protection. The crime branch extended protection to Kumar.

On August 12, 1997, Kumar was shot dead while coming out of the Shiva temple. Maria learnt that the protection had been withdrawn after the Uttar Pradesh police commandos provided protection to Kumar’s cassette factory in Noida.

The book also speaks of Maria alerting the crime branch in 1996 of a plan to kill union leader Datta Samant. He was shot dead on January 16, 1997.

Title: Nilgiris to develop fire-line-scrapping to curb forest fire
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Udhagamandalam: The forest department has started to develop fire-line-scrapping, wherein it will remove vegetation for six metres surrounding every block of 10 hectares, in the Nilgiris forest division to curb the spread of forest fire.

The move comes close on the heels of the forest department successfully trying out the method in Korakundha forest area that caught fire a week ago. The fire-line-scrapping was also employed near Lovedale on Tuesday when forest fire broke out in a private land there.

Saravana kumar, assistant conservator of forests, said 10 hectares of forest land was completely destroyed in the fire at Korakundha forest area. “The fire spread to Korakundha forest from Kerala forest as dried grass was present between the two forest areas. Hence, we proposed the plan to develop fire-line-scrapping across the Nilgiris division of forests to prevent such incidents in future,” he said.

Meanwhile, in view of the prevailing dry season in the Nilgiris and especially in forest areas, a mock drill on fire prevention and firefighting will be conducted for forest staff attached to the Nilgiris division of forests soon, the assistant conservator of forest said.

With the dry winter weather still prevailing, forests in the Nilgiris, including the Mudumalai Tiger Reserve, have gone dry. Normally, February and March are the months when forest fire occurs in the mountain district due to the long dry spell.

Title: Workshop on sourcing of power, gas
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Rajkot: The Federation of Kutch Industries Association (FOKIA), Indian Energy Exchange (IEX) and Indian Gas Exchange (IGX) had jointly organized a workshop on ‘Sourcing power and gas through tech enabled exchanges’ in Bhuj on Wednesday. According to FOKIA, the workshop will discuss Gujarat’s situation in power sector, how to reduce electricity cost in industry besides weighing options on how to deal with day-to-day power problems in the industry. It will also discuss how the price of the gas for industrial use remains in control. The gas exchange will be activated by March 2020 to supply gas to the industry.

Title: Nainital: Three nabbed with leopard skin in Haldwani
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Representative image

NAINITAL: A Special Operations Group (SOG) on Wednesday caught three people accused of smuggling leopard skin in Haldwani and seized the skin from them.

According to Kailash Chandra Tiwari, head of the SOG, forest department, the accused were caught from Haldwani’s Lamachaur bridge after they were tipped off by the Wildlife Crime Control Bureau.

Tiwari said, “While one of the accused is from Ramnagar, one is from Udham Singh Nagar district . We are interrogating them to find who the leopard skin was meant for.”
