Title: Delhi: SIT will quiz Jamia Millia Islamia staff on library video leak
Content:
File photo of damaged library of the Jamia Millia Islamia university

NEW DELHI: A few office bearers of Jamia Millia Islamia who are suspected to having leaked CCTV footage of Dr Zakir Husain library , which was posted on social media, are likely to be questioned by the Special Investigation Team of Crime Branch.An initial probe has revealed that the videos were uploaded by someone from Jamia Nagar, possibly to derail the probe. A police team that questioned a few students on Tuesday has zeroed in on a few suspects seen in the footage. Efforts are being made to track them.Police sources said that the videos were case property and copies of it were kept with the Jamia authorities to conduct an internal inquiry to identify people from the crowd who had entered the university. Senior officers said that while an inquiry is under way to identify the securitymen who had beaten students with lathis, releasing the video to an unauthorised group would affect the course of the investigation.On Sunday, the Jamia authorities had denied making the videos public. A separate FIR might be registered if foul play to help the miscreants is established.Earlier, the 17 youths who were arrested after the violence had told police that some student leaders had told them that they could take shelter in the university premises since police were not allowed to enter the campus without permission. It is suspected that the rioters, who had set fire to DTC buses and pelted stones at private cars on Mathura Road on December 15, had mingled with the students and entered the campus when cops chased them.Police scanned through the clips showing a few suspects rushing into the library. Some students who were seen in the videos were questioned to establish whether the suspects were known to them.In Video: Crime Branch SIT summons 2 students in connection with Jamia violence

Title: Dehradun: Army man killed, wife injured after bike crashes into divider
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Representative image

DEHRADUN: A 25-year-old Army personnel was killed and his wife was seriously injured after the bike they were riding crashed into a road divider near Ajabpur flyover in Nehru Colony police station area on Wednesday.

The motorists, identified as Naresh Kumar Gurung and Jyoti Gurung, were taken to a private hospital, where Naresh succumbed to injuries during treatment while his wife is still undergoing treatment.

According to police, the couple, who got married a year ago, was going towards ISBT when Naresh lost control over the bike and rammed into a divider near the flyover.

“It appears that they were speeding and the rider lost control over the bike that led to the accident . Both got seriously injured and were taken to hospital where Naresh died during treatment,” police said.

Title: Bhopal gas tragedy: CBI traces ex-Carbide official in Nagpur, brings him to court
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

BHOPAL: Shakeel Qureshi , the only local Union Carbide official facing criminal proceedings in the Bhopal gas tragedy, has been arrested by CBI. He was the shift in-charge that fateful night, and the only ‘eyewitness’.

He was missing ever since a court convicted all the accused in June 2009. The court of Bhopal district judge, which is hearing appeals of those convicted, had asked CBI to trace him and produce him in court, failing which the CBI SP was asked to present himself before the judge.

Qureshi was traced to Nagpur by CBI and brought to Bhopal in an ambulance on Wednesday as he is paralysed and bedridden. District and sessions judge, R K Verma went to the ambulance himself to see his condition, and granted him bail on medical grounds.

Qureshi, who was a supervisor at the Union Carbide factory in Bhopal, was the shift in-charge on the intervening night of December 2-3 when deadly MIC gas leaked into the atmosphere and turned Bhopal into a gas chamber .

Eight Union Carbide of India (UCIL) officials, including Qureshi, were put on trial on criminal charges. Qureshi was the only one who was a regular at the hearings at the chief judicial magistrate’s (CJM) court. The other accused had received exemption from personal appearance at the outset of trial.

Qureshi was seen in court on the day of verdict in June 2010. He was handed a suspended sentence of two years, like all the other accused, and released on bail.

He vanished after that and stopped attending hearings of the case in the appellate court of district and sessions judge, where both CBI and the convicts had filed appeals against the CJM court order. While CBI prayed for tougher punishment, the convicts sought acquittal.

Qureshi’s absence didn’t raise eyebrows initially since he was on bail and it was not mandatory for him to be present in court. But then, the counsel for two of the accused in the case, Anarbon Roy , started arguing in court that the only person who “knew the whole truth” was Qureshi since he was “present in the MIC room when the gas leaked”.

Bhopal district and sessions judge, R K Verma, asked CBI to trace Qureshi and bring him to court. An arrest warrant was also issued.

On his arrival in court on Wednesday, it was revealed that Qureshi had shifted to Nagpur with his family, where he had started a business. He is bedridden after suffering a stroke.

The judge, after examining his condition, granted him bail on medical grounds on personal bonds of Rs 1 lakh each and payment of a penalty of Rs 10,000.

Title: Waterholes in MTR to be filled using tankers
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Udhagamandalam: The Mudumalai Tiger Reserve (MTR) in the Nilgiris has planned to transport water through tankers to refill waterholes in the forest to cater to wild animals if the dry spell continues beyond February.

Deputy director of MTR (core region) Shenbagapriya said, “The amount of water available inside MTR is manageable till February-end. In case of no rain, precautionary measures are being taken to fill waterholes in the reserve to cater to the animals.”

Based on the requirement, water will be transported through tankers to refill the waterholes in the reserve. Arrangements in this connection are underway, she said.

Besides 50 artificial ponds, there are around 209 small waterbodies located within the core area of MTR which are facilitated by natural streams. The ponds were desilted recently. The hills received adequate rain during the north-east monsoon. Majority of them have sufficient water, according to the official.

She added, “Keeping in mind the dry season, we had cleared the fire-lines running through the core area of the reserve to protect wildlife from forest fire. Anti-poaching watchers, fire-watchers, foresters and forest guards have been provided with walkie-talkies and wireless instruments so that forest fires could be reported instantly to take immediate measures”.

In a bid to tackle the forest-fire much effectively, tools such as blowers, sprayers and helmets have already been procured, the official said.

According to her, constant patrolling is underway in the MTR. Almost all debris of dry leaves on the sides of road are being cleared off to minimize forest fire. NH 67 runs through the MTR to a stretch of about 20km.

Usually March and April are the critical period for the reserve due to dry spell.

“Accordingly, the situation in the reserve vis-à-vis water and forest-fire is being reviewed for action periodically,” Shenbagapriya said.

Besides home to over 80 tigers, MTR is abode for several species of wild animals including leopard, Indian guar, elephants, sloth bear and hyena.

Title: Man gets life term for impregnating minor girl
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Coimbatore: A 29-year-old man was sentenced to life imprisonment by the special court for Pocso cases here on Tuesday evening for impregnating a minor girl in 2015. The court also ordered the state government to pay a compensation of Rs 3 lakh to the girl and Rs 2 lakh to her baby girl. The accused, M Keerthiraj, a daily wage labourer from Ganapthy here, fell in love with a 15-year-old girl in 2015. The girl was studying in Class VIII. By promising to marry her, Keerthiraj had raped the girl repeatedly. When the girl’s mother learned that her daughter was pregnant, a complaint was lodged with the all women police (east), Coimbatore city, on September 29, 2015. Police registered a case under few sections of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (Pocso) Act and arrested Keerthiraj. He was lodged at the Coimbatore central prison. After the investigation, the police filed a charge sheet before the court. Blood samples were collected from Keerthiraj and DNA test was also conducted. Judge J Rathika pronounced the judgment on Tuesday and found Keerthiraj guilty under sections 5 (L), 5 J (ii) read with 6 of Pocso Act. Meanwhile, the minor girl delivered a girl and got married. tnn

Title: Three new medical colleges approved
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Gandhinagar: The Union government has given final approval for three new medical colleges, at Rajpipla, Porbandar and Navsari, Nitin Patel, deputy chief minister and health and family welfare minister Nitin Patel said in Gandhinagar on Wednesday.Patel said, “The Union government had invited proposals to set up new medical colleges in 75 districts of the country that have no medical college. Five medical colleges have been lined up for Gujarat. The Centre has given its approval for setting up medical colleges in Narmada, Navsari and Porbandar districts.”Patel said Rs 325 crore will be spent for each medical college. “Of this, 60% (Rs 195 cr) will be borne by the Union government, while the state government will bear the rest of the project cost. The three new colleges will thus cost Rs 975 crore,” Patel added.He said the hospitals attached to these medical colleges will have 300 beds each in the first phase and the medical colleges will 100 seats in the first year each. tnn

Title: A year into service, Vande Bharat Express eyes longer, comfortable run
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Vande Bharat Express, the first indigenous train of Railways that runs between Varanasi and New Delhi

LUCKNOW: Vande Bharat Express, the first indigenous train of Railways that runs between Varanasi and New Delhi and recently completed a year in service, may be diversified into a “long-route train without compromising on the comfort of passengers”.

The debut train set that rolled out in 2018 — earning it the sobriquet T-18 — was flagged off by the PM in February 2019, and had chair cars. The research wing of Indian Railways, RDSO in Lucknow, has reworked specifications of the train “for the better”. “In the future, T-18 may also have sleeper coaches. Passengers cannot be expected to sit through longer journeys,” a source at RDSO said.

Although the 44 new train sets that ICF will manufacture this year will have chair cars for now, given the revised specifications, it does not limit T-18 from diversifying into sleeper coaches as and when it is introduced on longer routes.

“In a sleeper coach, the load is not distributed equally as one side has more berths. The train might tilt to one side while running at high speed. The load, therefore, needs to be equally distributed in the underframe of the coach,” a source said, adding that the new specifications would allow the train save 20% journey time. The train sets with sleeper coaches may be called T-20, but will retain the same speed.

Title: From creating dreams to playing them out
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020


Gautham Vasudev Menon

Chennai: They began their film careers creating dreams from behind the camera. Now, they find they are equally adept in front of it, in a career they feel is as challenging as the first. Gautham Vasudev Menon — who earlier appeared in a song or two in his films and lent his baritone to characters like Ilamaran in ‘Vettaiyaadu Vilaiyaadu’ or Pandiya in ‘Kaakha Kaakha’ — Karu Pazhaniappan, Mysskin, Samuthirakani, M Sasikumar and Ram among others are all finding acting exciting. While directing a movie is no child’s play, particularly given the quality of today’s filmmaking — ask any of the multitudes of actors who took up the megaphone and gave it up after realising it was a tough task — there are twin benefits for directors who turn actors. Instead of wallowing in gloom after a few flops, which are inevitable, they get to make quick money; and, best of all, get to remain in the public eye. Pazhaniappan, who was encouraged to don the grease paint by director Sundar C, says the media glare is on actors every time. "They wait for an actor to come out of his residence, so they can get hot news. Where do we figure?" Pointing out that he was approached to act in a film that is to be released this May, and not vice versa, Pazhaniappan says, "Playing an antagonist, I can vouch it’s a ticket for success, though I have experienced the same as a director… A director loses his time if his work is not appreciated, although I must say that it’s not like I have quit direction. I can always go back to my roots." Gautham Menon, whose ‘Trance’ with Fahadh Faasil is in theatres this week, says most of the movies in which he acted had his friends as directors. "Dhanush wanted me to be part of ‘Power Paandi,’ and Dulquer Salmaan was adamant I share the screen space in ‘Kannum Kannum Kollaiyadithaal.’ Stating that acting is less stressful, Menon says, "I don’t have to worry about next day’s shoot and write my script in between shots. It de-stresses me, it’s a win-win situation. My family though insists I do less of acting and more of direction." Direction is a high pressure job, with one having to put up with star tantrums, keeping the crew together and handling unexpected situations, but many of those who have earned a name for themselves continue to opt to be in front of the camera. Why? Learning new things and engaging with others from the industry, says director-actor Samuthirakani, is the key to survival. "My first love is direction, but I have worked in amazing projects like ‘Visaranai’, ‘Vada Chennai’ and ‘Subramaniapuram’. Simultaneously, I write dialogues, engage in dubbing and think about my next project. Keeping my mind busy and fresh." Manobala, who has acted in more than 950 films after making his debut as a director in the 1980s, says acting is easier. The industry too has changed. "Young talent coupled with realistic cinema has taken it to a different level. I am not sure if the movies we did in the past would have received the recognition they did if made today. Besides, in today’s times, it’s an enjoyable experience to be an actor. I do what I am asked to perform, nothing more, nothing less." Having become an actor thanks to director Shankar, who got a sense of his sense of humour after seeing him at a gathering, Manobala says co-stars like Santhanam, Yogi Babu, Vadivelu and himself have given innumerable hits in a few years. "I am content and wish to take up challenging roles in the future as well, he says, adding that Shankar’s upcoming ‘Indian 2’ has him essaying playing a unique role. Until as late as the 1980s, directors were mostly invisible, with stalwarts like K Balachander, C V Sridhar, A C Tirulokchandar, Balu Mahendra, Mahendran and Panchu Arunachalam content in their space and satisfied with bringing out hidden talent. Even the celebrated Mani Ratnam, who managed to work wonders with the millennials, opted not to face the camera. The new trend may also have to do with the reality that down south one needn’t have to be like an Arvind Swamy, an Ajith or a Surya to be a ‘hero’. Average looks with an aptitude for learning will do. The young directors who have opted to act are aware of this and are willing to walk the extra mile for success.

Title: Four accused for ‘period check’ get bail
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Rajkot: The four women including principal of Shree Sahajanand Girl’s Institute, arrested for forcing girls to strip to check their menstruation status, were released on bail on Wednesday by a local court in Bhuj.

Principal Rita Raniga, Anita Chohan, Ramila Hirani and Nayna Gorasia were arrested for outraging modesty of the girls and threatening them. They were release on bail after their two day police remand ended on Wednesday.

Title: Delhi: Lifts can now take you to terraces
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: Senior citizens and physically challenged people in Delhi will now have easier access to the buildings’ roofs and terraces . The bylaws governing installation of lifts in the residential buildings of the city have been amended, and as per the new rules, “all the floors, including basement and rooftop/terrace, shall be accessible by the lifts.”“Several points of unified building bylaws of Delhi-2016 rules, which govern construction of buildings, have been amended by Delhi Development Authority (DDA). The new rules shall be applicable from February 12, 2020 onwards,” said a senior south corporation official.Till now, lifts are available only till the highest floor . From there, people have to climb up to the roof/terrace using staircases.“It was causing inconvenience to senior citizens and disabled people. Their access to roofs was hindered and their wheelchairs had to be carried from the top floor,” the official added.Lifts provided in the buildings will, however, not be considered for use in case of an emergency, clarify the amended regulations. “It is important to keep staircase access for tragedies like fire,” added the official.Some other changes regarding height exemptions and building permit requirement regarding lifts have also been incorporated in the amended bylaws.“Earlier, the height of a machine room/lift room, which houses all the equipment on a roof, was included in the overall permissible height of the building. This has now been exempted,” the official said.“People would be reluctant to install lifts in residential buildings in several cases as the height for the floors had to be reduced. But now, the machine room shall be exempted from the height limit,” explained the official.However, the total height cannot breach the Airport Authority of India’s permissible limits.To facilitate easy installation of lifts, authorities have also expanded the list of procedures for which building permit will not be required.

Title: Teesta Setalvad’s Shaheen Bagh address leads to controversy
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Teesta Setalvad

NEW DELHI: Rights activist Teesta Setalvad ’s address at Shaheen Bagh became a subject of controversy after BJP IT cell head Amit Malviya alleged that she was “tutoring” the women protesters .

Malviya tweeted a 2.16-minute video with the caption: “Teesta Setalvad tutoring Shaheen Bagh protesters on what questions to ask the interlocutors, appointed by the Supreme Court... See how organic and spontaneous this movement is?”

The video shows Setalvad standing beside a woman in a pink hijab facing a sea of women. The woman narrates some questions that they want the interlocutors to address.

“Will changing the style or kind of protest change or weaken it? Who will guarantee safety of the protesters at another location? What do we have to say about the problems being faced by some people because of road closure?” the woman on the mic is heard asking. She also asks if opening one carriageway of the road is a possible solution. Setalvad then asks the women if the questions are okay.

Although Setlavad was unavailable for a comment despite repeated attempts by TOI, her organisation, Citizens for Justice and Peace (CJP), shared her response to Malviya’s allegations.

“The disgusting attempts by some pro-BJP and government TV channels to dare suggest malicious motives in CJP’s involvement in a pre-mediation process is nothing short of a despicable and desperate attempt to deny Shaheen Bagh women protesters their agency. Can anyone dare suggest that women who have sat through Delhi’s bitter cold for 65 days be tutored? It’s demeaning and a diversion,” CJP quoted Setalvad.

Women protesters agreed with Setalvad’s assessment of “infantilising” them. “We have sat here for over two months day and night. We know why we are here to protest. I wish people would not think we don’t know why we are here or we don’t know what to do,” said a protester.

“It is an open forum. Anyone can come to speak to the women protesters. Teestaji came yesterday and said she would come today too. She is a big person. She said she will ask the women some questions. We said okay,” the protester added.

Title: Gujarat: BJ Medical may lose 100 postgraduate seats
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Faculty members at the B J Medical college fear that the college is set to lose nearly 100 postgraduate seats this year, if 70-odd faculty members are not transferred back to the college in time because the PG inspection by the Union government in Gujarat colleges is round the corner.

These faculty members were transferred in the last four months from the government colleges, where students study on subsidized fees, to those government colleges which are self-financed and run by the Gujarat Medical Education and Research Society (GMERS) across the state. These transfers took place when the National Medical Commission conducting inspection in medical colleges for undergraduate courses.

A senior faculty member at the BJ Medical College said that there are more than 250 teachers from different colleges, who were transferred to GMERS-run colleges but they have not been transferred back to their original workplace, though PG inspection is due now. “If BJ Medical College does not get its regular faculty members back, the college may lose nearly 100 PG seats in next academic session. This is because the seats are allotted in ratio of availability of faculty members,” he said.

Various representations have been made for restoring the transferred medical teachers to their original place, but the senior members think that the process has met a bureaucratic hurdle.

Sources said that the political pressure has worked in transfers, particularly in Bhavnagar medical college. “Because of intervention of BJP chief Jitu Vaghani, the administration transferred back all 27 faculty members who were shifted ,” sources in health department said.

Title: India Int’l Knit Fair hopes to yield Rs 300cr worth deals
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Tirupur: The 47th edition of three-day ‘India International Knit Fair’ which concluded on Wednesday saw buyers from across the globe come down to Tirupur scouting for quality garments.

According to Apparel Export Promotion Council (AEPC), buyers from Sri Lanka, Mauritius, the UAE, Sharjah, the US, the UK, Bangladesh, Europe and Canada visited the fair. Sponsored by the Union textile ministry, the fair was organized by the AEPC. Thirty-nine leading exporters from Tirupur, Coimbatore, Chennai, and Kolkata displayed their products in the fair.

AEPC said the exporters were overwhelmed with the response and hope that the fair would yield business deals to the tune of Rs 300 crore.

The fair had summer/winter collections in knitwear, space dyed yarn garments, cotton, polyester, poly cotton, polyester-viscose blended fabric apparels, special garments made from banana cotton blend. The banana cotton blend with 80%cotton and 20%banana fibre with an inherent property of offering comfort, particularly attracted the buyers, according to AEPC. Garments with reverse print, cold pigment dyed, 3D print, acid spray styles, tie and dyed, bio washed, enzyme washed were also showcased.

Chairman of India Knit Fair Association A Sakthivel noted that the fair was organized in the backdrop of the current scenario where China’s trade is affected due to COVID-19, the UK has detached itself from the European Union and Vietnam and Cambodia are exempted from import duty due to Free Trade Agreement.

“This is expected to make India a preferred market for buyers from western countries. Also, countries which were depending on China have learnt a lesson that they should have an alternate market for sourcing,’’ he said. tnn

Title: Atrocities by warder: HC directs DM and district judge to send team to talk to Chamoli jail inmates, submit report
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Representative image

NAINITAL: The Uttarakhand high court (HC) on Wednesday directed the district judge of Chamoli and district magistrate (DM) to send a team to investigate the allegations made by the inmates of the district jail against the warder.

The HC had taken suo motu cognizance of a letter written by a group of prisoners who alleged that the warder had brutally beaten up several prisoners and in some cases even draped them in blanket and then used a stick to deal severe blows on their feet. The letter signed by 26 prisoners also said that the warder doesn’t even allow them to perform basic activities such as puja and if his orders are not followed, the inmates are again harassed. The inmates alleged that the harassment and physical torture was very common in the jail and several inmates were on the verge of committing suicide.

The bench of Chief Justice Ramesh Ranganathan and Justice Ramesh Chandra Khulbe did not agree with the state government’s submission that several officials visit the jail continuously and no atrocities have been reported from the jail. “The complaint which has been treated as PIL has been signed by 26 inmates. We may not therefore be justified in brushing aside the allegations,” the court said.

In its order, the court added that the jailor who is alleged to have committed such an act would hardly admit to it and therefore the district judge should “depute a senior official along with the secretary, district legal services authority to visit Chamoli jail and interact with inmates and also those who signed the letter”.

The DM and the judge have been ordered to submit the report within three weeks and the court said that orders have to be handed over to them by a special messenger of HC.

Title: Climate change may affect migratory patterns: Study
Content: Ahmedabad: Climate change and gradual warming of migratory birds habitat is a threat to animal migration. The migratory populations or species could become partly or wholly sedentary under influence of climate change.This was observed by the research paper ‘Transboundary Wildlife Conservation in A Changing Climate: Adaptation of the Bonn Convention on Migratory Species and Its Daughter Instruments to Climate Change.’ The paper further said that there are ample observational evidence of migratory birds becoming more sedentary because of climate change.The research publication stated that the effect of climate change would thus be more of a threat to animal migration as a phenomenon than to species survival. Common buzzards in Europe appear to to becoming a sedentary species. Paper states that observers at the migration bottleneck of Gibraltar will witness the last time a common buzzard glides across the Strait to Africa, whereas numbers of buzzards crossing another migration bottleneck, at Falsterbö (Sweden), are also dropping.The paper states that both for migratory and non-migratory species, climate change considerably augments the need for international cooperation in wildlife conservation. The paper states that the Conventional on Biological Diversity Conference of Parties has resolved to “take measures to manage ecosystems so as to maintain their resilience to extreme climate events and to help mitigate and adapt to climate change and to integrate climate change adaptation measures in protected area planning, management strategies, and in the design of protected area systems.”It was also suggested to reduce the negative impacts from climate change as far as ecologically feasible, through conservation and sustainable management strategies that maintain and restore biodiversity. The paper stated that reducing non-climate stresses, such as pollution, over-exploitation, habitat loss and fragmentation was the need of the hour. Also to for reducing climate related stresses was through enhanced adaptive and integrated water resource and marine and coastal management.The paper states that climate change has been formally acknowledged as an actual or potential threat to the conservation of the species concerned under various MoUs. Further research or monitoring of climate impacts have been issued to study climate change.

Title: NHRC notice to Uttar Pradesh over 4 malnutrition deaths in a family
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Harishchandra Pandey with his ailing daughter

LUCKNOW: The National Human Rights Commission has issued a notice to the state government over a report that a family residing in a village in Basti lost four of its members in the past six years allegedly due to malnutrition.

NHRC took suo motu cognisance of the report and has asked UP chief secretary to submit a detailed report in four weeks.

The commission has also sought a report on the implementation of social welfare schemes in Basti, with details about the family where the alleged malnutrition deaths occurred.

Harishchandra Pandey’s wife allegedly died due to malnutrition eight months ago, chief medical officer, Basti, JP Tripathi told TOI. “Villagers have also told us that three daughters of Harishchandra also died of malnutrition in the recent years,” he added. Harishchandra is a native of Kaptanganj block of Ojhaganj village in Basti.

“Harsihchandra Pandey’s only surviving child, 4-year-old Bindhavasini, is seriously ill and undergoing treatment. She is suffering from a neurological disorder and there is no sign of malnutrition so far,” the CMO added.

“The girl has undergone medical tests and reports are awaited,” he said.

Title: Mobilise people for tomorrow’s CAA rally: Goa church to parishes
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: After having asked the Centre to revoke Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ), the Goa church has upped the ante and issued a diktat to all parish priests to mobilise parishioners for an anti-CAA rally on Friday.

In a letter to all the parishes sent on Tuesday, the church has asked priests to announce the date of meeting at daily masses and encourage parishioners to come out in support of the agitation.

“Our fight to oppose CAA/ NPR/ NRC and to demand that it be revoked unconditionally continues both at the state as well as the national level,” said the letter to the parishes.

Ten days earlier, archbishop of Goa and Daman Filipe Neri Ferrao released a strongly worded statement appealing to the Centre to “immediately and unconditionally revoke the CAA and desist from implementing the National Register of Citizens (NRC) and the National Population Register”. “The very fact that the CAA uses religion goes against the secular fabric of the country,” Ferrao had said.

Tuesday’s letter said that ‘Goa Alliance Against CAA-NRC-NPR’ is organising the rally and it would be followed by a public meeting at 3.30pm on Friday.

“The rally is not organised by the church and the other two organisations that held the last two rallies at Margao and Fatorda. The church through the Council for Social Justice and Peace has only extended support towards mobilisation of people for the rally,” Fr Savio Fernandes, executive secretary of the church body, told TOI.

“We sent out the letters on Tuesday to all parish priests and chaplains asking to mobilise parishioners,” he said.

The rally will be flagged off from Parade Grounds at Campal and will culminate at Azad Maidan with a public meeting.

Earlier in his statement, the archbishop had said the NRC and the NPR exercises would result in “a direct victimisation” of the underprivileged classes, who will “suddenly run the risk of becoming stateless and candidates for detention camps in their teeming millions”.

In response, chief minister Pramod Sawant had said he would meet the archbishop to convince him that CAA did not hurt any sections of society.

“It is observed, sadly, that these initiatives issuing forth from the government are forecasting a systematic erosion of the values, principles and rights which have been guaranteed to all citizens under our Constitution, and which citizens are called to protect and promote,” Ferrao had said.

Title: Dehradun: DMC becomes first in state to get ODF Double Plus grade
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Dehradun: The Dehradun Municipal Corporation (DMC) has become the first civic body in the state to be recognised with an ODF (open defecation free) Double Plus grade.

The ODF Double Plus grade will add extra 500 points in the municipal corporation’s kitty during the final evaluation of the Swachh Survekshan Survey 2020.

A team from the Centre had come last month which found that the city has ample amounts of public toilets run by the municipal corporation. The team also found that there are many community toilets in the slum regions. The toilets have exhaust fans and clean sheets and are in a decent hygienic condition.

Civic commissioner Vinay Shankar Pandey said, “We are extremely glad to receive an ODF Double Plus Grade. Also, we are glad to become the first municipal corporation in Uttarakhand to receive such an honour. With this, we have gained an extra 500 points and this will help us in getting a good ranking in the Swachh Survekshan Survey 2020.”

He added that the distinction has been achieved due to the relentless effort of DMC staff, including the sanitation workers. “The condition of public toilets across all 100 wards is good and we will continue to work in order to make sure that Dehradun remains free of open defecation,” he said.

Title: FC Goa now set for tiki-taka with Asia’s elite clubs
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Panaji: In the end, it’s only fitting that the most entertaining and consistent team gets the honour to become the first Indian club to take part in the high-profile AFC Champions League.

FC Goa have had four top-four finishes in five seasons, made it to the final twice, became the first team to record 50 wins in the Indian Super League ( ISL ) and have now broken their own record of most goals—46—in the league stage.

Though the team has not yet emerged league champions, they now have a record they can be proud of.

Goa’s 5-0 demolition of Jamshedpur FC at the JRD Sports Complex—a place their fans call the Furnace—on Wednesday gave the league leaders an unassailable 39 points and the top spot at the end of the league stage.

For their efforts, they will receive Rs 50 lakh and a ‘Shield’ introduced by the organisers for the first time. But most importantly, Goa will become the first club from the country to take part in the AFC Champions League group stage next season.

“From the beginning it was one of the objectives of the club to reach the group stages of the (AFC) Champions League by coming first in the league. Finally, to match that objective is a great feeling,” said Goa’s interim coach Clifford Miranda.

In the past, several Indian clubs, including Goa’s record-setting Dempo SC, have qualified for the Champions League playoffs but have never managed to cross the hurdle. All of Asia’s best clubs take part in the Champions League, while the rest test their might in the AFC Cup, Asian football’s second-tier club competition.

The AFC Champions League is second only to the European club competitions in terms of prize money and in addition to the $1 million increase for the winner and the runners-up from last season, they will now get an extra $500,000 taking the purse to $2 million.

While all Indian clubs have played the AFC Cup—or European football’s equivalent to the Europa League—they have received nothing in return. In fact, Dempo once gave the competition a miss, despite qualifying, since it did not make financial sense.

The AFC Champions League will be different as clubs have plenty to gain. Apart from the thrill and glamour of rubbing shoulders with the best clubs from Asia, there are added financial incentives too.

A fee of $40,000 is paid per team for each match they participate. There is $50,000 on offer for a club winning their match in the group stage, $10,000 for a draw, $100,000 for reaching the knockout stage and $250,000 for reaching the semifinals.

A spot for an Indian club among the elite in Asian football was made possible by the Asian Football Confederation’s decision to increase the number of teams from 32 to 40 for next season.

According to tentative groupings, when the competition starts next season in January 2021, Goa could be up against the might of clubs from Iran, Uzbekistan, Qatar and the UAE. The level of competition will be much higher than what any Indian club has faced.

But, for a start, Goa will be happy by just being there.

Title: From refusal to rash driving, app cabs take Lucknow for a ride
Content:
Represenative Image

LUCKNOW: Taking a cab home from work late in the evening wasn’t as smooth as Sanjana Mehdiratta had imagined it would be. After five frustrating attempts to book an Uber, the 24-year-old advertising professional learnt that app-based commuting services were anything but dependable.College student Honey Verma’s Ola bike taxi experience was intimidating. The 18-year-old was abandoned in the middle of nowhere for mildly protesting against rash driving. And that after the bike taxi nearly ploughed into a shop wall.These are not stray incidents. In fact, they are fairly routine going by concerns raised by several app cab users on social media platforms. From being quizzed by drivers about destination and mode of payment to watching the cab circle on the map and incurring penalty as rogue drivers take eternity to arrive — every second user has a complaint to voice. In 2018, the New Delhi government had proposed a policy to impose a fine of Rs 25,000 on taxi aggregators for violation of trust.. In the absence of a monitoring mechanism, app cab riders in UP face harassment on a daily basis.“I was booking a cab home to Krishnanagar from Hazratganj around 11pm. The driver called to know my drop location and said he was coming, but five minutes later he cancelled the trip. Five more drivers did the same. I got sixth time lucky,” Sanjana told TOI. She said most drivers, planning to call it a day, look for riders who live closer to their homes.Honey who goes to college on Faizabad Road and depends on bike taxis said most drivers had their temper on a short fuse.Anushree Gupta, an Ola regular, said the taxi aggregator recently charged her for a trip she never took. “I tried booking a ride thrice, wasted an hour doing so and was made to pay even though my trips were cancelled. To top it all, the customer service was pathetic,” the Aashiana resident said, adding that often drivers ditched riders once they realised the payment mode was online.Uber acknowledged receiving an email from TOI, but didn’t answer the queries made. Contacted over WhatsApp, an official on November 22 said “someone from the team will shortly get in touch”, which didn’t happen. Answering a phone call, an official said their response on the issues was awaiting a nod from the brass.Similar mails, messages and calls to Ola did not evoke any official response.

Title: Mussoorie: Man arrested for raping 10-year-old
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Representative image

MUSSOORIE: A 38-year-old man , a resident of Jharipani area of Mussoorie , was arrested on Wednesday for allegedly raping a 10-year-old girl.

In his complaint, the survivor’s father said that the accused, a neighbour, had been raping the minor for several months. He said he came to know about the matter on Wednesday and rushed to police.

Station officer Vidhya Bhushan Negi told TOI, “The accused, Govind Upadhyay, has been booked under the POCSO act and under section 376 ( rape ) of IPC. The victim has been sent for a medical examination,” Negi told.

Negi added that the girl had been sent to Dehradun for a medical examination.

Meanwhile, sources said that survivor had been warned against opening up about the abuse by the man. The parents got to know about it from a neighbour.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme Court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Maoists blow up school building in Gaya
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

A portion of a school building blown up by Naxals at Bankey Bazar area in Gaya on Wednesday. (ANI Photo)

GAYA: Suspected Maoists blew up a government school building in Gaya ’s Banke Bazar area late on Tuesday night and anti-NRC pamphlets were found at the spot, police said.

Gaya SSP Rajiv Mishra said, “Nobody was injured in the blast that razed the empty school building.” Hand-written pamphlets have been recovered, which bear slogans against “Brahminvadi, Hindutvavadi fascist BJP government,” and question the “occupation” of school buildings by security forces.

A CRPF contingent was stationed at the school until recently. “A team of 153 Battalion of CRPF had been camping here since March 18 last year when Naxals had carried out an attack ahead of the Lok Sabha polls. They had been putting up at the Sonedaha High School and shifted to a camp on February 08,” Mishra said.

“Three rooms were substantially damaged in the blast. About two dozen heavily armed Maoists were involved in the activity. More than 15 members of the squad took positions on the village outskirts to take on security forces, if they reached the blast site and the remaining activists triggered the blast. No arrest has so far been made in this connection,” the SSP said.

Title: Bihar: Sharad Yadav says not in CM race, backs Tejashwi Prasad Yadav
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Sharad Yadav

PATNA: Days after meeting incarcerated RJD chief Lalu Prasad in Ranchi, Loktantrik Janta Dal (LJD) patron Sharad Yadav on Wednesday made it clear that he was not in the race to be the Mahagathbandhan’s CM face for the coming assembly polls and backed Tejashwi Prasad Yadav for the position.

The LJD leader had held a closed-door meeting last week with the heads of smaller constituents of the alliance —RLSP chief Upendra Kushwaha, HAM (S) chief Jitan Ram Manjhi and VIP chief Mukesh Sahni. The three senior leaders wanted Sharad to convey to Lalu their “concerns” over RJD’s “big brotherly” stand of unilaterally projecting Tejashwi as the alliance’s CM face.

Sharad, while making it clear that his political arena is New Delhi, hinted that he could take up the responsibility of heading the Mahagatbandhan’s coordination committee.

“For Vidhan Sabha election, Tejashwi’s name is for CM candidate as RJD is the biggest party and he (Tejashwi) is the leader of opposition. Many people talk about me as CM candidate, but for 43 years my politics has been confined to Delhi,” Sharad told mediapersons on Wednesday.

Advising the Mahagathbandhan parties to stay united, Sharad added, “Tejashwi is the opposition leader and others should come together and fight the assembly election together.”

Talking to TOI, the LJD leader admitted that his name is being discussed as the patron of the opposition alliance’s coordination committee. On his meeting Lalu he said, “Meeting with RJD chief Lalu Prasad on Saturday was regarding strengthening Mahagatbandhan.”

Sharad’s name started doing the rounds for CM post after reports saying some opposition leaders, including RLSP chief Upendra Kushwaha, were inclined towards Sharad as possible CM face. The closed-door meeting between Kushwaha, Sahni, Manjhi and Sharad without RJD and Congress further fuelled speculation regarding a drift in the Mahagatbandhan.

But after the Friday’s meeting, LJD state vice-president Binu Yadav had told TOI that the alliance leaders had come together to discuss the issue of co-ordination committee and wanted him to take up the responsibility. Even Sahni had said that Sharad was not interested in Bihar politics and had hinted that he was not averse to Tejashwi as the CM candidate of the Mahagathbandhan.

Title: Bengaluru couple strikes gold for three-in-one diagnostic device
Content:
Gold award winners Binita Shrivastava Tunga and her husband Rashbehari Tunga with Sudha Murty (L) and Nandan N... Read More

BENGALURU: A Bengaluru couple who has created a single device capable of detecting the three most prevalent mosquito-borne diseases — malaria , chikungunya and dengue — in early stages of infection are among winners of the Aarohan Social Innovation Awards (gold) instituted by Infosys Foundation. The award carries a cash prize of Rs 20 lakh.While it usually costs over Rs 4,000 to get three separate tests done for the three infections, the device can help a patient can get diagnosis of all three at Rs 600.“A patient would usually spend Rs 4,000 to Rs 4,500 on the three tests. Through our single-use device, all three diseases can be detected at Rs 600. The device has been created based on vertical flow immuno dot technology. Though the three diseases can be termed very common, especially in India, there are no devices that pathology labs currently have for detecting co-infections,” said Binita Shrivastava Tunga, microbiologist and director of Ameliorate Biotech Pvt Ltd, a city-based biotech startup.The device was developed by Binita and her husband Rashbehari Tunga , who’s the firm’s director. It is currently undergoing medical evaluation in Bengaluru, Delhi, Kolkata and Ahmedabad.This year’s edition received more than 1,700 entries, and winners were identified across four categories: healthcare, rural development, destitute care and sustainability. Apart from the prize money of Rs 20 lakh, all gold award winners will be offered an eight-week residential mentorship at Indian Institute of Technology (IIT), Hyderabad. The cash prize for silver award winners is Rs 10 lakh.

Title: Shivaji could have saved Goa from colonial atrocities, says CM Pramod Sawant
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Chief minister Pramod Sawant

PONDA: Chief minister Pramod Sawant said on Wednesday that Goa would not have suffered atrocities from colonial rulers if Maratha king Shivaji had conquered Goa.

Sawant said the Maratha emperor had established his rule over major parts of Goa region and had he not to return (to Maharashtra) to sign a treaty with the Mughals, Goa would have been free 300 years earlier.

Following a long-drawn freedom struggle, Goa was liberated from the Portuguese rule in December 1961.

According to historical books, Shivaji was forced to sign the treaty on June 11, 1665 with a Rajput ruler Jai Singh I, who was a commander of the Mughal empire.

Under the treaty, it was agreed that if Shivaji wanted to claim the Konkan area including Goa, which was at that time under the Bijapur sultanate, he would have to pay 40 lakh hons to Mughals.

He said Shivaji had established the reign over five talukas of Goa, including Bardez, Pernem, Bicholim, Antruz Mahal (Ponda) and Salcete. However, he had to return under the treaty of Purandar.

Sawant said Shivaji was called king of the masses as he had members of all castes and religions in his cabinet.

He said while it was not possible to have a Shivaji-like reign, his government would try hard to imbibe some of the values in its governance.

“We will try our best to emulate his values and perform better,” he said at a state-level function held to celebrate Shivaji’s birth anniversary at Ponda.

After garlanding the horse ridden Shivaji statue at Farmagudi fortress, the chief minister also said a huge fort would be constructed at the fortress site. An exclusive gallery would be set at the renovated fort and all the historical documents available at the archaeology department would be brought here.

The work for the fort construction would start within a year, he said.

Title: Delhi high court bar calls for strike over judge’s transfer
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Justice S Muralidhar was appointed judge in Delhi high court on May 29, 2006.

NEW DELHI: The Supreme Court collegium headed by CJI S A Bobde has recommended the transfer of Justice S Muralidhar from Delhi high court, where he was appointed judge on May 29, 2006, to Punjab and Haryana high court , leading to protests from the Delhi high court bar association that called for a strike on Thursday.

Justice Muralidhar, who was part of the high court bench that first ordered decriminalisation of Section 377 of the Indian Penal Code to give freedom of sexual expression to the LGBT community, is number three in seniority in his parent high court. If the government accepts the recommendation, he will be number two in seniority in Punjab and Haryana high court after Chief Justice Ravi Shanker Jha.

He had run into criticism from certain quarters for quashing the transit remand and directing release of rights activist Gautam Navlakha from house arrest on October 1, 2018, in the Koregaon Bhima case even when the matter was pending in the Supreme Court.

Last year, a bench headed by Justice Muralidhar had convicted 16 former policemen of Uttar Pradesh in the Hashimpura massacre case and also sent Congress’s Sajjan Kumar to jail in one of the anti-Sikh riots cases.

Expressing “shock” at the collegium recommending Justice Muralidhar’s transfer, the high court bar association hoped the decision would be recalled, saying such transfers were “detrimental” to the institution.

“Unequivocally and in the strongest possible terms, the Delhi high court bar association condemns the said transfers... Such transfers are not only detrimental to our noble institution but also tend to erode and dislodge the faith of the common litigant in the justice dispensation system. Such transfers also impede free and fair delivery of justice by the bench,” a resolution passed by the association said.

The association requested its members to abstain from work on Thursday “as a token of protest as the said transfer is a rarest of rare case, the majesty of our revered institution is at stake”.

However, sources said the judge’s consent was taken before issuing the transfer proposal.

The Supreme Court collegium, through cryptic notifications, also recommended the transfer of Justice Subramonium Prasad of Madras high court to Delhi high court. Justice Prasad, before his appointment as Madras high court judge on June 4, 2018, was practising as an advocate in the apex court.

It recommended transfer of Bombay high court’s Justice Ranjit V More to Meghalaya high court and Karnataka high court’s Justice R V Malimath to Uttarakhand. The collegium also recommended appointment of four judicial officers — I J Vora, Gita Gopi, Ashokkumar C Joshi and R M Sareen — as judges of Gujarat high court.

Title: CAA protests: Former Mangaluru mayor deposes for magisterial probe
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Road to recovery: File photo of ex-mayor K Ashraf undergoing treatment in a private hospital in Mangaluru, in ... Read More

Mangaluru: Former mayor K Ashraf , who suffered a head injury during the December 19 Mangaluru violence, submitted his evidence in writing before Udupi deputy commissioner G Jagadeesha, who is heading the magisterial inquiry into the alleged police firing, on Wednesday.

Ashraf said in the 10-page submission before the Udupi DC, that he has explained what he had seen at the spot. “I reached there to convince the protesters at the request of city police commissioner P S Harsha. I submitted 15 CDs and a compilation of videos from various social media platforms. However, the magistrate refused to accept it, as they were not recorded by me, ” he said.

Jagadeesha told reporters that 204 people have made their submissions. Since a bandh was observed on February 13, public, police and the media were given another opportunity to submit videos before the court, based on the high court directive. On Wednesday, only Ashraf appeared and submitted his evidence in writing. The CDs and pen drive brought by him, were not accepted because he claimed in his affidavit that he had received the videos on his phone, and copied them into a CD at a cyber centre. Since we do not know the source of the videos, it cannot be used in the investigation. The inquiry is happening as per the Supreme Court’s guidelines. Those released on bail can come forward and submit their evidence during the hearing, he said.

Next hearing for police personnel

Jagadeesha said 12 police officers and staff will be given an opportunity to appear for the next hearing on February 25. Notices have been issued to the police through ACP (North) and nodal officer Belliappa K U to submit all the documents during the next hearing. City police commissioner Dr P S Harsha and DCP (law and order) Arunangshu Giri will be called separately. The statements of 176 policemen will be recorded as part of the inquiry, based on the list provided by the police. Meanwhile, the DC will submit the status report on the case to the high court on February 24. Jagadeesha said the police have submitted a pen drive with 50 video clips and one CD. The police had seized 23 DVRs that were submitted before the court, and the acknowledgement was presented here. As per the government order, a report on the inquiry will be submitted before March 23.

Jagadeesha said depending on the situation, if required, he would seek more time from the government. Following the December 19 violence and the death of Nauseen Kudroli,49, and Jaleel Bengre, 23, due to alleged police firing, the state government commissioned two probes, one magisterial and the other CID.

Title: Bail condition of Mugilan relaxed
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Madurai: The Madras high court has relaxed the bail condition of activist Mugilan in a rape case registered against him by the Karur CB-CID officials.

The case was registered against Mugilan alias Shanmugam under IPC Sections 417, 376 and Section 4 of the Tamil Nadu Prohibition of Harassment to Women Act, 2002, based on a complaint filed by a woman alleging that he had physical relationship with her after he promised to marry her. The case was later transferred to the CB-CID.

When Mugilan moved the high court Madurai bench seeking bail, the court on November 13, 2019, granted bail to him on condition that he should appear before the Karur CB-CID inspector of police once in two days at 10.30am until further orders.

In January, Mugilan had filed a petition seeking to relax his bail condition following which it relaxed the condition and directed him to appear before the police once a week.

Meanwhile, Mugilan once again moved the high court Madurai bench seeking to completely relax his bail condition. When the petition was heard on Wednesday, justice G R Swaminathan gave the direction relaxing the condition. TNN

Title: India in need of more women in life sciences
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

IT minister KT Rama Rao along with Intel India country head Nivruti Rai (extreme left) welcomes Odisha ministe... Read More

HYDERABAD: In a bid to encourage more women in the pharma and life sciences sector, Primal Enterprises vice-chairperson Swati Piramal mooted the idea of setting up a National Commission for Women in Science to encourage over 100 million girls to excel in science and eventually emerge as leaders in this industry. She pointed out that Telangana being one of the leading states in the pharma and life sciences industry can take the lead in this area and set an example for other states as well.

“Telangana being one of the leaders in the lifescience industry, it could target million girls from science and get them from schools and work with teachers and parents … to make them leaders in this industry,” she said, while speaking on ‘Women in Life Sciences, Healthcare & Tech – The Journey From Aspire to Inspire’ at BioAsia 2020 here on Wednesday.

As per industry estimates, women constitute only about 10-15% of the workforce in the pharma and life sciences industry in India constitutes as compared to around 28% globally.

The other industry leaders such as Nivruti Rai, country head, Intel India, and Dr Christiane Hamacher, CEO, Biocon Biologics, too suggested that companies create a conducive ecosystem for women to thrive in their careers.

Rai pointed out that Intel had introduced 'Home to Office’ or ‘H2O’ initiative that brought women, who have been on a career break, back to work. As part of the programme, women are trained for a stipulated period and eventually given a chance to join the organisation.

Similarly, Dr Alenka Stefanic Petek, head of Sandoz Development Centre, India, spoke about how organizations are not just making a conscious effort to ensure diversity in their workforce but also ensuring that its service providers too follow the same by setting up benchmarks for them.

Title: USFDA: Manufacturers’ quality systems in India have matured
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Facilities in over 150 nations export FDA-regulated products to the US

HYDERABAD: The US drug regulator, United States Food & Drug Administration ( USFDA ), indicated that the overall adherence to quality framework by Indian manufacturers has improved over the last couple of years.

“I think that if you are talking about difference from a few years ago, there has been an increase in maturity of quality systems…,” Dr Sarah McMullen, deputy director, USFDA India office, said on sidelines of BioAsia 2020 when asked about the performance of Indian firms.

McMullen added that FDA has been closely collaborating with the Indian drug regulator Central Drugs Standard Control Organisation (CDSCO) and in many inspections, CDSCO officials join as observers. FDA conducted around 200 inspections last year in India, which supplies approximately 40% of the generics sold in the US.

The FDA official said that once pharma manufacturing units receive Form 483, they must respond to authority in “comprehensive thoughtful and realistic” manner within the stipulated time of 15 days, following which they can fix the problem.

“So, if you are facing regulatory action, you need to be open and transparent in your communication to the agency … your responses are read comprehensively by the agency…you have to make a response within 15 days to 483, you do not have to fix everything in 15 days. So, I think that is a misconception… so sometimes people want to look at short-term fix or something and that might not be the most appropriate thing …,” she said while participating in a panel discussion on ‘Meeting the Quality Imperative’.

Title: Montevideo the new calling for IT professionals
Content:
Artists perform a traditional routine at the Las Llamadas parade in Montevideo

HYDERABAD: A significant number of Indians are now making their way to Uruguay with the growth of the IT sector in the Latin American country. A similar time zone as the United States has also made the country an attractive location for companies who are now scaling up their hiring. At present, around 1,000 Indians currently work in Uruguay, up from 300 in past three years according to industry insiders. Almost 50% of this workforce is Telugu.One of the reasons for this increase in hiring is down to US-based clients looking to outsource work to ‘near-shore’ centres. Near-shore centres allow companies under similar time zones to work together to make communication faster, a recent shift from the traditional off-shore or on-site axis.At a time when many countries are moving towards protectionist measures, Uruguay comes as a breath of fresh air for many Telugus looking for international exposure. “Uruguay has become a destination which can cater to EST, CST and IST,” says Bairaboena Niranjan, who has worked in Uruguay for three years with TCS.With tech biggies such as TCS, IBM, Deloitte present in Montevideo and Google soon to open its Latin American data centre, hiring in Uruguay is said to be on an upswing. “This is one of the safest places. There is a lot of potential for growth and no restrictions,” says Raghunath Rao Buddineni who works with a tech giant in Montevideo.Having lived for four years in the Uruguayan capital, Jaswanth Reddy also agrees that it offers a peaceful and an easier way of life. “While the pay is less than the US, so are the costs. The quality of life is unparalleled. That there is almost no pollution and serene landscapes makes it a place to look forward to,” he says.Cost of living is an important draw for many, says Telangana Information Technology Association (Tita) president Sundeep Kumar Makthala. “Accommodation for a paying guest, including food, can be as little as Rs 25,000 which is ideal for freshers. Indian food too is easily available,” he says. Starting salaries range from between Rs 50,000 to Rs 60,000 a month. A Uruguay peso amounts to just a shade under Rs 2. Industry experts say that given the IT sector’s nascence in the country, there are very few people at the senior levels thus offering a better scope for growth.

Title: CGS Inc to ramp up Hyderabad headcount to 2,000 in next 5 years
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Phil Friedman

HYDERABAD: US-based applications, learning and outsourcing player Computer Generated Solutions Inc (CGS) is expanding its presence in Hyderabad with a new facility and is drawing up plans to ramp up its headcount in the city to about 2,000 over next five years, founder president and CEO Phil Friedman told TOI here on Wednesday. He said CGS also plans to set up its global cybersecurity operations centre (CSOC) in the city and ramp up its capacities in augmented reality based learning solutions.

Friedman, who is in town for the opening of CGS Inc’s new 80,000 sq ft facility spread over five storeys in Madhapur on Thursday, said the company plans to grow its headcount from around 500 to nearly 800 in the city over the next 18 months or so.

“We have development work happening in US, UK, Canada, Romania and Hyderabad. Our engineers in Hyderabad are engaged in doing some sophisticated software development work,” Friedman said, adding that apart from software development, the company is also building teams for development of AR-based learning solutions as well as cyber security operations in the city.

“All our AR learning solutions visualization work is currently done out of our CoE in Canada but we plan to do the data curation work for it here in Hyderabad. Currently, we have a small team of about a dozen employees engaged in this here, which we plan to grow over time,” he explained and added that the CSOC team, which is about a handful of people now, will grow in the future as the company brings on board the requisite talent for it.

Title: Involve citizens in drawing up plans and budgets, say activists
Content:
TimesView Given the state of the city’s infrastructure, it’s clear that BBMP is not the most efficient of organisations. This inefficiency masks a significant amount of graft, influence management and patronage. Involving citizens in decision-making, especially where budgets and efficient delivery of services are concerned, is something that councillors will find deeply threatening. How many people have been held accountable for pothole deaths or punished for the state of lakes? How many have been penalised for flouting guidelines — building, fire safety or others? This is why citizen participation is important, starting from the ward level.

BENGALURU: When it comes to formulating ward projects, masterplans and budgets, a bottom-up approach is required, where citizens are actively involved in urban planning, said civil society members , adding that ward committee meetings have been reduced to grievance redressal fora.Civil society members, under the banner of Civic, recently wrote to urban development department principal secretary Anjum Parvez, with recommendations for the Karnataka Municipalities draft bill prepared by the National Law School of India University, Bengaluru.“Ward empowerment and strengthening is key to bring about transparency and accountability in urban governance. Very little weightage has been given to citizen participation in the draft bill,” said Kathyayini Chamaraj, executive trustee, Civic.“Our main suggestions include ensuring participation of genuine people through elected area sabha representatives, who sit in on ward committee meetings. Area sabhas should also be empowered to conduct social audits. The veto power given to counsellors concerning ward panel meeting decisions has to be removed,” she added.Srinivas Alavilli of Citizens for Bengaluru, who recently spoke at a ‘consultation on transparency and accountability in the paradigm of urban governance’ at BMS College of Law, pointed out that ward committees , which have taken over 28 years to be established, must be given more time to become stronger.“The committees have finally become functional in Bengaluru and over 1,000 meetings have been held in the past 18 months or so. While their functioning is in no way perfect, it’s developing in a positive manner. The main problem is inadequate citizen participation. The next BBMP elections will be crucial since 2,000 additional ward committee members will be added to the existing network. This will change urban governance in the city,” opined Srinivas.Pointing to a study conducted between July and October in 22 wards by Sensing Local Foundation, it’s co-founder Ankit Bhargava said it showed there’s lack of consistency in conducting monthly ward committee meetings and documenting the same.“There is no standard format for communication of ward committee meetings — notices are shared on WhatsApp groups, which all citizens may not be a part of. We also detected inconsistency in setting and sharing of the meeting agenda in many wards. Only in 60.9% of the meetings surveyed was the corporator found to be anchoring it. Such meetings have largely become grievance redressal platforms instead of focusing on ward planning, budgeting, project oversight and monitoring of supply of urban services,” he said.

Title: APSRTC goes digital with app and prepaid card
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Vijayawada: State-owned AP State Road Transport Corporation ( APSRTC ) on Wednesday went digital with the launch of a free mobile application called Chalo, and the Chalo travel card. The app will integrate all 500 RTC city buses in Vijayawada into a single live-tracking and journey planner tool.

The free mobile app will benefit around 2.5 lakh bus travellers in Vijayawada as the app will help them know the live arrival time of their bus so that they can plan their travel accordingly, track the live GPS position of their bus on a map, plan their trip door-to-door using a multi-modal trip planner, find the cheapest and fastest trip options including all the bus route options to their destination, and buy their daily tickets directly through the app at 5% discount and thereby save on every trip.

The Chalo travel card is a prepaid smart card to buy bus tickets on the go.The card is offered free with a first recharge of Rs 100.

Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Title: Telangana: Project Tej launched to aid local innovators
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

HYDERABAD: In a bid to accelerate and support indige-nous innovations in medical technologies, the Telangana government and MedTechConnect, a platform founded by Cyient and Xynteo’s India2022 coalition, have joined hands to roll out a new initiative called Project Tej . Xynteo is a Norway-based consulting company focused on sustainable growth.

The initiative will provide aspiring entrepreneurs a platform that can help them test their innovative ideas in medical technologies space. An MoU was also inked between Telangana State’s Research and Innovation Circle of Hyderabad (RICH) and MedTechConnect at the ongoing BioAsia 2020, which is touted as Asia’s largest biotechnology and life-sciences forum.

The project will accelerate the adoption of indigenous and cost-effective innovations in medical technologies in India’s public health systems by bringing together an alliance of industry, hospitals, start-ups, and ecosystem builders in the MedTech space. It already has the support of more than 25 institutions across India. Through Project Tej, medical technology innovators and device manufacturers can validate the usability of their devices in public health settings and gain access to public health channels.

These testbeds will give MedTech innovators access to real-world clinical settings for faster validation of innovative, affordable technologies and also provide access to industrial networks and markets. “Implementation of Project Tej will help provide real-world access for companies to test and commercialize their technologies. We hope this creates an encouraging environment for local start-ups to bring their products to the market,” said Cyient executive chairman BVR Mohan Reddy.

Title: SSB constable found hanging in Pilibhit
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Pilibhit: A constable of Sashastra Seema Bal’s 49th battalion posted at DIG office in Pilibhit was found hanging inside his flat in late hours on Tuesday.

The deceased was posted in Pilibhit for past five years and was living alone at a rented accommodation in Bagh Gulsher Khan locality under Pilibhit Kotwali police station. The police have sent his body for autopsy. The deceased was identified as Munesh Kumar (30) - a permanent resident of Mathura district. According to SSB officials, he had been blessed with a son a fortnight ago and had resumed duty on February 24.

According to SHO, Shrikant Dwivedi, the constable was first seen “hanging” by his landlord. Postmortem report confirmed the cause of death as hanging, he said.

Deputy inspector general of SSB, SN Singh Visht, further said that Kumar was a normal person and hardly had any issues. He is survived by wife, two daughters and a 15-day-old son.

Title: BMTC to BBMP: No money for staff salaries and you expect us to pay tax
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Bruhat Bengaluru Mahanagara Palike

BENGALURU: A desperate attempt by Bruhat Bengaluru Mahanagara Palike ( BBMP ) to collect property tax dues to shore up its revenues met its match in an equally desperate Bangalore Metropolitan Transport Corporation (BMTC), which is in the red.

“We don’t have money to pay our drivers and conductors. Do you expect us to pay property tax to BBMP?” a senior BMTC official was quoted as telling the Palike officials who visited the transport utility’s Shantinagar headquarters last week to recover levy dues totalling Rs 9.6 crore, which had piled up over four to seven years.

A few days earlier, another BBMP team was in for a bigger shock when it visited a BMTC office in Malleswaram ward to recover property tax dues. According to Palike staffers, a BMTC official told them: “We don’t have money. Take our Volvo buses .”

It was the BBMP officials’ turn to beat a retreat. “Where do we keep the Volvo buses if we confiscate them? We have to safeguard them as they are not our property. It would be a logistical nightmare. The cost of maintaining them would only drill holes in our pockets,” said a senior official from the revenue wing of the civic agency’s west zone.

BMTC sources, however, denied their official had the made “take the Volvo buses” remark. “Volvo is our luxury bus. How can we give it to anybody?” they said.

Another BMTC official said the utility’s financial position is weak. “The cost of diesel has gone up and so have employees’ salaries. Besides, passenger traffic is reducing,” he explained. The official said they have requested BBMP to collect tax only for BMTC’s commercial structures and not for vacant properties or housing infrastructure like depots. About 60% of BMTC’s properties are commercial. “Property tax arrears towards our non-commercial properties alone amount to nearly Rs 4 crore. We are asking the Palike to bail us out by collecting property tax for our commercial properties ,” added the official.

The corporation has also requested BBMP to write to the government on its behalf and request extra subsidy for the utility.

Title: LRD candidates end protest after minister’s assurance
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Gandhinagar: Chief minister Vijay Rupani would have breathed a sigh of great relief after women candidates from the SC/ST/OBC categories of the Lok Rakshak Dal recruitment ended their protest after more than two months, after Pradipsinh Jadeja, minister of state (MoS), home, met them and promised them justice.

Jadeja said, “The state government is adhering to the policy of reservation. We are committed to ensuring the constitutional reservation rights of all citizens. The stir was totally political and the government has assured all LRD women candidates that it will take care of their interests. The recruitment will be completed shortly. The government has created 2485 new LRD vacancies and set 62.5% as the cut-off mark for the recruitment. The government’s decision to create supernumerary seats is to protect the interests of candidates of all castes,” he added.

Title: BS Yediyurappa: On hunger strike, Bilal Bagh women want talks with Karnataka CM BS Yediyurappa
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

The demonstration entered its 12th day on Wednesday

BENGALURU: Women protesters at Bilal Bagh have intensified their campaign against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, 2019, by starting a relay hunger strike and demanding that chief minister BS Yediyurappa visit the site to hear their concerns.

Two women stopped eating on Tuesday and two others will take their place on Thursday as part of a cycle which will continue till the government acknowledges their demands.

The Occupy-movement-style demonstration at Bilal Bagh, organised on the lines of Delhi’s Shaheen Bagh, entered its 12th day on Wednesday. The women here have demanded that the Karnataka government should not implement the controversial citizenship law and the proposed National Register of Citizens (NRC).

Poet Nasreen Syed, who is among the protesters, said the decision to go on a hunger strike was the result of anxiety and pain that the participants were facing because of the government’s indifference.

“Dard ko bhi Aadhaar card se jod do na, saheb, jinko mila hai unko dubaara na mile! (Dear sir, link even the pain with respective Aadhaar cards, so that people who experienced it once don’t have to go through it again),” she said. “The indifference of the government, unconstitutional laws like CAA and NRC have killed our appetite anyway. We can’t eat, drink or sleep because of the constant worry about the state of affairs.”

According to a volunteer, about 1,000 women joined the first two protesters on hunger strike, staying off even water, on Tuesday.

The Bilal Bagh women said the developments in Delhi won’t have an impact on their stir. A Supreme Court-initiated mediation process is underway in the national capital to persuade Shaheen Bagh protesters to shift their venue of sit-in.

“We are ready to die, but won’t move from here. We will continue to fight to protect our Constitution,” said Warsi, one of the women on hunger strike. She added that the opposition to CAA had united citizens.

Another protester, Firdaus, shared a similar view. “Shaheen Bagh inspired us and this fight will continue,” she said.

Avani Choksi said Bilal Bagh had an independent existence and the events in Delhi won’t alter its course. Teresa Braggs, a student, said Shaheen Bagh protesters were unlikely to budge.

Title: Telangana to boost medical device manufacturing sector
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Telangana industries and IT minister KT Rama Rao

HYDERABAD: To tap the potential of the multi-billion dollar medical devices industry in the country and give a fillip to local manufacturing, the Telangana government will be setting up common testing facilities in the medical devices park at Sultanpur as well as establishing a med-tech export promotion council in Telangana, state industries and IT minister KT Rama Rao said on Wednesday.

The announcement was made after the minister’s meeting with medical devices manufacturers at BioAsia 2020. He also assured the industry that Telangana government will be taking up their cause for issues such as regulatory hurdles and inverted tax structure with the relevant ministries of the government of India. “We will be their advocates in terms of bringing regulatory changes that are in the government of India’s domain…,” he said.

Speaking about the Medical Devices Park, Sultanpur, which is the largest in the country, he said it has already attracted 25 companies. “Within the Medical Devices Park, Sultanpur, we have seen a great deal of success as 25 companies have now signed up. In July, we expect to inaugurate six manufacturing facilities on the same day,”KTR said.

Title: Photos: Deepika Padukone pairs crop denim jacket and jeans with white sneakers for her airport look!
Content: The CBI has taken over the mysterious death case of Bollywood actor Sushant Singh Rajput from the Mumbai Police and has been probing it extensively. While Rhea Chakraborty is expected to return for the fifth round of questioning today, the CBI has summoned her parents to join the investigation as well.

Title: Personalised stamps in honour of Parrikar on anvil
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Panaji: The department of posts has requested the state government to come up with a proposal for the release of a ‘My Stamp ’ in memory of former defence minister and ex-Goa CM Manohar Parrikar .

‘My Stamp’ is a personalised sheet of postage stamps. It involves the printing of thumbnail images of a person, logos of institutions or images of artwork, heritage buildings, etc, alongside the selected commemorative postage stamp. “Postage stamps are usually released after 10 years of the death of a person,” said postmaster general, Goa region, N Vinodkumar. “We have informally told the state government that it can come up with a corporate My Stamp on Parrikar.”

During World Post Day celebrations at Maquinez Palace last year, chief minister Pramod Sawant had requested the department to come out with a postal stamp of Parrikar to commemorate his stint as Union defence minister.

“We need to get proposals from sponsors for the release of stamps. The proposals are then forwarded with recommendations to our New Delhi postal directorate where they are examined and approval for the release of stamps is given,” Vinodkumar said.

The central government recently renamed the Institute for Defence Studies and Analyses (IDSA), a government think tank, as the Manohar Parrikar Institute for Defence Studies and Analyses to honour the former defence minister. Posts officials said this may urge stamp collectors to have a thumbnail of Parrikar in their collection.

“Philatelists will also want to collect this stamp especially considering that Parrikar was posthumously awarded the Padma Bhushan last month. We are hopeful that once printed, the stamps will sell out immediately,” a senior posts official told TOI.
