He was replying to a question in the assembly by Congress MLA Bharat Singh Kundanpur. A day earlier, 29 peacocks died after consuming poisonous food grains in Nagaur district. The Congress MLA pointed out that peacocks are being killed by people for meat and feathers. The incidents of death of peacock have been reported in the state quite frequently. This could be addressed only if the government takes strong measures like banning sale of peacock feathers. He asked whether the government considering banning the sale of peacock feathers as it encourages poaching of the national bird. The minister replied in the affirmative.

Title: After quarantine, medicos to be monitored for 14 days
Content:
According to officials, the two students are expected to return to Bareilly by Wednesday night

BAREILLY: The district health department will monitor two medical students who were kept in an isolation ward in Manesar after they were evacuated from China. Following the spread of novel coronavirus (nCov-2019), New Delhi had evacuated students stuck in China, and afterwards quarantined them for possibility of affliction by the deadly disease at the army base camp in Manesar near Gurgram.Additional chief medical officer Dr Ranjan Gautam said, “Both students from Bareilly who were evacuated from China and kept in isolation, have tested negative for nCov-2019 and their condition is stable. But, we’ve been asked to monitor them for a few more days as a precautionary measure.”District epidemiologist Dr Meesam Abbas said, “Integrated Disease Surveillance Programme (IDSP) unit of Bareilly will monitor them for the next 14 days. If any symptoms appear, samples will be collected and sent to a Lucknow laboratory for tests.”According to officials, the two students are expected to return to Bareilly by Wednesday night. Father of one of the students told TOI, “My 22-year-old son is a third year MBBS student at a college in Siyan, China. He arrived in India on February 1, and was discharged now after 18 days. We are waiting for the situation in China to normalize before he can return to continue his studies.”Meanwhile, the sample of a five-year-old girl who caught fever after returning from Thailand, tested negative for nCov-2019 on Wednesday. The child was among seven people who had travelled to Thailand last month and are being monitored by the health department. The girl’s sample was taken on Tuesday after she had fever.In Bareilly, health department has collected samples of five suspected cases for nCov-2019. All of them have tested negative.The incubation period of the virus begins from the date of arrival to India. The health team takes daily updates to check if any symptom has appeared, including fever, cough, difficulty in breathing, chest pain, pneumonia and rapid heartbeat.

Title: Sand mafia unleashed terror: BJP MLA Lahoty
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

JAIPUR: Hours after the Supreme Court asked the Rajasthan government to take immediate action against illegal mining, Jaipur BJP MLA Ashok Lahoty welcomed the decision, saying the sand mafia has unleashed terror in the state.

He alleged that the state government and the sand mafia were working "in an alliance" for the past one year. Earlier reacting to the order, state revenue minister Harish Chaudhary said the government will submit a report and other information sought by the Supreme Court regarding sand mining.

The Supreme Court on Wednesday took strong exemption to rampant illegal sand mining in Rajasthan and directed the state government to take immediate steps to stop it. Seeking an action taken report from the state government within four weeks, the bench headed by Chief Justice S A Bobde said illegal sand mining is likely to "damage the environment irreparably". “The Supreme Court's direction is a welcome step. The sand mafia has written a new chapter of terrorism in Rajasthan.

Every night, 2,000 trucks transport sand illegally. This is a very serious matter. The mafia attacks the media and police. An organised crime is flourishing in the state," Lahoty said.

Title: Youth plant trees to turn Chinnalapatti green
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Madurai: At a time when greenery has largely been wiped out of the globe to make way for urban space, an army of youngsters in Chinnalapatti of Dindigul district, made a difference by planting thousands of trees in 18 town panchayat wards.

Joining hands for the green gesture, organizations Vritcham Pasumai Iyakkam, Pasumai Vaasal and Abdul Kalam Trust hope that they can soon turn the drought-hit wards lush green again, thus bringing back rain eluding the region for some time. The campaign members said that their panchayat received less rain for lack of trees resulting in water crisis and this could be sorted out by growing trees.

To source their saplings, they set up a nursery in Jeeva Nagar, the fifth ward of the town panchayat, and the saplings are distributed for free to public and other organisations who came asking for them. As the saplings are free for all, many came forward to join the effort.

P Raghavan of Jeeva Nagar says that the awareness among the youth on this and their response are encouraging enough. Many others, including elder people, are now following suit. He said a lot of youngsters in the panchayat consider APJ Abdul Kalam as their mentor and leader, trying to fulfill his vision the way they can.

“Kalam had stressed the importance of trees for a better environment. When trees are grown in large numbers, soil will be reinforced with nutrients, which will lead to the growth of many trees, grasses and shrubs. This is what we are doing,’’ he said.

Vijayakumar, Nagarajan and Saravanan of Vritcham, Durairaj, Sivakumar of Chinnalapatti green movement and Ajay, Sivakarthik and Ashok of Abdul Kalam trust are the active members of the drive, together planting about 4,000 saplings so far. They travel regulary to water the saplings

Title: Bhilwara’s Gori family to flag off 808 Urs in Ajmer today
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Ajmer: The Gori family of Bhilwara will flag off the 808 Urs of Khwaja Moinuddin Chishti from February 20 in Ajmer. The first mehfil will be held either on February 24 or 25 depending on the sighting of moon.

District administration has made elaborate arrangements for the devotees. Health teams are pressed into service at railway station, bus stand to control virus-related diseases in the city. This is the third year in succession in which delegation from Pakistan is not coming to attend Urs.

As per the tradition, the Gori family of Bhilwara bring flag for Urs which will be hosted at Buland Darwaza and a procession will be carried out in this regard. Thousands of devotees from India and other countries are likely to attend the event.

As part of security arrangements, 1,600 police personnel will be deputed inside dargah premises, dargah bazaar and at various resting places.

Railways is running special trains for the event.

Title: Panaji: Varsity’s Japanese course a hit, 42 sign up in one month
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: Even as Goa University ’s full-time foreign language programmes in Portuguese and French have in the recent past seen intake of students in single digits, the varsity has received an enthusiastic response for its Japanese language short-term programme announced last month.

In less than a month after the course was announced, GU has received 42 applications already, officials said.

In the past, Goa University has offered other foreign language certificate courses, but none have stirred quite an interest among Goans as the Japanese programme.

This is the first time that Goa University has announced a Japanese language course, and it is open to students of GU as well as others.

The university will soon enter into an MoU with the Japanese government, following which a Japanese tutor is expected to be provided to GU. The varsity will then begin regular Japanese language courses, which will be open to non-GU students as well, officials said.

Until the time the MoU materialises, Goa University had called for enrolment to a Japanese language certificate course. The course is being offered in association with the Japan Foundation .

The university had announced that those who successfully complete this certificate programme can expect to teach at Goa University in the near future when the Japanese teaching division eventually opens.

On completion of the level-one certificate course in Japanese, students can also work with the Japan Foundation in India or 23 other countries, the varsity had stated.

The three-and-half month programme will end on May 15. Students will be charged a fee of Rs 5,500 for the entire duration of the course.

Title: Panaji: Even students can lead yoga sessions in schools, says Directorate of education
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: The directorate of education has said that in schools where yoga teachers aren’t available, other teachers or even students with knowledge of yoga can lead daily sessions in basic exercises as part of the Fit India movement.

Deputy director of education (academics) Shailesh Zingde, however, said, that all schools from primary to higher secondary level, including special schools, should encourage their staff and students to hold daily fitness activities.

The circular states that the Fit India movement can only be a success if it becomes a people’s movement “and if physical activity is made a part of the daily routine for all classes in schools to boost fitness”. The daily fitness session should include yoga for “holistic development”, Zingde has said in the circular issued to government, government-aided and unaided institutions.

“As all of you are aware..., the Fit India school campaign is being run by the government of India in schools across the nation,” he said.

“To make physical fitness a way of life, the Fit India movement aims to make behavioural changes from sedentary lifestyle to physically active day-to-day living.”

Title: Central team visits locust-hit villages
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Jaisalmer: The inter-ministerial team on Wednesday visited villages in Ramgarh area of Jaisalmer district and took stock of damages caused by locusts.

The team led by Union agriculture ministry joint secretary Atish Chandra had DAND&F assistant commissoner Dayanand Sawant, assistant advisor, water works and sanitation, Santosh R, joint advisor Niti Aayog Manas Choudhary and additional district collector OP Vishnoi.

Farmers Kherdeen, Rramnivas and others from Kolutala gram panchayat told the team about the damage caused to jeera, isabgol and chana crops.

Similarly farmers Prahalad Sharma, Dalveer Godara, Hanuman Choudhary and others at 7DMM informed the team about the damages caused to their crops.

The team discussed with farmers and took information in detail about the losses. Social worker Govind Bhargav and others told that farmers got Rs 13,500 per hectare which was not enough to buy seeds.

Chandra assured farmers that he would give a detailed report about crop damages to the government. The team also took information about activities carried out by the Locust Control Organisation.

Title: Raj gets largest investment of Rs 4,000cr in solar sector
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Jaipur: In what will become the first largest investment in Rajasthan during the current regime of the Congress government, Central PSU NTPC and Rajasthan Solarpark Development Corporation Ltd (RSDCL), a subsidiary of RRECL, will sign an agreement on Thursday to develop 925 megawatt capacity solar power projects in Nokh Solar Park, near Jaisalmer.

As per the agreement, NTPC will develop solar PV projects in the park at an estimated investment of Rs 4,000 crore, while RSDCL will build the basic infrastructure that would require about Rs 450 crore. The park will be connected to PGCIL 765 kV Bhadla-II sub-station. TOI was the first to report on the deal on its January 8, 2020 edition.

“The agreement follows rounds of discussion between NTPC and RSDCL officials and will bring to Rajasthan the biggest investment in state’s solar power sector. The NTPC board has already approved the investment in a meeting held on February 7, 2020 and signing of the Implementation Support Agreement (ISA) will officially mark commencement of the investment inflow to state,” said Ajitabh Sharma, principal secretary, Energy and chairman of RRECL.

The park is proposed to have four projects, three of 245 MW each to be developed in EPC mode and one of 190 MW in developer mode. For power evacuation system, RSDCL will construct four park pooling substations and transmission lines for Nokh solar park. Availability of most sunny days in a year, high insolation and large tracts of government as well as private non-cultivable barren land make Rajasthan a sought-after destination for solar developers. To harness the potential, the state government has recently launched new Rajasthan Solar Energy Policy, 2019 and Rajasthan Wind and Hybrid Energy Policy, 2019, giving competitive incentives to investors.

Government is also promoting establishment of ultra mega renewable energy power parks with CPSUs and private developers.

Title: 2.7kg gold worth Rs 1.05 crore recovered from serial burglar
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Madurai: The Kanyakumari district police have arrested a 30-year-old burglar and recovered 337 sovereigns of gold jewellery worth more than Rs 1.05 crore and two stolen bikes from him. A search is on for an AIADMK functionary running a jewellery outlet who bought the stolen jewellery for a very less price.

The accused has been identified as Edwin Jose of Pullanvilai near S T Mangadu in Kanyakumari district. “He has more than 28 cases against him. This includes at least eight in Kerala and four in Tamil Nadu for which he was lodged in jail before he committed many burglaries in 2019 and 2020 for which he has been arrested now,” Thuckalay DSP M Ramachandran said.

Ramachandran said that Jose has confessed to at least 15 burglaries in Kanyakumari district after he came out of jail. The major burglaries he had committed include the ones at Silanga Jewellers in Marthandam on December 15, 2019, and Jayasri Jewellery and the house of its owner on January 28. Six special teams were formed to crack the case.

“Initially, we were not aware that he was an ex-convict. We followed the CCTV footage of the man with helmet collected from the scene of crime at various places in recent months and narrowed down on his place of stay,” the DSP said and added that they deployed police personnel at the locality for nearly 10 days to identify him and his house.

Police said that he was nabbed during a vehicle check near Marthandam on Tuesday. Police claimed that he abandoned his two-wheeler and tried to flee when he fell into a roadside pit and fractured his leg.

Explaining his modus operandi, police said that Jose used to disrobe himself whenever women were alone in the house. “When the occupants closed their eyes in disgust he made use of the opportunity to burgle the house and flee. In the two jewellery outlets, he wore a helmet to conceal his identity as there were CCTV cameras,” the DSP said. According to police, a major share of the loot was recovered from his house.

He also pledged the loot in a leading gold loan company. Jose sold around 80 sovereigns in a jewellery outlet belonging to AIADMK functionary Rameshkumar in Marthandam.

Title: Khadi board official sentenced to1-yr RI for misappropriating funds
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Puducherry: Chief judge of Puducherry P Dhanabal has convicted a 59-year-old manager of a government-run board to one-year rigorous imprisonment for criminal breach of trust and another one-year rigorous imprisonment for misappropriating government funds . Both terms will run concurrently.

The judge slapped a penalty of Rs 52,000 on Puducherry Khadi and Village Industries Board (PKVIB) manager S Rajendira Prasad, failing which he has to undergo one-month rigorous imprisonment. He also imposed a fine of Rs 1,000 on Rajendira Prasad for criminal breach of trust failing which he must undergo one-month rigorous imprisonment. According to special public prosecutor M V Ramachandramurthy, Rajendira Prasad misappropriated Rs 51,356 collected through various exhibitions-cum-sales by the board between February 4, 2009, and March 5, 2009. The vigilance and anti-corruption unit registered a case against Prasad under Section 409 (criminal breach of trust by public servant, or by banker, merchant or agent) of the IPC and Section 13 (1) (c) and 13 (2) (criminal misconduct by public servant) of the Prevention of Corruption Act after PKVIB chief executive officer M Dhinesh lodged a complaint. Prasad failed to attend duty after he was booked by the vigilance unit. TNN

Title: Panel planned for good education in private universities
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: The state government on Wednesday announced forming a regulatory commission to promote quality education in private universities and to prevent irregularities.

The minister for higher education Bhanwar Singh Bhati announced this while replying to a discussion on the functioning of private universities in the state.

Bhati said that the quality of education should be increased, fees should be controlled, and students should not be exploited. For this we promised to set up a regulatory commission.

Earlier, the committee was constituted to study the proposal for a regulatory commission, but no positive outcome. “We are studying its findings and examining the complaints of various universities and commissions of other states. He claimed that that employment opportunities have increased in the state with the establishment of private universities which invested over Rs 5000 cr and students from other states also come to Rajasthan to study.

He said the establishment of private universities has helped in increasing the ratio of higher education. We cannot point fingers at all universities, although some universities continue to receive complaints that need to be stopped. He informed that the gross enrollment ratio in Rajasthan was only 6.04 in 2004, which has increased to 23 in 2018-19. In 2004, this proportion was 7 in the Scheduled Castes category, which has now increased to 20.

The gross enrollment ratio in the Scheduled Tribes category is higher than the national average. While the national average of this class is 17.2, that of Rajasthan is 21.3. The role of private universities is important in the state's ever-increasing enrollment ratio.

Title: Kannada film to be screened free for pourakarmikas
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Mysuru: The authorities of Mysuru City Corporation (MCC), appreciating pourakarmikas for their round-the-clock effort in keeping the city clean, have decided to screen Kannada movie ‘Kaanadanthe Maayavadanu’ free for them in the city theatre.

Sharing the details during a press meet on Wednesday, MCC commissioner Gurudatta Hegde said that the movie will be screened for free at Woodlands Theatre on February 21 and 22 for pourakarmikas.

“Nearly 2,750 pourakarmikas working round-the-clock to keep the city clean will watch the movie free-of-cost. Arrangments have been made for them to watch the latest movie at 4.30 pm and 7.30 pm show,” he said.

Actor Vikas said that the movie is produced by Back Benchers Motion Picture which is running good in theatres throughout the state.

“The cinema team wanted the pourakarmikas also to share the joy and had arranged the special shows for two days. The pourakarmikas must visit the theatre with their family members but had to just show their identity cards to watch the movie,” he said.

Mayor Tasneem, deputy mayor C Sridhar, health officers D G Nagaraj and film director Raj Pathipati were present.

Title: Partially eaten carcass of tigress found in Dudhwa, ‘cannibalism’ suspected
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Bareilly: In a case of suspected “cannibalism” among tigers, a partially eaten carcass of a 10-year-old tigress was found in Kishanpur Wildlife Sanctuary of the Dudhwa Tiger Reserve on Wednesday.

Pug marks of a male tiger near the spot suggest that the male tiger may have killed her while mating and there was a fierce fight. Male tigers sometimes kill tigress when they don’t co-operate but eating the flesh is something unusual. In this case, the tiger had eaten the scruff of the neck. Last year, a case of cannibalism among tigers was reported from Kanha National Park in Madhya Pradesh. However, this is second such instance recorded in Dudhwa.

The news of carcass was initially shared by some tourists on Wednesday morning and a ranger rushed to the spot with his team. Soon, field director DTR Sanjay Pathak and others went to Kishanpur and a team of wildlife veterinarians was called for postmortem.

After reaching the spot, the field director declared “high alert” across the reserve and staff was put on patrol. Dog squad was used to confirm that poachers were not involved. Forest department also put emphasis on looking for the male tiger. Tourists were prohibited from entering the forest area as the wounded male tiger may pose a threat.

Field director DTR Sanjay Pathak told TOI, “After receiving information, principal chief conservator of forests (PCCF) Sunil Pandey and CCF Ramesh Pandey also arrived from Lucknow and an autopsy was conducted in their presence. The autopsy confirmed that it was a case of infighting and a male tiger may have also suffered injuries as the nails of the tigress had blood stains. The trachea was crushed and there were two puncture wounds of canine. Two ribs of the tigress were broken and it all points to a brutal fight.”

“Male tigers sometimes kill female ones when they don’t cooperate while mating and the act of ‘eating the flesh’ could be a result of vengeance. The incident may have occurred on Monday night as the body was 24-36 hours old and there were signs of rigor mortis,” Pathak added.

Siddharth Singh, one of the tourists who saw the carcass, said, “The carcass was found in forest’s tourism zone and tourists gathered there. Plants present at the spot were completely damaged which suggest that the fight was fierce.”

Title: Non-bailable warrant against ex-IAS officer
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: The special enforcement directorate court has sent four of the eight accused in the mining bribery case to judicial custody till March 17. At the same time, the court has issued non-bailable arrest warrant against the other four accused absconding, including former IAS Ashok Singhvi on Wednesday.

The court has sent to jail then director (mines) Pankaj Gehlot; then mines superintending engineer Pushkar Raj Ameta, Shyam Sundar Singhvi, chartered accountant, and Dhirendra Singh alias Chintu, who appeared in the court in the money laundering case registered by the ED.

The court will hear their bail application on Thursday. These four had got bail in the ACB case involving Rs 2.55 crore bribery for the reopening of a marble mine in Chittorgarh district in September 2015. The ED court issued non-bailable warrants against the other four absconding accused — former IAS Ashok Singhvi, middleman Sanjay Sethi, Rahid Sheikh and Tamanna Begum. The ACB had busted a mining racket in September 2015. After the case was pursued by the ACB, ED had initiated investigation against Sanjay Sethi and others under PMLA following an FIR filed by its Anti-Corruption Branch, Jaipur, on allegations of corruption. ED has charged Sethi and others for taking bribe.

Title: Udaipur: Teacher thrashed for misbehaving with girl in school
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

A student beats up the teacher in a government school in Udaipur

UDAIPUR: Irate students of a government senior secondary school in Udaipur district thrashed a physical training instructor (PTI) for his alleged misbehavior with a girl.

The teacher was thrashed badly in presence of over two dozen students and the case turned serious after villagers came to know of the incident. They staged a protest, locked the school gate and said they won’t let the school open until the staff is changed.

Considering the gravity of the situation, the block education officer Bheemraj Khatik visited the school and relieved few staff including an office clerk. Police was called which took away the PTI after after loding the girl’s complaint, sources said.

The incident took place at the govt senior secondary school at Chansada in Kurabad block. PTI Prem Singh Chundawat reportedly wrote ‘I love you’ in a copy and gave it to a girl of Class XII. The girl showed it to her classmates who were infuriated by the PTI’s misconduct.

The PTI is said to have misbehaved with other students on earlier occasions, too. They confronted him during school hours and thrashed him severely. Later, parents and villagers arrived at the school and staged a protest. Though the principal took action against Chundawat and relieved him to report at the headquarters, the villagers didn’t let the school open on Wednesday until the BEO arrived and spoke to them.

At the demand of the villagers, the BEO Bheemraj Khatik relieved the prinicipal, two lady teachers, a clerk. Khatik said APO action would be taken against them while an FIR too has been given.

Title: Top companies give job mela a miss
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Mysuru: The economic slowdown has affected the two-day ‘Mysuru Job Fair’ as most top companies failed to turn up for recruitment on Wednesday.

The two-day job mela is being organised for aspirants from Mysuru, Mandya and Kodagu by the respective district administrations in association with Skill Development Centre at Scouts and Guides ground. Though there was good response from the job aspirants, they were disappointed as there were no top companies and not many companies were providing offer letters on the spot.

K Jyothi, CEO, ZP, after going through the stalls set up for various companies, said they were expecting many companies to come. “Though we had approached all top companies, they didn’t turn up. Due to economic slowdown, it is said that many companies are reducing their staff,” she said. She also said that many companies select staff through campus recruitment.

The present trend in most companies is to get candidates from training centres and consultants so that they need not spend time in recruitment and expenses for providing training, she added.

She had also requested the companies to provide offer letters on the spot to the selected candidates instead of telling them to come to Bengaluru or respective places for final round. “In the next job mela, we will try to get more companies including top companies,” she said.

“Though employment exchanges keep conducting job mela almost every month, district level job mela is conducted only once in a year. There is a demand from the aspirants that district level job mela should be conducted regularly. In this regard, we will place this demand before the deputy commissioner and try to organise district level job mela once in two months,” said Jyothi.

“The job mela has failed to attract top companies and there is not much for MCom students,” said M Mega, who had come empty handed after going through job mela.

KN Nishanth, a BCom student said: “There is good opportunity. I have submitted my resume to four to five companies and they have assured me that they will get back to me in a day or two. Deaf and dumb students who had completed ITI in fitter too had come for job mela which will conclude on Thursday.”

Parimala Shyam, president zilla parishad, who inaugurated the two-day job mela, promised to write to the government to hold the job mela once in six months.

Mayor Tasneem and additional deputy commissioner BR Poornima were present.

Freshers getting only 10% posts

Over more than 150 companies who have come for the job mela, is selecting people for nearly 20,000 posts in different trades. The qualifications for the jobs range from Class X to PG which include BE, B Tech, M Tech and MBA. Some companies are giving offer letter on the spot while most of them are selecting the candidates for final round in Bengaluru. There are more than 8,000 jobs for those with ITI and diploma background while its just 300 posts for post-graduates. According to a 2020 survey, the companies are hiring just 10% freshers while 50% jobs are reserved for for those having one to four years experience.

Title: Phase VI excavation begins at Keeladi
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Madurai: Tamil Nadu chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami on Wednesday inaugurated -- through videoconferencing from Chennai -- the sixth phase of excavation at Keeladi, following which work at the site began.

The excavations at Keeladi have brought to light an ancient civilisation that flourished on the banks of the Vaigai river.

An allocation of Rs 40 lakh has been made for the first phase of this excavation and additional amount would be released as per requirement later, said sources. This would be one of the longest excavations in this ancient site and is expected to go on till the end of September this year.

Advanced technologies including LiDAR (light detection and ranging), photogrammetry, ground penetrating radar (GPR), will be used in this phase. The excavation is expected to go on simultaneously in all four villages - Keeladi, Konthagai, Manalur, and Agaram - which has been approved by the Central Advisory Board of Archaeology (CABA).

Sivaganga district collector J Jayakanthan, who was at the site for the inauguration said the district administration would provide road facilities to the four villages.

Madurai MP Su Venkatesan, joint director of the state archaeology department, R Sivanandham, excavation in-charge B Asaithambi, among others were present.

More than 15,500 artefacts have been recovered from the Keeladi site in the last five phases of excavation. The Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) conducted the first three phases from 2014-2015, 2015- 2016, 2016-2017, while the next two were done by the state archaeology department.

Though five excavations have been completed only the report of the fourth phase has been published in detail so far, which revealed that Keeladi dated back 2,600 years ago.

Title: Spl team to check illegal mining in Barmer
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Jaisalmer: To abide by the court orders to stop illegal mining of minerals and sand, their transport and storage in a sensitive district like Barmer, making partial amendment in previous orders, a special team of mines, forest, revenue, transport and police department officers has been made at the police station level.

As per the orders issued by Barmer district collector Anshdeep, the in-charge of the special investigation team will be the concerned SDO. The team will take effective action to stop illegal mining, transportation and storage. He said at district and at each SDO office level, a register will be maintained for illegal mining, transportation and storage in which complaints will be filed and report of action will be filed.

Title: Smart City: BMC to start work on six projects by March-end
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

A smart city project team gives presentation at a meeting held at a divisional commissioner's office in Bareil... Read More

BAREILLY: Bareilly Municipal Corporation (BMC) authorities have set March deadline to commence at least six projects under the Smart City after receiving a budgetary allocation of Rs 60 crore to begin with the projects before the end of the current fiscal.

The projects are likely to come up at an estimated cost of around Rs 250 crore, according to BMC officials.

During a meeting with a Smart City team in Bareilly on Tuesday, divisional commissioner and chairman of the Bareilly Smart City project Ranvir Prasad said, “As many as six projects will be taken up by March, the tendering process for which has been completed successfully.”

Speaking to TOI, Bareilly municipal commissioner Abhishek Anand said, “Several projects need to be taken up to develop Bareilly as a Smart City. However, six projects have been finalised, so far, and the e-tendering process has also been completed. The six projects include development of integrated command and control centre, development of handicraft promotion centre, renovation of Sanjay Community hall and swimming pool, e-kiosk, waste transfer station and development of ‘She’ lounges. The estimated cost of the projects is around Rs 250 crore.”

“We have set March deadline after receiving an instalment of Rs 60 crore under the Smart City. The work of developing open gyms at public parks, installation of LED streetlights and musical fountains is under process. We hope to start the projects before the deadline,” said Anand.

Divulging details of a few finalised projects, the municipal commissioner said, “Handicraft promotion centre will create job opportunities in the city. Besides, e-kiosks will be set up in six different wards to give an organised look to markets and do away with encroachment. Also, ‘She’ lounges will be developed specifically for women who will be provided facilities such as food counters, waiting rooms, sanitary napkin vending machines and washrooms.”

Other projects under the Smart City include —installation of solar rooftops on 17 government buildings, water ATMs, multi-level vehicle parking, underground vehicle parking, renovation of prominent city junctions and improving road network, road signage, solid waste management across 80 wards, development of vertical gardens, settlement of smart classes equipped with digital learning tools in government schools, digital library, renovation of swimming pools and a stadium, among others.

Title: Nagpur: BSc student caught writing HSC exam for friend
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Representative image

NAGPUR: Vigilant invigilators at a centre of HSC exam on Tuesday booked a BSc student who was appearing for the exam for his friend. The BSc student had changed the photo on the hall ticket of the friend to evade being caught.

Bajaj Nagar police have registered a case of fraud against the HSC candidate and his friend. The accused have been identified as Rahul Bagde and his friend Vinay Maurya, both 20 and residents of Bhim Nagar.

According to police, the actual candidate was Maurya and as his sister was getting married in Uttar Pradesh , he wanted to attend the wedding. He asked Rahul, a third year BSc student, to appear for his English paper scheduled for February 18.

Maurya’s centre for exam was Nutan Bharat Junior College. Maurya and Rahul made a fake hall ticket with latter’s photo and also took its colour printout.

While Maurya left for UP for wedding, Rahul went to the centre to appear in the exam. While checking hall tickets, invigilators suspected something fishy. While taking signatures of candidates, invigilators spotted difference in photo on the hall ticket and one on list of students.

Invigilator then informed Bajaj Nagar police about the dummy candidate appearing in the exam. During questioning, Rahul revealed his real name and also told cops he was impersonating Maurya as latter was attending his sister’s wedding.

Senior PI of Bajaj Nagar police station RA Kshirsagar said, “We have not arrested the BSc student or the HSC candidate as he is out of station. We have given a notice to the BSc student regarding the incident and a probing further.”

Title: Narayanasamy asks police to end ganja menace in Pondy
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Puducherry: Regretting that even school students , including girls in Puducherry , have started using ganja, chief minister V Narayanasamy said he has directed police to unearth the source of supply of the contraband and initiate concrete measures to curtail the drug menace in the territory.

He was speaking at the inaugural of a two-day capacity building programme on drug abuse prevention for school teachers, organised by the state social welfare board in association with the national institute of social defence, Union social justice and empowerment ministry on Wednesday.

Narayanasamy went on to the extent of saying that a woman anti-social in Tiruvannamalai remains the main source of ganja that reaches Puducherry by train. Ganja peddlers in Puducherry, on receiving the contraband, use children to sell it in small sachets to tourists who gather at popular landmarks and to shops near schools and colleges.

He said he has directed the director-general of police to send a team to Tiruvannamalai to identify the source of the contraband and initiate stringent action to eradicate the menace. He regretted that police fail to maintain a constant vigil on peddlers despite his repeated directions.

“Once in three months, a meeting is convened with top police officers. We instruct them to keep constant vigil and prevent peddling of ganja into Puducherry. Police initiate action and after two days do not keep up the vigil,” Narayanasamy said.

He said the government cannot enforce total prohibition as it depends on the revenue generated through liquor sales but quickly added that the government will initiate efforts to reduce the sale of alcoholic beverages in a phased manner in Puducherry.

The chief minister said that repeated efforts to secure more financial assistance from the Union government have not yielded any positive results. “The Union government extends 42% financial grants to Tamil Nadu, but provides just 26% for Puducherry. Earlier, we used to get grants close to 70%. I called on the Prime Minister and other ministers seeking additional assistance, but nothing has materialised so far,” he said.

Narayanasamy appealed to the social welfare department to rise to the occasion and spearhead campaigns to create awareness among people on the ill-effects of use drug abuse. He also appealed to all sections of society to lend a helping hand to the government to transform Puducherry into a drug-free territory. “It is the primary duty of the government to ensure a drug-free society, but teachers and parents play a significant role,” he said.

Title: Goa University's accreditation by national council slotted for July-August
Content:
Goa university

PANAJI: The accreditation process of Goa University (GU) by the National Assessment and Accreditation Council ( NAAC ) is expected to take place in July-August this year, GU officials said.The state’s lone university was granted A grade during its last accreditation cycle by NAAC, results for which were announced in September 2014. The five-year validity of the last accreditation ended in September 2019.The reevaluation is now taking place in the monsoon of 2020, late by a whole year since validity of the last accreditation ended. This is because the Goa University itself had written to the state government last year that it wants to postpone the accreditation process.The GU is currently in the process of filling up its vacant faculty positions and the university does not want to apply for reassessment by NAAC before the posts are filled, as it may lead to the university losing out points.Over the last five years, a lot has changed with the NAAC assessment process.“NAAC has altered its accreditation process. Earlier, a lot depended on the NAAC peer team’s visit, where they inspected facilities and interacted with students, faculty and parents of students. Now, the peer team’s visit will carry only 30% weightage. NAAC has given 70% weightage now to purely quantitative assessment, like the qualifications of teachers, the number of teachers working on permanent basis, etc,” explained an official.“If GU had to apply for NAAC accreditation, before its vacant posts were filled, its grade would slide,”the official added.GU currently has close to 50% of its posts lying vacant and the process of filling up these positions is on.Once the university fills up its posts, it will submit its self-study report to NAAC, following which the peer team’s visit will be fixed and then the accreditation will be awarded.In 2014, Goa University had finally managed to shed its ‘B’ grade and upgrade itself to an ‘A’ grade.The Union HRD ministry has now changed the categories of grading for NAAC by introducing catergorisations like A1, A2, AC1, AC2 and so on, with A1 being the highest grade.

Title: Police block anti-CAA march to collector office
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Madurai: Tension prevailed in the city as more than 1,000 people including 200 women, predominantly from the Muslim community, who gathered at Tamil Sangam Building started marching on Dr Thangaraj Road towards Madurai district collector office demanding the state government to pass a resolution stating that the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), National Population Register (NPR) and National Register of Citizens (NRC) will not be implemented.

A large number of policemen were deployed at various pockets in the city. Policemen wearing protective gears were deployed at vantage points. The entire area around the collectorate was brought under police control. Police have put up barricades in at least six spots on Dr Thangaraj Road. Madurai city police commissioner S Davidson Devasirvatham supervised the security arrangements. Higher officials including deputy commissioners of police E Karthick (law and order), K Sugumaran (traffic) and K Palanikumar coordinated security measure.

The crowd gathered at Tamil Sangam Building started marching towards the collector office at 11 am. But police stopped the march immediately near Madurai corporation swimming pool and warned the protestors not to move beyond it as the march was not permitted by police.

Leaders of Jamaat Ul Ulama Sabai, who organized the protest, addressed the gathering. They said that a delegation will meet the district collector and hand over a petition. They asked the gathering to leave the place without creating any law and order issue. A section of people was reluctant to leave and sat on the road for some time. However, after a few Ulama members spoke, they started leaving the place peacefully.

An elderly person, who brought a can full of kerosene, doused himself with kerosene. One of the protestors, Syed Ahamed Basha, said, “We stopped him and asked him to leave the place at once after warning him not to take part in other protests.”

Meanwhile, the protest at Mahaboobpalayam continued for the sixth consecutive day on Wednesday. The protest at Nelpettai also continued for the third day.

Similar protests were staged in all the southern districts including Tuticorin, Tirunelveli, Tenkasi and Kanyakumari. A large number of police personnel were deployed at each protest venue.

Title: Jaisalmer cops launch drive, seize five trucks carrying illegal ‘bajri’
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Representative image

JAISALMER: Jaisalmer Police have caught five dumpers filled with gravel without challan. These dumpers were involved in road construction in Bharat Mala Project.

To abide by the court orders to stop illegal mining of minerals and sand, its transport and storage in sensitive district like Barmer & Jaisalmer making partial amendment in previous orders a special team of mine, forest, revenue, transport and police department officer has been made at the police station level.

Jaisalmer Police team has also launched campaign to stop illegal mining. In this sequence, police while patrolling at PTM Circle have caught five dumpers filled with illegally mined gravel. One Dumper had no receipt and four dumpers had three times gravel than the receipt taken for. Mining department was informed about it and dumpers were seized at Nehdai Police station. They are leading to loss of crores to government.

Title: Panaji: No discrepancies in rates charged, says mayor Uday Madkaikar
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

PANAJI: There is no discrepancy between pay -parking rates notified by the North Goa collector and the fees being charged by the pay parking contractor, Corporation of the City of Panaji (CCP) mayor Uday Madkaikar said on Wednesday.

Madkaikar said that certain mischievous elements were circulating an old notification issued by the North Goa collector to try and mislead people. “There is a revised notification issued based on which the pay parking fees are charged,” he said.

CCP commissioner Sanjit Rodrigues also said that local residents who stay near the stretches where pay-parking has been implemented are not being charged to park their vehicles.“Traffic movement has improved after pay-parking began. At least 25-30 slots where tourist taxis were parked have opened up,” Rodrigues said. He also said that the CCP is now looking at phase II of the pay parking system. “It is a staggered decision. There is a plan in place,” he said.

Title: IIT Powai exposes excess billing scam in MSEDCL
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Representative image

Nagpur: Even as MSEDCL is grappling with the revelations of the report of Maharashtra Electricity Regulatory Commission ’s (MERC’s) working group on agricultural power consumption, TOI has got hold of a report prepared by IIT Powai that had exposed excess billing by the discom in 2017.

According to IIT Powai’s study, agricultural power consumption in the state is only around 55% of that claimed by MSEDCL. This implies that MSEDCL has indulged in jugglery of thousands of crores in the last fifteen to twenty years.

When Chandrashekhar Bawankule of BJP became the energy minister, he received several complaints of excess billing of farmers. He had constituted a fact-finding committee in July 2015 to look into the complaints. The committee asked IIT Powai to determine the consumption by doing a survey across the state. The committee was headed by MSEB Holding Company director Vishwas Pathak and had power experts Pratap Hogade and Ashish Chandarana as members. MSEDCL is governed by the Holding Company.

The revelations of IIT’s study were so damaging that Pathak refused to sign the report of the fact finding committee. The report was submitted to the Holding Company in July 2017 with the signature of only Hogade and Chandarana. The Company has not taken any action on the report since then.

Pathak admitted that he had refused to sign the report. “Hogade and Chandarana were more interested in publicity. They refused to take into account the positive things being done by MSEDCL by using technology. I therefore prepared a separate report and submitted it to the Holding Company. Mine was accepted while theirs was rejected,” he told TOI. He, however, accepted that the Company had not acted on his report too.

Bawankule refused to comment on why no action was taken on the report despite repeated calls and text messages for three days. Incumbent energy minister Nitin Raut said that he was not aware of the existence of the report.

The committee in its report concluded that the estimated agriculture power sale was 15,093 million units (MU) against 25,685 MU (58.76%) reported for 14-15 by MSEDCL and 14,973 MU against 27,505 MU (54.43%) reported for 2015-16.

IIT’s figure is on the higher side, which is evident from the assumptions made by it. IIT calculated low tension (LT) distribution loss at 23% but considered 25% for the sake of calculations. It states that agricultural feeders get power for 8 to 10 hours a day but 12 hours was being considered. It has been assumed that agricultural pumps work for 300 days a year. This assumption is fallacious as pumps work for 300 days only in irrigated areas. Most of the state has dryland agriculture where the third crop is not possible due to unavailability of water. If these factors are taken into account, MSEDCL’s inflation of sales figures is higher than that calculated by IIT.

Hogade alleged that MSEDCL indulged in this jugglery to conceal its massive failure in curbing power theft. “Had MSEDCL actually brought down distribution loss to 15%, our power tariff would have been considerably lower,” he told TOI.

The fact finding committee had recommended that “Considering the higher percentage of losses observed by the IIT and the committee, it is necessary that any unauthorized use of power and theft of power should be strictly prohibited and should be treated strictly in accordance with the law. The committee recommends that the regular theft detection drive should be taken by the MSEDCL to reduce the losses on this account.”

The committee also stated that “For the purpose of tariff hike petitions, agricultural connected load as per MSEDCL data is considered. Attempting to justify higher consumption hours, high unauthorized and illegal load under the ambit of agricultural sales and thereby claiming direct subsidy from state government and cross subsidy from the rest of the subsidizing consumers is unfair and unlawful practice. In our view, it needs to be avoided and stopped fully within minimum possible period. Appropriate authority can take suitable decision in this regard.”

IIT Powai has observed in its report that MSEDCL’s method of estimating agricultural power consumption has been faulty right from the beginning. “There has been no convergence over the years to a reliable methodology to calculate agricultural consumption. The method followed by the Commission in 2006-07 had already thrown up very unreliable metering data. The current situation may be worse as observed from the preliminary field data and from some analysis of metering data of Nasik and Aurangabad zones.”

Title: Rajastan News: Two youths thrashed for theft in Nagaur, videos go viral
Content:
A screengrab from the video

The recent video of two young Dalit men being brutally tortured in Nagaur, Rajasthan is horrific & sickening. I urg… https://t.co/OlDnTpWaWf — Rahul Gandhi (@RahulGandhi) 1582185110000

In the horrific incident in Nagaur, immediate and effective action has been taken and seven accused have been arres… https://t.co/ZR74fjmysl — Ashok Gehlot (@ashokgehlot51) 1582188014000

JAIPUR: Two persons were beaten up for alleged theft in Panchaudi police station area on Nagaur. A series of six videos went viral in which the tormentors were seen applying petrol with a screwdriver on the private part of one of the two persons.The incident took place on Sunday but the FIRs were registered on Wednesday. The plight is that almost three days after the incident, the FIRs were registered in the case.According to police, the victims registered an FIR on Wednesday against seven persons who thrashed them and tortured them.The police registered an FIR under Section 323 (for voluntarily causing hurt), Section 342 (for wrongful confinement), Section 143 (unlawful assembly) of the IPC and under various other sections under the Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes (Prevention of Atrocities) Act.However, Bhim Singh, Jasu Singh and Sawai Singh and others, who are purportedly seen beating the two persons, filed an FIR against the two accused for stealing Rs 50,000 under Section 380 (theft) of the IPC.The police have not yet made any arrest in the matter. The police said that they have started investigating into the matter as complaints were registered only on Wednesday. “The incident happened in Karnu village when workers in a motorbike agency allegedly caught two accused on charge of theft,” said Rajpal Singh , station house officer, Panchaudi. The police said that the two are fine and they are not hospitalised.Those beating the two persons, pulled his pants down of one of them and one person was seen holding a screwdriver dipping it in a bottle of petrol and applying it on his private part. He is seen crying in pain and begging them to stop.The two of them are seen begging to them to let them go. One video shows that one of the two went unconscious after he was beaten up badly with belts. They poured water with a jug on his face and on the body for regaining his consciousness. One of the group, put his foot on his knees and tried to stand on his knees. They also checked their pockets. Sound of laughing is also captured in the video while the two were being tortured. The police said that they are investigating into the matter.In Video: 2 youths brutally thrashed, tortured for alleged theft in Rajasthan’s Nagaur as video goes viral

Title: 1 more Indian on Japanese ship tests positive for COVID-19
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Madurai: The Indian embassy in Tokyo has confirmed that one more Indian crew on board quarantined ship Diamond Princess at Yokohama in Japan has tested positive for COVID-19. The cruise ship management said that more countries have airlifted their citizens – passengers and crew members – from the ship on Wednesday.

One Indian crew who tested positive for COVID-19 is among the 88 new cases identified on Tuesday. They have been taken to a hospital for treatment, reads a tweet by the Indian Embassy in Japan. This takes the total Indians on board the ship getting treated after testing positive for COVID-19 to seven, till 9pm (Japan time) on Wednesday and that their health condition is improving. The embassy added that disembarkation of passengers has started and is likely to continue till February 21.

The embassy is yet to respond to queries on the number of Indian crew members who had expressed their interest in prematurely ending the 14-day mandatory quarantine that began on February 19. “Countries have already started airlifting their citizens from the ship. We have been waiting for the government of India to fly us home. It’s been three days since the US evacuated their citizens and three days since we filled the forms given by the Indian embassy asking our willingness to prematurely leave the ship,” said Anbalagan, 41, a crew member from Madurai.

On Wednesday, the crew was given forms asking whether they had any symptoms of COVID-19. “We were informed that swab samples will be collected from us on Thursday. We are in fear that the delay in evacuation could lead to every one of us getting infected. Whenever a country evacuates their citizens, we hope that the government of India will be next,” he said. Princess Cruises, the operator of Diamond Princess, on their official website confirmed that that the embassies of Canada, Australia and Hong Kong are coordinating the evacuation of their guests and crew via chartered flights on Wednesday. It said that according to Japanese ministry of health, the disembarkation process for individuals who are not taking government repatriation flights will start on Wednesday.

“The disembarkation process will take several days, since they will be tested, and the testing and results require two to three days to complete,” it stated. An internal communication from Susan Coskey, senior vice-president of HR-global fleet operations, to the crew members on Wednesday stated that they are of the understanding that most (if not all) teammates will have to undergo a minimum of 14 days additional quarantine once guests have disembarked. They are in discussion with the Japanese government on where and how it will take place, including whether this will be on the ship or ashore.

“An increasing number of governments are arranging charter air travel for their citizens to complete their quarantine periods in their home countries. This includes New Zealand, Hong Kong, India, Philippines, South Korea, Indonesia, Italy/European Union and United Kingdom (as a second flight),” she added. Delay in evacuating the crew members has left the families of the five from Tamil Nadu worried as they were expecting to fly home any time.

Title: Two, including woman, 50, held for peddling marijuana
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Tiruvannamalai: The Tiruvannamalai police on Wednesday arrested two people, including a 50-year-old woman , for peddling marijuana and seized about 1.5 kg of the contraband from them.

A senior police officer said that acting to a tip received by Tiruvannamalai district SP M R Cibi Chakravarthi that a woman was involved in peddling marijuana in the rural and suburban areas of the district, a special police team was formed to nab her. On Wednesday morning, the team led by inspector Barathi, while conducting a search at an isolated spot at Chinnamayanpettai near Thanipadi arrested a woman who had marijuana in her possession. Investigation revealed that the woman was Vasantha of Thanipadi. Police seized about 1 kg of marijuana from her.

Similarly, the Tiruvannamalai town police headed by sub-inspector Sambasivam, while on patrol at Singamuga Theertham, detained a man on suspicion.

Preliminary inquiry revealed that the man was Sugisivam alias Surendar, 22, of Mariamman Temple Street in Tiruvannamalai. He confessed to peddling rectified spirit and marijuana for the past one year. Police arrested him and confiscated 10 litres of rectified spirit and 500 grams of marijuana. They are conducting an investigation.

Title: Panaji: Juveniles who fled Apna Ghar traced within hours
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

the state protective home Apna Ghar (file photo)

PANAJI: The six juveniles, who had escaped from the state protective home Apna Ghar late Tuesday night, were found by police in the early hours of Wednesday and have been lodged at the home again. While three of the boys were found hiding at a construction site on the Kadamba Plateau, the other three were traced to Karmali Railway Station.

The six were planning to board a train to Mumbai, sub-divisional police officer, North Goa, Uttam Raut Dessai said.

Officials, however, said that another juvenile, who had escaped from Apna Ghar earlier this month, remains untraceable.

“At 10.30pm on Tuesday, the matron of Apna Ghar, Esperanca Menezes, called the PCR to inform that six juveniles had managed to escape from the Merces facility, at around 9.45pm. PI KP Sinari, along with his staff, rushed to Apna Ghar. He noticed that the juveniles had tied bedsheets together to climb into the CWC section of the home. They then escaped through the windows by removing the grilles and later scaled the home’s compound wall,” Dessai said. He said that the window grilles had been dislodged by the juveniles with their bare hands.

They also jammed the locks of the dormitory, locking the caretakers inside, Dessai said.

Police personnel were then deployed to search for the juveniles. A thorough search was conducted, wherein three of the juveniles were spotted near Gera School, hiding at an under-construction site. It was learnt from the three that the six planned to flee to Mumbai by train from Karmali Railway Station. Accordingly, the other three juveniles were caught trying to board the train.

“When I visited Apna Ghar, I found that there was no proper illumination around the premises, which helps the juveniles escape onto the road without being noticed. This needs to be attended to,” said Dessai. Several of the six juveniles who tried to run away were involved in a cheating case in Calangute , and have been lodged at Apna Ghar for more than six months now.

The other juvenile who had escaped from Apna Ghar earlier and remains untraceable, managed to flee while being taken to court.

Title: Panaji: Panchayats minister Mauvin Godinhsays, SEC will finalise reservation of zilla seats
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

panchayats minister Mauvin Godinho

PANAJI: Following criticism by the opposition that the government has been delaying the reservation of wards for the zilla panchayat elections scheduled for March 22, panchayats minister Mauvin Godinho on Wednesday, said that he has already cleared the file pertaining to reservation of wards.

“I cleared the file long ago and handed it over to the State Election Commission (SEC). No file is pending with me, whether it is about ZP election reservations or date of the election,” said Godinho while responding to media queries.

Both, the reservation of wards and programme for conducting the elections, Godinho said, will have to be decided by the SEC.

Godinho however, declined to comment when pointed out that the SEC has stated that it is yet to receive the file concerned. “I cannot say anything on their statement,” he said.

Earlier, the BJP-led government was also questioned over delays in announcing the ZP election date.

The government had hinted that ZP elections would be held in mid-March. Recently, chief minister Pramod Sawant said the election will be held on March 22.

It was speculated that the delay in announcing the ZP polls was due to the time taken in deciding a favorable reservation for the ruling party.

Though BJP enjoys a brute majority in the House of 40 representatves, the ZP election results will reflect the mood of the people towards it, a year ahead of the state assembly elections. The ZP elections will be fought on party lines

Title: Panaji: Two held for smuggling khair wood
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: The forest department has arrested two persons in separate incidents for alleged smuggling of khair wood , which has been seized along with the vehicles used for transportation.

Udai Sadu Gawas, a native of Dodamarg, Maharashtra was arrested by the range forest officer (RFO), Vivek Gaonkar and his team while transporting 36 khair wood logs in a van at Gullem Morlem Sattari late evening, on February 12. Forest officials said that Gawas had cut trees in the Harvalem communidade property for the logs.

On February 17, Damodar Nagvekar from Korgao, Pernem was arrested with 47 khair wood logs and one bag of khair wood chips at Agarwada, Pernem by Tukaram Kharbe, from the RFO mobile squad, while transporting the wood. The illegal cutting was carried out in a private property at Sodiem, Siolim. Forest officials said that in 2019, Nagvekar was arrested in a similar case. “The forest protection squad is well equipped and alert to check such offences,” said deputy conservator of forests North Goa, Kuldeep Sharma. The wood has a huge market value in adjoining Sawantwadi taluka of Maharashtra for ‘kattha’ making.

The forest department has carried out similar seizure operations in the past.

Title: Many cops due for promotion: NCP to Goa CM Pramod Sawant
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

chief minister Pramod Sawant

PANAJI: Nationalist Congress Party ( NCP ) on Wednesday urged chief minister Pramod Sawant to promote police inspectors, constables and police sub-inspectors awaiting their turn for more than 10 years.

“When MLAs work hard, they get promotions from the party and are made ministers. But our policemen who have worked hard can’t get promoted. For 10 to 15 years, police inspectors are waiting for promotion as deputy superintendent of police (DySP),” said state NCP general secretary Sanjay Barde.

He said that several policemen are nearing the age of retirement but have remained in the same post without promotion.

NCP also warned transport minister Mauvin Godinho of trying to regularise illegal homes of non-Goans in Chicalim comunidade property.

The party warned Godinho of an agitation if he went ahead with his plan.

The state NCP general secretary also criticised ports minister Michael Lobo for suggesting that casinos could be introduced in Chapora and Zuari rivers to bring in more revenue for the government.

Title: Nine-years after Panchkula realtor’s murder, court indicts SIT for shoddy probe
Content:
Representative image

CHANDIGARH: More than nine years after a 26-year-old realtor of Panchkula was tied up with an iron chain, locked inside his car and the vehicle set ablaze, a trial court has acquitted all the accused of his murder and indicted the special investigation team (SIT) for a poor probe.The SIT, which was led by Harmeet Singh, PPS, had conducted only a “formal investigation,” and brought no concrete evidence, according to the court.The 90-page verdict released on Tuesday evening said the police failed to probe Sajni, with whom Suresh Kumar, the victim, was alleged to be having an affair. Even Sajni’s sister Rajni as well as Neelam, whose phone had allegedly been used by Sajni to call Suresh, had not been examined by the prosecution, the court observed.“The police had failed to investigate and find the facts as disclosed by accused Raj Kumar and Mohinder Pal during their brain mapping tests. No efforts were made to obtain evidence about a contract killing and to trace Mohna Baba (the alleged contract killer), if any,” the court observed.Highlighting further loopholes in the investigation, the trial court of Monika Goyal, additional sessions court, Mohali, observed that the police did not try to trace the scattered glasses of the car, to find out if the accused had beaten Suresh at one place or not or only taken him to Baddi-Siswan road to burn him along with his car.“Apart from the results of tests (polygraph), no other corroborative evidence was brought on record. The results of the tests can only lead to suspicion of the involvement of the accused in the crime, but do not prove the case of prosecution beyond reasonable doubt. Moreover, no brain mapping and polygraph test of accused Gurwinder Singh, Harjinder Singh and Kamal Kumar were conducted,” the trial judge observed in her orders.The court said the prosecution had failed to trace call details and route of Suresh through his mobile and not enquired about his friends with whom he had gone to watch a movie on the fateful night.On November 26, 2010, the burnt body of Suresh, a resident of Mansa Devi complex Panchkula, was found in his car near Siswan village on the Mullanpur-Baddi highway. His body was beyond recognition and identified only from the partly-burnt number plate of his car. He was running a real estate business from Kharar. When the police had failed to crack the case for a year, the victim’s cousin, Davinder Lubana, had moved the Punjab and Haryana high court in 2011 for a CBI probe after which the case was handed over to a SIT of Punjab Police .

Title: 3 dead in blast at fire cracker unit
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Virudhunagar: Three workers, including a minor died and six others suffered injuries in a blast at a firecracker manufacturing unit at Chinnakamanpatti in Virudhunagar district on Wednesday. The blast happened when workers were loading crackers onto a vehicle.

A spark from the vehicle spread to the cracker manufacturing unit. Three chambers were damaged in the blast, leaving two people dead on the spot and injuring seven others. One of the injured died later.

The deceased have been identified as E Pandiarajan, 28, and P Karthick, 17, of Meenampatti and P Vellaisamy, 60, of Paraipatti.

Six people including Valliammal, Muthulakshmi, Lakshmanan, Murugan and Vijayakumar were shifted to the Sivakasi hospital. Since the condition of four of them was critical, they were shifted to the Government Rajaji Hospital in Madurai.

Police sources said that cracker production work started in the factory at the usual time. It is suspected that the source of the fire could be the vehicle. On being alerted, fire and rescue services personnel from Vembakottai rushed to the spot. The Sattur police registered a case.

Title: SC directs state govt tostop illegal sand mining
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

New Delhi: The Supreme Court on Wednesday ordered state district collectors and superintendents of police to take immediate steps to stop massive illegal sand mining in Rajasthan and ordered the Central Empowered Committee (CEC) to probe allegations that the sand mafia is having a free run in the state.

The order came after state government’s additional advocate general Manish Singhvi confirmed fears of petitioner Navin Sharma that illegal mining was rampant in the state despite SC orders. Singhvi said that against an annual demand for sand of around 70 million tonnes, only 2 million tonnes were being produced by those having leases currently.

“Naturally, there will be rampant illegal sand mining. So, please vacate the stay on grant of new leases by the state. When there is huge demand for sand and so little is being produced legally, it will lead to illegal mining. This will result in a loss of revenue for the state and create a law and order situation,” he told a bench of Chief Justice S A Bobde and justices B R Gavai and Surya Kant.

After ordering the state government, collectors and SPs to immediately stop illegal sand mining, the bench asked the CEC to carry out a detailed investigation into the issue and the allegation that the sand mafia was having a free run. It empowered the CEC to summon any government officer, examine records and asked it to submit a report with recommendations in six weeks.

“We find that it is not disputed by anyone, including the state government, that illegal sand mining is rampant in Rajasthan. This cannot be allowed to continue. We direct the Rajasthan government and collector and SP of each district in Rajasthan to take immediate steps for stopping illegal sand mining as there is no doubt that such unbridled sand mining is likely to damage the environment irreparably,” the bench said.

Appearing for NGO ‘Dastak’, senior advocate Vikas Singh said to circumvent the rule that requires environment clearance for mining in over five acres of land, the state government had devised an ingenious way out by leasing four acres of land on flood plains which does not require a green nod.

The court asked the CEC to hear representatives of the state government, the ministry of environment and forests, petitioner Navin Sharma, NGO ‘Dastak and all stakeholders before finalising its report.

Title: HC bells big CAT delay, asks date of landing at airport
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Chandigarh: The Punjab and Haryana High court on Wednesday directed all stakeholders to categorically file an affidavit stating clearly by when the Chandigarh international airport will be CAT-III enabled, observing that an airport does not become international by merely naming it one.

The CAT III-B Instrument Landing System (ILS) allows flights to land safely in low visibility of 50 metres. It lets aircraft land with runway visual range (RVR) of up to 50m with a decision height of 15m.

The court pointed out that due to visibility issues in Chandigarh, even the Chief Justice of India could not reach the city on time as his flight was delayed by 2 hours. The court said it should be informed whether CAT-III installation is possible or not, directing the amicus curiae to file a report mentioning the exact situation after consulting all the stakeholders. The court further observed that even after spending Rs 2,000 crore in five years, the airport does not have all the facilities and international operators are shirking away from operating from here.

The court was informed that the installation of CAT-III will be done in a phased manner and it is not possible immediately as certain defence installations have to be removed. CAT-I approach lights will be installed on the runway by AAI at the earliest and upgradation to CAT-II and CAT-III undertaken, the court was told.

Puneet Bali, the counsel for petitioner Mohali Industries Association, responded that the airport has not become CAT-III enabled even after spending Rs 2,000 crore. He said what to talk of CAT-III, the airport is not even fully equipped with CAT-II, the reason behind international operators staying away. He accused the “hotel lobby” of working behind the scenes.

“Someone should be prosecuted and an inquiry marked to the CBI to find out why even after five years of operation, the airport is not equipped with CAT-II and CAT-III,” Bali said. “There is someone behind the scene who is playing the ball,” he alleged. Assistant Solicitor General of India Chetan Mittal refuted all the charges, saying extra efforts have been made to make the airport CAT-II and CAT-III ready. “It is painful to hear that despite serious efforts, charges have been levelled by the advocate,” he said.

The court observed if operational issues, like the defence airport being near, were one of the causes, then Chandigarh should not have been made an international airport. “There were so many other airports in Punjab, like Ludhiana, that could have been chosen and made international,” the court said.

Mittal, however, claimed not a single flight was diverted because of visibility. To this, the court cited the recent delay in the flight of the Chief Justice of India.

Mittal said even if the airport is CAT-II enabled, a lot depends on the skills of the pilot to take off or land during low visibility. The court then said just naming an airport international does not make it one; international flights are required to take-off or land her. The court pointed out that that if the issue of visibility can be solved in Amritsar airport, then why not in Chandigarh?

OBSERVATIONS

Just naming an airport international does not make it one

Even after spending Rs 2,000 crore in five years, the airport does not have all the facilities and international operators are shirking away from operating from here

If operational issues are the reasons behind the delay, Chandigarh should not have been made an international airport

Open Sky policy

A meeting of senior representative of Punjab, Haryana, Airport Authority of India and CHIAL concluded that addition, deletion or substitution in the list of 18 tourist destination will not be advisable and instead it will be better to encourage Indian carriers to start international flights from Chandigarh. It was observed that designated airlines of the US and UK had access to any point in India and they can undertake operations to Chandigarh

GoAir for Thailand

The high court was informed that private airlines GoAir has shown interest in starting a flight between Chandigarh and Thailand. It was agreed that CHIAL would do everything possible to facilitate commencement of such flights by GO air. All other airlines said international flights from Chandigarh will not be commercially viable due to inadequate traffic

Air India response

Air India stated that it was providing good international connectivity to Chandigarh by its hub-and-spoke operation

Title: Four more held in fake licence case
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Madurai: The city crime branch (CCB) police have arrested four more people in connection with the issue of fake driving licence and batch from Madurai North RTO office. Police officials said that so far 16 people have been arrested in the case, which was registered in August, 2019.

A CCB official said the four have been identified as Soundarasubbiah, contract employee engaged through a private company for the online facility, driving school owners Pandiarajan and Muthuraman from Madurai and broker Abbas. They have been remanded in prison on Tuesday.

In March, last year a message spread on WhatsApp promising to get driving licence for two-wheelers, cars, heavy vehicles and batches within three days without any test. A phone number was also provided in the message. Applicants have to provide their Aadhaar, blood group details and phone number, the message had stated, police said.

There were copies of a few licences attached to the message, which were purportedly obtained by the brokers, circumventing mandatory procedures required to get a licence including a test.

The shocked regional transport office (RTO) officials and employees checked with their repository using the details found on the licence copies and found that they were not recorded in their database. However, when the officials further checked, it was found that the licences were issues through Sarathi Parivahan online facility, which was meant for replacing missing licences, police said.

Title: Panaji: Elvis Gomes says, Delhi polls prove Modi-Shah not invincible
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Elvis gomes

PANAJI: Aam Aadmi Party said on Monday that the party’s decisive victory in Delhi has proved that good governance and work can win elections, and that the Narendra Modi-Amit Shah duo was not invincible. The party said that it was working on a similar roadmap for Goa.

The party said it would contest the upcoming Zilla Panchayat elections, and had begun the process to select probable candidates for certain seats.

“AAP has shown that Modi and Shah are not invincible. We will try to implement a similar roadmap here in Goa,” said Elvis Gomes .

Arvind Kejriwal led AAP to a massive victory for the second time in the Delhi assembly polls, dealing a body blow to BJP and completely decimating the Congress. Gomes, who attended the swearing-in ceremony in New Delhi, is counting on the victory to give the party a boost in Goa too.

“Our political ideology is work, and that is what we promise — to give everyone basic necessities. The common man in Delhi is happy with AAP’s victory. We will try to capitalise on this in Goa,” said Gomes.

Gomes also questioned the state government’s “anti-people” policies and criticised chief minister Pramod Sawant for coming out with policies that were not adequately studied.

“At every stage, the Goa government flounders. It looks like there is no foundation behind the policies of this government. Over the past few days, three decisions were reversed. Who is running this government? Don’t they have any vision?” said Gomes.

Asked about the party’s preparations for the upcoming ZP elections, Gomes said that AAP had already started its preliminary work. “If I have to fight the elections, how do I know if a particular seat is reserved or not. The State Election Commission is favouring BJP and keeping them informed about which seats are reserved. What is the use of conducting elections?” Gomes asked.

Title: Haphazard parking on city roads a major menace to commuters
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Madurai: Many important roads in the city, like the Panagal Road where the Government Rajaji Hospital is situated have become congested due to haphazard parking of vehicles.

Wide roads have been divided in a move to reduce accidents in many parts of the city. This is helping to some extent. But, as people park their cars and two-wheelers on both sides of the roads it causes heavy traffic congestion during the peak hours. “Police only take note of rickshaws, autos and cycles parked on the road, but if it is a luxury car they are not questioned,” said an auto driver, Manikandan.

One major reason for the haphazard parking is the series of eateries which have lined up the road. “Sometimes there are three rows of two-wheelers parked in front of these shops which leads to heavy congestion,” said K Pandiarajan, a regular commuter on this road.

The congestion due to parking on the roadsides is a major problem at Suguna store junction in Anna Nagar. Many shops have encroached the road and made it their own parking space. As the pavements are badly damaged on this stretch, people are forced to walk between the parked vehicles.

Kamarajar Salai, a trading area, is difficult to navigate through in the mornings and evenings. “The problem worsens on days when functions are held in the halls on this road. Vehicles jostle with each other for parking space and end up blocking the road,” said S Manimaran of Kamarajar Salai.
