Title: UDF calls for hartal in Kannur corp limits today
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Kannur: UDF has announced harthal in Kannur corporation limits on Thursday, till 12 noon, alleging that the LDF councillors manhandled mayor Suma Balakrishnan ahead of the council meeting on Wednesday.

The UDF said the LDF members had a fight with the UDF members in the mayor’s room and in that the mayor was manhandled in the morning. The harthal call was following that, as a mark of protest. Vehicles have been exempted from harthal, said the organizers, seeking the cooperation of the shops and establishments.

For the last few days the employees belonging to the Kerala municipal and corporation staff union, which is a pro-Left organization, has been on agitation in the corporation, alleging that the governing body is going against the democratic rights of the employees and harassing them in a different manner. The LDF councillors came to the mayor’s chamber demanding to find a solution for the issue and during the argument they manhandled her, said the Congress.

The mayor had to be taken to the hospital following a variation in blood pressure.

But the LDF claimed that the councillors did not manhandle the mayor but that the UDF councillors manhandled the LDF councillors. Four LDF councillors later got admitted to the hospital raising the complaint.

Meanwhile the Congress alleged that the CPM councillors were behaving like demons and that the police should take action against them.

The councillors physically attacked the mayor from behind without even giving her the consideration of a woman, but the police officials were mute spectators even after the mayor complained, alleged DCC president Satheesan Pacheni. He said the police should take action against the councillors who attacked the mayor, and also department-level action should be taken against the erring police officials.

Ever since the LDF lost power in the Corporation and the UDF came to power after deputy mayor P K Ragesh switched over to the Congress, the LDF and the UDF have been at loggerheads and the present issue is also a continuation of that.

Title: Constable dies as bus hits bike
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Warangal: An armed reserved constable killed in a road accident at Laknepally village of Narsampet mandal on Wednesday.

According to inspector Naveen, the deceased, identified as Maibelli Pasha, 55, was a resident of Laknepally. He was travelling towards Narsampet on his motorcycle when he was hit by a speeding engineering college bus near a hamlet close to Laknepally. The constable was severely injured and was shifted to a private hospital in Hanamkonda. However, he succumbed to his injuries. Pasha was attached to the ACP office of Narsampet as armed reserve constable. His body was handed over to his family after completion of postmortem. —Shiva Kumar Pinna

Title: Mantri vows prompt action in LED fishing
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Panaji: Following criticism that the government has been lax in implementing the ban on LED fishing, fisheries minister Filipe Neri Rodrigues assured to act against the practice within 15 days

Goenchea Raponkarancho Ekvott (GRE) and other boat owners’ associations led a delegation to the fisheries minister demanding a ban on use of LED equipment and other “destructive gear”.

GRE general secretary Olencio Simoes, also claimed that few trawlers have not only violated state laws but central laws as well. tnn

Title: Telangana: Vice president M Venkaiah Naidu to visit Warangal on February 23
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

M Venkaiah Naidu

WARANGAL: Vice-President M Venkaiah Naidu will inaugurate a three-day platinum jubilee celebration of Andhra Vidyabhi Vardhini (AVV) institutions on February 23.

Speaking to reporters, Chanda Vijaykumar, executive chairman AVV Sangham and N Narsimha Rao, president of the society, said the AVV Sangham was formed in Nizam’s era in 1944, and has successfully completed 75 years of rendering service to the needy. Business legends and well-known personalities in Warangal had convinced the Nizam and established a Telugu medium school when education was given in Urdu medium. Many political leaders were educated in this college. State planning commission vice-president Vinod Kumar and retired IAS officer Papapa Rao are alumni of the institute. --Shiva Kumar Pinna

Title: Hyderabad: 52 notices undelivered, addresses don’t exist
Content: HYDERABAD: The controversy over the issuance of notices to some of the residents in the Old City by the UIDAI regional office, Hyderabad, has taken a curious turn with 52 of the notices coming back undelivered as the addresses to which they had been sent do not exist.Highly-placed sources said some of those who received notices could be Rohingya refugees with UIDAI seeking to know as to how they obtained Aadhaar cards. Further, TOI has learnt that the total number of notices issued were 87 and not 127 as mentioned in a release of UIDAI on Tuesday night.Some time back, the Union government had made changes in the Aadhaar card rules for NRIs. The earlier condition was that Aadhaar could be obtained by Indian citizens, NRIs and even foreign nationals after residing in India for one year. The Supreme Court gave a ruling that Aadhaar card cannot be issued to illegal migrants.“In view of the changes in the Aadhaar rules for NRIs and the apex court ruling, we need to verify as to who they were and how did they obtain Aadhaar cards,” a senior UIDAI official on condition of anonymity told TOI. He was referring to some of the residents of the Old City, who were issued the notices. “We have issued the notices based on a report of the state police,” he elaborated further.Senior officials said some of the complaints and the report they had received clearly mentioned that they were not Indian nationals. “We mentioned the same in the notices issued to them. Our job is find out whether they had obtained the Aadhaar cards by false pretences during enrolment. We are not asking them to prove their citizenship,” the officials said.UIDAI considered inputs from a TV channel’s sting operation on Aadhaar cards apart from the state intelligence department’s report on how some persons had obtained the Aadhaar cards, sources said.In Tuesday’s press release, UIDAI said the notices had nothing to do with citizenship of the residents and that Aadhaar was not a document of citizenship.

Title: Officials seek CM’s help to reopen plant
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Palakkad: The top officials of PepsiCo India Limited’s bottling plant run by Varun Beverages Limited at Kanjikode met chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan and director general of police Loknath Behra in Thiruvananthapuram on Wednesday and sought their immediate intervention to reopen the soft drink unit which has remained closed for last 12 days due to strike by workers of a labour supplier.

The company officials said that the CM and the DGP assured all help to reopen the company unit. Meanwhile the labour commissioner has called a meeting on Thursday of the labour contract company representatives and the trade union leaders to discuss the issue as the meeting called by the district labour officer here on Tuesday failed to reach any settlement on the wage increase of Rs 250 demanded by the workers daily.

The company management wrote to industries minister E P Jayarajan and labour minister T P Ramakrishnan on Monday for their immediate intervention to reopen the company that has been closed since February 8.

The company is not directly involved in the issue because the striking contract worskers are not employees of the PepsiCo India Limited or Varun Beverages Limited, the officials said.

They said that “running a factory in Kerala has become very difficult. Some people here think that running a factory is a crime in the state. In this situation we will be forced to move out of the state.”

The closure resulted in a huge loss to the company and more than 150 permanent and 500 indirect employees were affected.

The officials said that though the Kerala high court on February 12 ordered that “police shall accord necessary protection to the petitioner and his employees and shall ensure that no obstruction is caused to the smooth functioning of the petitioner’s establishment at the hands of the party\ respondents for their association,” the company did not get any protection.

Meanwhile district superintendent of police G Siva Vikram said, “police presence is very much there in front of the company to avoid any untoward incident. If the police intervene to remove the striking workers forcefully, there could be a law and order problem.”

The company officials filed an FIR in Walayar police station on Tuesday against eight persons who had allegedly attacked them outside the company area.

Title: Amit Shah likely to visit Hyderabad on March 15
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Amit Shah

HYDERABAD: Union home minister Amit Shah is likely visit Hyderabad on March 15 to address a meeting on Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA).

The state BJP unit has booked the Lal Bahadur Shastri Stadium for the meeting, which will be held in the evening. The state BJP unit had sought his dates on March 7 and 14, but Shah had asked them to conduct the meeting on March 15. tnn

Title: Can’t freeze assets of ex-MD of PNB in Nirav scam: SC
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

NEW DELHI: The Supreme Court has ordered that the Union government could not have moved under company law for freezing the assets of ex-managing director of Punjab National Bank Usha Ananthasubramanian, who was chargesheeted by the CBI in the Rs 14,000 crore loan default scam allegedly engineered by Nirav Modi and Mehul Choksi.

A bench of Justices R F Nariman, S Ravindra Bhat and V Ramasubramanian in a recent order said the powers under Sections 241, 337 and 339 of the Companies Act could not be utilised to attach assets of persons heading a bank or any organisation when the fraud was not committed by that particular organisation.

It clarified that these provisions of Company Act related to persons responsible for the business of the company that indulged in the fraud leading to defaulting of the loan and not to the business of another company or persons heading it.

Appearing for Ananthasubramanian, senior advocate C S Vaidyanathan and advocate Vikrant Singh Negi told the bench that the CBI chargesheet against several senior officials of PNB and directors of Gitanjali Gems, at best, showed that she “omitted to take precautions or preventive steps to prevent the fraud perpetrated by Nirav Modi and thereby committed misconduct and conspiracy with other accused”.

Vaidyanathan said provisions of the Company Act permitted the government to move for attachment of property of those officials involved with the running of the company accused of fraud and, hence, could not be used against the ex-MD of PNB.

Writing the judgment for the bench, Justice Nariman said, “Under Section 241(2), the central government, if it is of the opinion that the affairs of the company are being conducted in a manner prejudicial to public interest, may apply itself to the tribunal for orders under this chapter, which is headed ‘prevention of oppression and mismanagement’.”

He added, “Section 337 refers to penalty for frauds by an officer of the company in which mis-management has taken place. Likewise, Section 339 refers to any business of the company which has been carried on with intent to defraud creditors of that company. Obviously, the persons referred to in Section 339(1) as persons who are other than the parties ‘to the carrying on of the business in the manner aforesaid’ which again refers to the business of the company which is being mismanaged and not to the business of another company or other persons.”

The bench further said, “This being the case, it is clear that powers under these sections cannot possibly be utilised in order that a person who may be the head of some other organisation be roped in, and his or her assets be attached. This being the case, we set aside the impugned order passed by the NCLAT and well as the NCLT. The appeal is allowed in the aforesaid terms. We may clarify that nothing stated in this judgment will have any effect insofar as the investigation conducted by the CBI or the investigation by the SFIO is concerned.”

Title: Double Decker Bus in Kolkata: Double Decker Buses set to return to kolkata roads
Content:
Double-decker buses are set to return to the city

KOLKATA: Double-decker buses — the lumbering behemoths of everyday commute once ubiquitous on Kolkata’s streets, but phased out since the early 90s — are set to return to the city, exactly a century since the first one arrived during British rule, but in a swankier avatar.Until the certification comes from the Central Institute of Road Transport (CIRT) — merely a formality, according to sources — there are no approved double-decker models, since no Indian automobile manufacturer makes them. Officials at the West Bengal transport department said the final nod is expected by this month, allowing the two buses to hit the road early March.Kolkata, also, is on the cusp of leading the second wave of double-decker buses in metros across the country. Once CIRT gives its final certification to the two buses designed and developed indigenously, those will be the latest approved model of double-deckers across the country.“These buses will open a new vista for the reintroduction of double-deckers across the nation, particularly in the form of electric vehicles (EV),” said a transport department official. “As of now, the two buses are diesel-run, but unlike the earlier double-deckers, which were fuel guzzlers, these are BS-IV compliant and fuel-efficient,” he added.In the late 1980s, the then Left government in Bengal had decided to decommission double-deckers in phases as the fleet guzzled fuel. They also belched black smoke, but that wasn’t much of a concern then. By 2005, the last double-decker went off road. In Mumbai, double-deckers still ply but the number is on the decline. At present, BEST has 48 double-deckers, down from more than 250.

Title: Coronavirus in Chennai: 2 Chinese test negative for COVID-19
Content:
Representative image

CHENNAI: After a minor scare over COVID-19 infection of two crew members of a Chinese ship that berthed off Chennai port on Tuesday, state health authorities have declared that both tested negative for the infection.Chennai Port Trust said the vessel M V Magnate with 19 Chinese crew visited Chinese ports before being berthed off Chennai. Its last port of call was Shanghai. After the ship was berthed, a health team with the Port health officer boarded the vessel and examined all the crew members.During the examination, it was found that two crew members had mild fever without other respiratory symptoms. Otherwise, both of them were healthy, a release said.The crew members were isolated on the ship, which has been kept out of bounds for people from the shore. No crew from the ship is allowed shore access.The health team and health officer visited the ship on Wednesday morning and collected blood samples after taking due precautions as per standard operating procedures. The samples were sent to King’s Institute of Preventive Medicine, Guindy.Port Trust authorities said with the two crew members testing negative for COVID-19, the ship will now be allowed to unload its cargo as per standard operating procedures for safe port operations. Crew members will be monitored 24X7 till the ship sails out of Chennai port waters. However, the Chinese crew has been denied landing permission as per government regulations and it will be strictly followed during their stay in the port, the authorities added.Meanwhile, passengers of flights from China, Hong Kong, Thailand, Singapore, Japan and South Korea are being screened through thermal screening at airports. More than 50,000 passengers have been screened at the airports in Chennai, Trichy, Madurai and Coimbatore.As per health department records, 2,324 passengers are under home quarantine for 28 days. All 46 samples obtained from the passengers tested negative for COVID-19 infection. The health condition of the passengers under observation at home was stable.

Title: Rs 500 cr allocated for AI reseach centre for healthcare
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

IIIT-Hyderabad, Indian Institute of Public Health and US chipmaker Intel along with the Telangana government on Wednesday announced the setting up of the Applied AI Research Centre For Mobility & Healthcare in Hyderabad. The centre will be coming up on the IIIT-Hyderabad campus and will entail an investment of around Rs 500 crore over next five years, Ramesh Loganathan, professor of practice, co-innovations at IIIT-Hyderabad said.Speaking earlier at a BioAsia session Intel India country head, Nivruti Rai, pointed out that emerging technologies such as AI and Machine Learning (ML) can be leveraged to boost healthcare services delivery in a country like India that lacks adequate resources for all. TNN

Title: USP to expand its presence in Hyderabad
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

HYDERABAD: The United States Pharmacopeial Convention ( USP ), a non-profit scientific organisation that develops and disseminates public compendial quality standards for medicines and other articles, is expanding its presence in Hyderabad, which houses its largest centre outside the US.

It currently has around 250 people at its Hyderabad facility and is now looking at adding about 70 more employees over the next three to four months, KV Surendra Nath, senior vice president-global sites, USP, told TOI. The facility, which was set up nearly 15 years ago, will be ramping up headcount in analytics and biologics, Nath said.

Title: SDPI & oppn parties protest Delhi violence
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Trichy: Violence in New Delhi reverberated in Trichy on Wednesday with the Social Democratic Party of India (SDPI) and opposition parties including the CPM holding agitations demanding action against the perpetrators of violence.

SDPI cadres including women staged an agitation alleging that the BJP supporters launched an indiscriminate attack on people who have been leading peaceful protests against CAA, National Register of Citizens (NRC) and National Population Register (NPR) in the national capital for the past two months. SDPI Trichy unit staged an agitation near Ramakrishna bridge near Palakkarai on Wednesday evening. More than 350 people including 50 women participated in the agitation. They raised slogans against the central government for the violence on the anti-CAA protesters in New Delhi. The protesters condemned BJP MLA Kapil Mishra for his alleged ‘provocative remarks’ against the anti-CAA protesters. The CPM organized an agitation in Woraiyur on Wednesday. VCK cadres also joined them in the protest. As many as 80 people including women took part in the stir and raised slogans.

Trichy district secretary of CPM R Raja who led the protest accused the RSS of instigating violence against the anti-CAA protesters in New Delhi. “The violence was manufactured by RSS. Those igniting violence should be brought under law,” he said. On Tuesday, the KK Nagar police registered cases against 25 students of various colleges for staging a protest outside Jamal Mohammed College (JMC) against the attack on anti-CAA protesters in New Delhi.

Title: Hyderabad: Biased UIDAI abusing power, says Asaduddin Owaisi
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Asaduddin Owaisi

HYDERABAD: AIMIM chief Asaduddin Owaisi on Wednesday accused the UIDAI of abusing power after it sent notices to 87 people for obtaining Aadhaar cards on false pretence.

Owaisi, who is leading a campaign against CAA and NRC, alleged that the Aadhar authority has exceeded its power, created panic among people and was biased. His reaction came soon after UIDAI tweeted that 127 people in the city obtained Aadhaar cards on false pretences and primary enquiry revealed that many were illegal migrants, and were not eligible to obtain Aadhaar card.

Owaisi also requested UIDAI and Telangana police to roll out the percentage of Muslims and Dalits among the people to whom notices have been served.

“Request @UIDAI & @TelanganaPolice to tell us how many of those 127-listed people are Muslim & Dalit @TelanganaPolice please stop asking for Aadhaar during your “search & cordon” operations. You’re not legally permitted to do so UIDAI sent notices to 127 people in Hyderabad for obtaining Aadhaar on false pretences” tweeted Owaisi.

He also said that Aadhaar authority has no right to verify citizenship and their notices have created panic among people. “UIDAI did not follow due procedure & abused its powers. The result was (understandably) panic among people First, @UIDAI has no power to verify citizenship. It has few powers to consider some cases of Aadhaar being granted incorrectly (rules 27 & 28),” tweeted Owaisi.

UIDAI also clarified on twitter that Aadhaar is not a citizenship document. Owaisi said the deputy director (UIDAI) has turned the case into citizenship verification which he is not empowered to and claimed that notices don’t even have the details of false pretences.

Title: Bilingual writer’s book on Puducherry history launched
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Puducherry: The fourth edition of the book , ‘A Concise History of Pondicherry’, by bi-lingual writer P Raja was released during the recently-concluded Pondicherry Heritage Festival at Palais de Mahe, a resort in the town.

Assisi Peace Centre director Fr A S Antonisamy released the book and All India Radio director Dakshinamurthy received the first copy in the presence of Raja, Sunaina Mandeen, Pondy Citizen Action Network (Pondy Can) co-founder, and Sunaina Narang, Pallavan Learning System (New Delhi) managing director and others.

Antonisamy, while addressing the gathering, said the gripping book unravels the history of Puducherry. “In writing this book its author has very much relied upon the folklore of Pondicherry. Through its folktales and folksongs, the author traces beautifully the history of this significant speck on the map of India. No wonder that the book, published by Busy Bee Books, Pondicherry, makes a magnificent read,” Antonisamy said.

Raja told the gathering that his interest in his home-town began when he was a student of Petit Seminaire HSS. He recalled how he derived inspiration from Fr S Peter, then principal of the school. He shared his experience with the audience on the study and documentation of the folklore of Puducherry and outlined how he put them to use in writing the book. He acknowledged that the storytelling technique he adopted in writing the book made him go for the fourth edition within a short period.

Title: Pune: Doctor falls for MRI scan machine bait, loses Rs 35 lakh
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The director of a Kolkata-based private firm, along with two others, was booked on Tuesday on the charge of duping a city-based medical practitioner of Rs 35 lakh on the prextext of providing him with an imported MRI scan machine .

The 34-year-old complainant had transferred the amount on November 10 last year through RTGS. When he did not get the promised machine for over two months, he lodged an FIR with the Kothrud police.

The police said the director of the firm approached the complainant, who runs a healthcare centre on Karve Road, last year. “The suspect gained the complainant’s confidence by helping him in selling a medical equipment from his healthcare centre,” an officer from the Kothrud police said.

The officer said in the first week of November, the suspect had contacted the medical practitioner and told him that he could arrange an imported MRI machine from a hospital in Malaysia. “The person told the complainant that the machine was worth Rs 35 lakh,” he said.

On November 10, the suspect contacted the complainant again. “He told the complainant that if the machine remains idle for more than 15 days, the helium gas in it might leak out and he might have to pay Rs 15 lakh extra for the refill,” the officer said.

Following this, the complainant transferred the asked amount, after which the suspect sent him the receipt with the photographs of the machine. “The suspect told the complainant he would get the machine within a week,” the officer said.

The medical practitioner started pursuing the suspect when he did not get the delivery. He visited his office at Gahunje and met the suspect’s wife, who promised the delivery of the unit at the earliest. After few days, when the complainant visited the officer again, he found it locked. “He told the suspect to cancel the order and return the money. At that time, the suspect promised to return Rs 5 lakh. The medical practitioner, however, did not get the amount and the machine,” the officer said.

Title: Private schools demand pending RTE dues of last two years
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: A large section of private schools coming under the ambit of RTE Act 2009 has raised grievances over non-release of dues towards admissions done under 25% quota among other issues since the academic year 2018-19.

Maharashtra English School Trustees Association (MESTA), a body of private unaided English schools said the state government dues towards RTE admissions have been withheld from the last two years. “The government had released a partial amount of dues corresponding to the academic year 2017-18. We cannot disown the students admitted under the 25% quota concerned, but the government should not taste our patience,” MESTA president Sanjay Tayade said.

While the government reimburses a sum of around Rs 17,600 towards each student admitted under the RTE Act, the private schools owe a whopping Rs 700 crore from the government, MESTA has said.

Among other issues related to RTE admissions, several private schools have demanded separate arrangements from the government for providing uniforms, school books, and food. “The government reimburses money towards tuition fees only and parents of the beneficiaries have to bear expenses towards other essentials such as uniforms, school books, and food. Several beneficiary parents find it difficult to arrange the money for the same. The government must either provide money to beneficiaries for the same or give grants to schools for providing the daily essentials,” MESTA joint secretary Manish Hande said.

Among other RTE-related demands, MESTA has pressed for a pension scheme for teachers from schools that come under the ambit of the legislation concerned. “Despite having private managements, our teachers are rendering services towards the implementation of the government welfare scheme in the field of education by implementing the RTE Act. Therefore, teachers must get a pension from the government. A separate pension scheme can be worked out for teachers,” MESTA members said.

As many as 9,328 private schools are part of the admissions under the RTE Act having a collective intake capacity of 1,15,191 seats.

When contacted, authorities from Aurangabad Zilla Parishad said the demands raised by MESTA fall in the purview of the state government. “The state-level authorities are expected to take a call on different demands of private schools related to RTE Act, including pending reimbursement,” authorities said.

Title: Oz heritage experts to help restore Humayun Mahal
Content: Chennai: Australian forensics and Tamil traditional building methods may soon find a creative meeting point at Humayun Mahal at the Chepauk Palace . AusHeritage, an Australian network of heritage experts and architects on Wednesday held discussions with the state public works department on restoring the building that suffered serious damages in a fire accident in 2012.“The Australians use forensic methods to restore monuments, while we use traditional methods,” said C Kalyanasundaram, superintendent engineer, building centre and conservation, PWD. Before visiting the site, we had an elaborate discussion with the Australian delegates and exchanged ideas. We are looking forward to their involvement.”K P Sathyamurthy, joint chief engineer, PWD, said Humayun Mahal and the palace which it is a part of were built using the best quality materials available 250 years ago. “We have decided to use traditional methods,” he said.As he explained the method to the Australians, Sathyamurthy showed them the materials used — eggs, curd, aloe vera, palm jaggery and limestone ground using Kangeyam bulls.“If the palm jaggery is wet and dripping, it is not to be used. It has to be dry,” said Sathyamurthy.“This morning we spent half a day with officials sharing knowledge on traditional and intangible heritage. We were given a presentation on how colonial buildings are preserved in Australia, the methodology, the process and all aspects. They also explained about their work and both parties got a sense of what each specialises in. We will soon work on the specifics,” said Vinod Daniel, chairman of AusHeritage.“The idea is to exchange knowledge and do things in a better way. We want to collaborate and produce something that will have a legacy, like this monument,” said Munish Sharma, trade commissioner and consul, Australian government.In Video: Australian heritage experts to help restore Humayun Mahal

Title: Mumbai: Ejaz Lakdawala probe blows lid off gold smuggling racket
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Gangster Ejaz Lakdawala

MUMBAI: The city crime branch stumbled upon a gold smuggling racket while investigating the alleged hushing up of an extortion case involving gangster Ejaz Lakdawala and police informer Salim Maharaj.

The crime branch has identified more than a dozen persons involved in smuggling gold from the Gulf.

Last week, Mumbai police commissioner Sanjay Barve ordered an inquiry on learning that some police officers had hurriedly transferred an extortion case from Pydhonie police station to M R A Marg without citing valid reasons. It was also learnt MRA Marg police officers did nothing to bring the case to its logical end.

Crime branch Unit I, which is conducting the inquiry, learnt that the hushed up case related to a dispute between the gold smugglers and a woman carrier. In June 2018, one Sumaiyla who lives at Null Bazaar smuggled in gold strapped to her body. She returned from Dubai to Bengaluru airport and called one Imtiaz and told him that she was being followed by some people. Imtiaz brought her to Mumbai and the very next day she allegedly began to receive calls from gangster Tariq Parveen, a Lakdawala aide, and Maharaj. The duo threatened Sumaiyla saying she must hand over 600 grams of gold or be killed.

They called Sumaiyla to Rafai Towers in Pydhonie. She, Imtiaz and his friend Saddiq were then assaulted and threatened saying if they failed to get the gold, they would be handed over to the cops. Frightened, Sumaiyla, Saddiq and Imitiaz then approached police and lodged a complaint saying they were confined, assaulted and threatened at gunpoint by Tariq and Salim.

During inquiry, police summoned Imitaz, Saddiq, Sumaiyla and her friend Reshma who shared information about such smuggling rackets in South Mumbai.

It is learnt that the smugglers mostly hail from Kerala and live in Dongri in dormitories.

They handpick young women and men who want a sponsored trip to Dubai. They are offered a small shopping allowance and free three- four day stay. On every kilo of gold smuggled into India, smugglers earn make Rs 3-4 lakh profit.

“A carrier carries around 500 to 600 gram of gold biscuits on her body,” said an informer. The carriers prefer to land in Chennai or Bengaluru due to laxity in customs. From there, they either reach Mumbai by road or rail and hand over the packets to their mentors.

“Among the carriers, there are some who steal 50gm to 100gm of gold from a consignment and if smugglers ask about it, they threaten to file molestation or rape cases against them,” said a police officer.

Title: Maharashtra: FIR over videos linking poultry with coronavirus
Content:
This caused undue fear amon people and eventually hit the demand for poultry products

PUNE: The state animal husbandry department on Wednesday lodged an FIR with the cybercrime police station here in relation to three misleading videos uploaded on the social media and a video-sharing platform, which linked the spread of coronavirus infection with consumption of poultry meat.“We have registered an offence under Section 505 (1) (b) of the Indian Penal Code, which refers to acts intended at causing fear or alarm to the public,” inspector Jayram Paygude of the cybercrime police station told TOI.The move comes close on the heels of a delegation of poultry farmers and breeders’ body meeting animal husbandry, marketing and dairy development minister Sunil Kedar recently to raise their concern about a sudden fall in the demand for poultry meat due to misleading videos and messages.The minister had then instructed the state animal husbandry commissioner to take appropriate steps. Assistant commissioner of the animal husbandry department Shriram Sitaram Pawar on Wednesday filed the complaint with the cybercrime police station.Paygude said the department came across three such videos, in which the presenter was seen urging people at large against consuming chicken and eggs. The presenter claimed that the coronavirus was transmitted through the flesh of the animals and birds, especially poultry chicken and eggs.According to the complaint, these videos, along with the long text messages, were circulated on different social networking sites, among others. “Many people, who received these video clips forwarded them without understanding the facts. This caused undue fear among people and they stopped eating chicken and eggs, thus, adversely impacting the demand of eggs and meat,” he said.“The contents of these videos were examined by the authorities from the animal husbandry department, which were found utterly false and misleading,” he added.“We are yet to ascertain the motive behind these videos and why people circulated them on the social networking sites,” he said.

Title: HC seeks reports on observation homes
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Hyderabad: Expressing concern over the plight of children locked in government shelter homes run by irresponsible and insensitive staff, Telangana high court on Wednesday sought detailed reports on the facilities available in these observation homes and the conditions prevailing in them, by April 15.

The bench comprising Chief Justice Raghavendra Singh Chauhan and Justice A Abhishek Reddy took note of the serious contents in a letter written by district and sessions judge, Karimnagar about the condition of the observation homes in the district and converted that letter into a PIL. TNN

Title: I was born in Hyderabad & still being asked to prove my nationality: Old City resident
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Mohammed Sattar Khan

CHARMINAR: Mohammed Sattar Khan, who is among the 87 people from Old City who received notices from Unique Identification Authority of India ( UIDAI ) for obtaining Aadhaar cards on the false pretence, told TOI that the claims were baseless and his family has been living in Hyderabad for decades.

He wondered how could UIDAI send notice or call him to prove his citizenship without a proper check.

“I have been residing in Bhavani Nagar Talab Katta for the past several years. I was born and brought up here, I have two daughters and a son. After so many years, I am being asked to prove my citizenship, how can it be possible? The notice will be challenged in court and I have discussed the matter with my counsel Muzafferullah Khan,” Sattar Khan said on Wednesday.

He added that like every citizen he also stood in long queues in 2007 to obtain Aadhaar card and despite that he is being asked to prove his citizenship again.

Senior advocate Muzafferullah Khan told TOI that the legal process has been initiated and the matter has been taken up in the court.

GHMC ward committee member and AIMIM leader, Talaha Kaseri, said: “It seems like UIDAI is abusing its power by serving such notices without checking the facts.”

Meanwhile, Telangana Advocates Joint Action Committee (JAC) demanded that UIDAI should withdraw the notices immediately.

Terming the notices arbitrary, unlawful and unconstitutional, Telangana Advocates JAC convener Mohammed Wali-ur-Rahman said the UIDAI should clarify that on what basis the notices have been issued. “Such notices are considered as arbitrary, illegal and unconstitutional. On what basis have these notices been served and what authority does UIDAI have to call people to prove their citizenship,” asked Wali-ur-Rahman.

The JAC has decided to move the high court against UIDAI.

“If the Aadhaar card is not correct then it could be cancelled, but how can someone be called to prove their nationality or citizenship by claiming that their Aadhaar card is false. These notices will only add to public woes at a time when anti-CAA protests are going on,” said Wali-ur-Rahman.

Title: Mumbai News: How this south Mumbai wine shop owner trapped extortionists
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

CCTV film shows an extortionist trapped by staffers as he returned to collect ‘hafta’on Tuesday

MUMBAI: A few men in white linen clothes walked into a liquor shop on Sidhwa Road in Fort last week. And posing as political party workers, they asked the staff if they had a licence and other documents.

But, little did they know that the shop belonged to Ashok Patel , 65, who had got 117 persons—including cops, I-T staff and officials of various departments—arrested for extortion in the last 25 years.

They learnt it the hard way on Tuesday when one of them returned to knock off ‘hafta’ (bribe) of Rs 7 lakh. How? Patel and his staff literally made a ‘trap’: they locked the door from outside and called up the police control room. The Marine Drive police then arrived and arrested Rajendra Waghmare, a Dadar resident, making him Number 118. His three accomplices too were arrested, taking Patel’s ‘trapped’ count to 121.

Among 117 trapped over the last 25 years were police inspector Anand Bhoir, held for demanding and accepting Rs22 lakh last year, and various sales tax and I-T personnel, policemen, BMC officials, fire brigade staff, Railway Protection Force cops, Mhada officials and smugglers and drug peddlers. Of the 117 ‘trapped,’ 35 were frauds posing as government officers.

“The four men had been asking for monthly ‘hafta’ of Rs7 lakh and a few wine bottles. I am an honest tax-payer and don’t indulge in illegal activities, so why should I pay them? I kept bargaining with them and on Tuesday, they thought they could make a final deal,” said Patel, who is president of the Fort Merchants Association which represents the interests of 425 shopkeepers and traders.

Tuesday’s incident, where Waghmare parked his car outside the wine shop and walked in and demanded money, has been captured in the shop’s CCTV cameras. Patel’s son Bhavesh called up the police after one of the staffers had locked the main door from outside. During interrogation, Waghmare told police about his three aides——Sanjay Ahire, Janardhan Gyanit and Manish Tambe— and police suspect they may have been collecting money from other shopkeepers in the area as well.

Patel, who hails from Bhuj, said he feels “relieved” every time he traps people on the wrong side of the law and has received more than 100 cash rewards and certificates from government agencies so far. “The most remarkable case was in 2012, when I tipped off the income-tax department and got a cash reward of Rs5 lakh,” he said. He added that he was not much educated but was “tech savvy” and had “all modern gadgets to tape, video-record and do sting operations.”

Recalling a December 2003 case where he helped the Cuffe Parade police to catch three policemen who had kidnapped three traders from Hutatma Chowk, he said the traders had been held by their kidnappers under the Chowpatty bridge for a ransom demand of Rs25,000. He has also helped the authorities in Gujarat to crack some cases, he added

Title: Symbiosis institute gets accreditation from AACSB
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Pune: The Symbiosis Centre for Management and Human Resource Development ( SCMHRD ) recently became the first institute in the city to get the accreditation of the Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business ( AACSB ).

AACSB is an internationally recognized body that provides business education intelligence, quality assurance and professional development services to over 1,700 member organizations and over 840 accredited business schools worldwide.

“In India, Symbiosis Centre for Management and Human Resource Development is the 14th B-school that is accredited by AACSB. Some of the other institutions that hold this accreditation include ISB (Hyderabad), IIMs (Kolkata, Indore, Udaipur), among others. Only 5% of the business schools across the globe hold the AACSB accreditation,” Vidya Yeravdekar, the principal director of Symbiosis Society , said.

Pratima Sheorey, director of Symbiosis Centre for Management and Human Resource Development, said the institute formally entered the accreditation process in 2014.

“The next five years had endless rounds of brainstorming, re-engineering, putting the thoughts to action and developing a robust ‘assurance of learning’ and various other processes as mandated by the AACSB,” Sheorey said.

She added that regular annual and sometimes biennial updates were sought by the AACSB to the standards on which they evaluate institutions.

“After five long years of work and reporting, the peer-review team was assigned to Symbiosis Centre for Management and Human Resource Development, which visited the college, interviewed the stakeholders, assessed all processes and documents and then recommended that the institute be accorded with the accreditation,” Sheorey added.

Title: Monitor lizard rescued from water tank in Nakshatrawadi
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

The reptile was spotted by the owner of the hotel

AURANGABAD: A monitor lizard (Ghorpad) was recently rescued from the water tank of one of the hotels based on the outskirts of the city in Nakshatrawadi .

The reptile was spotted by the owner of the hotel, Monisha Brahma, who then called the animal rescuers.

“The monitor lizard had apparently fallen in the tank for a few days, but went unnoticed. The rescue team safely removed the reptile without hurting it. The operation that lasted for 20 minutes,” environmentalist Kishor Pathak said.

“The lizard, weighing around 5 kg and 65cm in length, was offered necessary aid before being released into the wild with permission from the forest department,” rescue expert Manoj Gaikwad said.

“The monitor lizard is a reptile which is shy in nature. The creature avoids coming into contact of humans or their habitat. The rescued lizard must have strayed into human area in search of food or water,” he added.

Usually found near farm lands, rocky hill region or jungles, the monitor lizard is a carnivorous creature and feeds on rodents, crustacean snails, snakes, scorpion, birds, eggs and insects.

“Nakshatrawadi area is on the outskirts and one of the biodiversity-rich habitats around Aurangabad. The area has mountain ranges and waterbodies making it a suitable place for different creatures. However, the growing construction activities in the area is leading to man-animal conflict,” Pathak said.

Hunting monitor lizard attracts provisions of Schedule I of the Wild Life Protection Act, which is tantamount to hunting a tiger. “It is believed that eating the meat of monitor lizard increases sexual power in humans. However, there is no scientific evidence to prove this myth,” Pathak said.

Title: Funds allotted for 4th Egmore, Beach rail track
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

CHENNAI: Finally, a long-pending demand of Southern Railway is set to be fulfilled. The fourth line between Chennai Egmore and Beach railway stations would soon become reality, as the railway ministry had allotted funds for taking up the work.

Chennai divisional railway manager P Mahesh told TOI that the fourth line between Egmore and Beach will cover 4.30 km. Despite the short distance, due to lack of the fourth line, long distance express trains or freight trains from Tambaram heading to Arakkonam or Gummidipoondi had to be operated on a single line and were halted at various stations before reaching Beach. This can be avoided when the fourth line is laid.

At present, many trains from the southern parts of the state use Egmore and Beach stations to proceed to Coimbatore, Mumbai and Gummidipoondi towards Andhra Pradesh and beyond. Hence, the Southern Railway is keen on the fourth line, he said. Another official said MGR Chennai Central is saturated and no new trains can be added due to space constraints. In an effort to cut congestion in MGR Central it has been proposed to shift a few trains to Tambaram, after making it a second terminal, the official said. This would also help decongest Egmore station too to some extent, he said.

To begin with, Southern Railway will start survey work for the fourth line. It will be completed in six months as Southern Railway is keen to finish the project at the earliest. Along the stretch, land acquisition has been a major impediment. It can be addressed only with the support and cooperation of the Tamil Nadu government, the official said. Track laying won’t take too long the official added. The fourth line will go up to Royapuram and along the route a large number of encroachments have to be removed by the state authorities.

Title: Nath govt approves new Film Tourism Policy
Content:
This story is from February 20, 2020

Bhopal: A month before the IIFA Awards in the state, the Kamal Nath government on Wednesday approved the Film Tourism Policy,2020.

The cabinet headed by chief minister Kamal Nath approved the policy to make Madhya Pradesh attractive for film producers and encourage investment by private players. Under the policy, 50% of a feature film shot in the state will be given a subsidy of up to Rs1 crore.

Law minister P C Sharma explained that it will be a special subsidy. If in a three-hour film, Madhya Pradesh is featured for one-and-half hours, then the movie will get 50% subsidy on production cost of a maximum of Rs1 crore. “Feature films, television serials, web series shows and documentaries will get benefit of the subsidy scheme,” the minister said.

“It will generate employment and help skill development. The state will also get publicity and substantial screen time,” Sharma added.

The policy has more benefits for shooting international and south Indian movies. There will also be land allotments, financial incentives and grants for construction of permanent infrastructures such as studios and film cities. Film production teams will be given necessary clearances, permissions and benefits within a fixed time limit.

Services will be given at concessional rates by the Madhya Pradesh Tourism Development Corporation (MPTDC). A film facilitation cell will be set up for implementation of the new policy. Permission for film certification will also be granted through a single window system. The policy will also encourage renovation and incentivise single screen cinema halls, closed cinema halls and give boost to new multiplexes. Workshops will also be held on films and film studies.

Title: Pune region records highest number of organ donations for a month in January
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Pune region recorded the highest number of organ donations in a month from 10 brain dead donors in January this year, giving a thrust to the movement aimed at saving lives.This was possible after relatives of brain-dead came forward to donate vital organs, mainly kidney and liver, that benefitted 23 needy patients suffering from end-stage renal and liver failure in Pune, Solapur , Kolhapur and Nashik .This is the highest number of brain-dead donors recorded in a month ever since the Zonal Transplant Coordination Committee (ZTCC) that oversees organ donation became functional in Pune in 2004. "This is the first time that Pune region has recorded vital organ donations from 10 brain-dead donors in a month that benefitted 23 needy patients. A few years ago, this used to be the number for the whole year,” Aarti Gokhale, transplant coordinator of Zonal Transplant Coordination Committee (ZTCC), Pune region, told TOI.Of the 10 brain-dead donors whose family members donated their vital organs in Pune region, Pune city registered organ donations from six donors followed by Solapur (2) and one each from Nashik and Kolhapur. In 2019, of the 63 brain-dead donors in the Pune region, 11 were from small cities like Nashik, Solapur, Kolhapur and Sangli, while 52 were from Pune city. The contribution from these four small cities prior to 2016 was nil.Nephrologist Basavraj Kolur, chairman, Yashodhara Superspeciality Hospital, in Solapur, said, “Hospitals having approval for organ transplant are appointing transplant coordinators to counsel relatives of the brain-dead for organ donation.”

Title: Pune: Retired bank official duped of Rs 3.29 lakh in online trap
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: A cybercrook represented himself as an executive of a UPI application and duped a senior citizen (77) of Rs 3.29 lakh under the pretext of updating his KYC on January 4.The elderly man filed a complaint with the cyber police station immediately and lodged an FIR with the Kothrud police on Tuesday.The complainant, a retired general manager of a private bank, shared his bank account number, net banking password, credit card details and the one time passwords (OTPs) with the cybercrook.The police investigation revealed that the siphoned amount was transferred to different bank accounts, mainly in Kolkata, and also in Jharkhand and Haryana. “We have ascertained the identify of one suspect. Our probe is on,” Kiran Balwadkar, inspector of the Kothrud police, said.On January 4, the complainant had received an SMS stating his KYC had expired. The SMS mentioned a number, which he would have to contact immediately, or his account would be blocked within 24 hours. When the complainant contacted the cellphone number, the person on the other end told him his KYC had expired. He said it would need to be updated or else the company would block the account. “The person also offered to update the elderly man’s KYC online,” Balwadkar said.He said the person told the complainant to download an app on his cellphone. He told the elderly man that to to update his KYC, he would have to do an online transaction of Re1. The suspect then asked him for his account number and net banking password. “The complainant shared his account number, password and five OTPs with the suspect,” Balwadkar said.The person then told the complainant to share the details of his credit card. He also shared the OTP. “The complainant then became suspicious and disconnected the call. He tried to contact the bank’s customer care number, but he could not connect. Later in the night, the complainant started receiving messages from the bank about the money being debited from his account and also from the credit card,” Balwadkar said.On January 5, he found that Rs3.29 lakh had been siphoned from his bank account and credit card collectively.Balwadkar said the UPI application does not send such messages to its customers. “People should not share details of their bank accounts, credit and debit cards with unknown persons,” the inspector said.
